reviewText:
This review is an open letter to one of the developers, Jane Ng, the lead environmental artist at Campo Santo.

Jane recently made a very thoughtful post right here on the Steam Community Forums...

-----------

hey there.

I thought about not responding
date: because normally ppl who want to refund are rude and unpleasant and I choose to not engage and dwell on it.\n\nYou seem nice and I figured what the heck
recommended: why not have a conversation about this
hoursPlayed:
now that I have read it and it's right here in front of me.

So here is what I think. As the developer. Sorry if it's a bit stream of consciousness because I want this to come from the heart.

The 11 of us all took a lot of risk to make this
voteText: and sacrificed financially to give Firewatch a chance. We all could have had much better paying jobs elsewhere
helpfulPercent: but we all thought this game idea had potential to be something special. We seemed to like each other ok
votesHelpful: so we all took a big leap of faith. Two years
votesTotal: we say. Let's give this a go
votesFunny: worst outcome is we all hate each other and go back to various money jobs
commentsCount: but we all could say
column16: WE TRIED.\n\nTwo years +. We are all crammed in a tiny office
column17: sharing one bathroom. It is not a glamorous thing
column18: making an independent game. It is just a small room full of computers and a used microwave and $10 office chairs we luckily got from craigslist. Life happened during those two years: there were big breakups
column19: profound illnesses of loved ones
column20: a baby
column21: etc. The dev team got to be like family
column22: because that's how making an indie game is
column23: you are all in it together
column24: through thick and thin
column25: supporting one another bc if you don't
column26: there is no way in hell this game would get made

column28: but terrified. We felt free

column30: and this is the hardest I have ever worked. We all gave it our all
column32: and we had no idea if it was any good to anybody else. All we could do

column34: if this was a commercial failure
column35: all we have got is what we have made. Nobody could take that away.\n\nSo yes

reviewText:
So close to being a great game. Short, but that's not a big issue. My biggest beef is with the ending - it ended very abruptly for me, and the payoff wasn't there. Up until the last second, I was expecting more, and if this was Firewatch, Episode 1, I would've given a 9/10. Unfortunately, it looks like that's the end of the adventure, and so I'd rate this 5/10.

Pros:
- Great voice acting
- Environment is great
- The game really grabs you, especially midway through
- Not too much backtracking

Cons:
- Decently short (3/4 hours)
- Bait and switch ending, really waiting for a twist that never comes
- Feels like they ran out of budget and just tried to wrap the game up
- Feels like the game is on rails

Essentially, I feel a bit cheated by the promises made by the marketing, as they promised a different experience than I got. I can see where the devs were trying to go with this in terms of emotion and story, but it felt like a letdown to me.

reviewText:
Firewatch is probably one of the best walking simulators ever. The walking is a bit more interactive than in many other games. You have to navigate with a map that doesn't show your direction, and a compass. That alone keeps you kind of busy and makes the walking less boring. I will still say that I started to get a little bored sometimes, when I had to walk great distances to the next destination.

But that was only when there was no voiceover. Because the voice acting in this game is absolutely fantastic. The two actors did a really great job. I can't think of any game that had voice acting on that level. The dialogue is very well written. It's funny. It's sad. It's intense when it needs to be. Just awesome. Henry and Delilah are both fantastic characters, and the growing relationship between them is interesting, and not as one-dimensional as stuff like this usually is in games. I liked it a lot.

The ending is at least questionable. I expected something else, to be honest. The game gets more intense as you go, until you really can't wait to get to the conclusion. And when you're finally there - well, I was a little disappointed. It's an interesting idea. But not really what I wanted. This is a personal preference, of course. Some people will like it, others will not.

The game is relatively short. It took me 4.4 hours, and I didn't rush it. I really took my time and looked at all the items I could find. You have to decide for yourself, if a 4 hour game is worth 20€. For me it was.

8/10

Yes, I get the metaphor of the tower/escapism/reality vs. hopes and dreams/etc. etc.  I already understood that from watching trailers of the game.  Having said that...

I have mixed feelings.  I don't the mind the short length of the game, as I understood going in that it was a narrative focused experience.  The problem is that experience did not pay off in the end.  I'm able to tolerate cliff hangers of all kinds (I have read all of George RR Martin's books without having  multiple strokes).  But, this game, as beautiful as the visuals were, took little advantage of the possibilities the story had and completely fell flat at the end. reviewText:
I had high hopes for this game after I saw the 15 minutes review gameplay on YouTube. I didn't even mind the high price tag for the supposedly short 6 hours of gameplay as I was expecting a good mystery for my character to solve. But all in all, I was pretty disappointed with how the game unfolded.

+ Beautiful graphics.
+ Very atmospheric.
+ Good soundtrack.
+ Excellent voice acting for the witty dialogues.
+ Engaging story at the start and towards the middle.

- Story didn't really deliver. It started off strong and then just fell flat / boring towards the end. Some parts were predictable.
- Very short (expected at least 6 hours of gameplay, got only 4.5hours).
- No consequences of your dialogue choices.
- No replay value.
- Price tag is too high for its current content.
- Linear. Since this is more like a walking simulator, I was expecting a bigger map, if not an open world.
- Expected a good mystery but got a flirty woman on the radio instead.

Buy it if you don't mind a walking simulator with a subpar storyline, but I simply cannot recommend it at its current price; there's just not enough content to justify the price tag. Get it only when it's heavily discounted.

EDIT: Like a lot of people, I wish there's a Neutral button that I could give it. It's not a bad game per se, it has its merits and I did enjoy some parts of it. But with its current $20 base price (less in my regional Steam store), I got about 4 hours of gameplay. Of a mediocre story line. With an abrupt 'WTF' ending that I didn't enjoy / like.

My Rating: 5/10

reviewText:
1) Essential purchase
2) Recommended purchase3) Recommended purchase during a sale
4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors

Sleepless in Wyoming
Firewatch, the new first person exploration game from Campo Santa Studios (which in turn is comprised of industry veterans from Double Fine, Telltale, 2K and Klei) is a game forged in the fires of loneliness. Both its two central characters -  Henry and Delilah  - have had incidents happen in their lives which has left them emotionally strung out or inaccessible. Through a short montage of emotionally heartfelt words we soon learn why Henry - the character the player controls - has taken it upon himself to isolate himself in a forest as vast and expansive as the Shoshone National Forest in Wyoming USA for the summer of 1989 as a firewatcher. Delilah on the other hand, who is stationed at the opposite end of the forest at another lookout post is Henry's immediate senior and boss. When we first hear Delilah introduce herself to Henry she is flirty and playful  but we  soon learn that Delilah has a tendency to keep the world around her largely at arms length. Could both these characters end up being foils for one another? Well you will have to play Firewatch to find out.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=634544775
While I am not the worlds biggest fan of first person exploration games with this partly tempered by my recent exposure to the genre where of the three I did take for a spin around the block - the one left me underwhelmed with its contrived shock" ending (The Vanishing of Ethan Carter)
date: the other was so obtuse it was like going on a date with a person that spoke in white noise (Dear Esther) with the final one being a pretentious piece of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ masquerading as philosophical alumni with the purplest prose this side of Oscar Wilde (Leviathan : The Old City which I absolutely hated with a fiery
recommended: burning passion). I was hoping that Firewatch would be able to find the middle-ground between telling an engaging story with actual characters that resembled relatable adult human beings and not blank canvases
hoursPlayed:
contrived gumshoe detectives that see "dead people" or characters that resemble clowns with their flowery exposition.

Five minutes into Firewatch I knew I had found that game as both Henry and Delilah actually converse like real adults would with realistic dialog that echoes their temporary happiness or compounds their pain and loneliness. Occasionally some sequences in the game will give rise to panic and both characters are not adverse to using colourful language that is laden with expletives. If you have young children around you then perhaps this is not the game to be playing when small ears are within listening shot as Firewatch is a mature gaming experience dealing with loneliness and loss (including the losing of the self - a perfect metaphor for the forest on more than one occasion where the forest rightfully claims what it believes belongs to it). Most of this anyway  will fly over the little ones heads and part of me wishes that the game came with a big warning - that only mature adults need apply since I feel that even most younger gamers will find it boring despite its heavy adult themes that will be perhaps lost on those who have never felt them before.


http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=623446181
Most of Firewatch's 79 or so odd days (although their are not really 79 gameplay days) these two characters will get to know one another through the use of walkie-talkies as Henry explores the vast park under the command and watchful eye of Delilah. It is through these sequences as you wonder through the isolated wilderness that both these characters begin to flesh themselves out becoming more and more real as they speak candidly about their life experiences or try to dodge conversations where difficult topics are raised. With Henry feeling particularly vulnerable and fragile at the start of the game
voteText:
he soon embarks on uncovering a mystery around the disappearance of two teenage girls who have been camping in the park. Given his emotional state its quite plausible that he jumps to some of the conclusions he does. It's not long however before the real mystery of the park surfaces and while I found it slightly contrived it is no less heartbreaking.

A lot of people have expressed displeasure with how Firewatch ends and initially I also kind of felt cheated by it as there was no big emotional payoff especially given the series of events that play out towards the end. I had to go away and think about if for a bit and now that I have it really was the smart way to end the game.  It's no mystery that Henry becomes more and more emotionally dependent on Delilah as the game progresses. It even gets to the point near the end where Henry starts to see Delilah as his emotional savior. For Delilah - her Achilles heel is the inability to deal with this emotional dependence once it surfaces which explains why each summer she hides herself away from the world in the park. Various notes uncovered lying around the park from previous rangers and firewatchers depict a similar fate of her simply abandoning them. The ending was Delilah's personality going through its motions. Another clue is how Delilah literally goes out of her way never to meet up with Henry even when dropping off various goods and necessities around the park despite them sharing some very personal information about one another

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=623807447
Firewatch grapples with some serious adult issues and in the end succeeds admirably thanks to some very strong writing that has its two main characters saying things that could  have come straight from your very own mouth. This tale of two lonely souls who find each other in a forest may not have that happy "Hollywood" ending that I think most where expecting at least its a true ending that doesn't have these very characters doing a ninety degree about-face which would not have been plausible or believable given their emotional tapestry. Highly recommended.

If you enjoyed reading this review please follow my curator group at:-
Curator Rater"

reviewText:
Firewatch is a prime example on how to hype a game, that is decent, but really nothing juicy or groundbreaking in any way. It's a walking simulator through and through, but with outstanding voice acting.

+ GREAT voice acting
+ decent art style
+ a little bit interesting
+ Update: great soundtrack

- short (you've seen it all in less than 4 hrs)
- no replay value
- no decisions
- linear
- not worth 20 bucks, maybe 5-10...
- weak ending

If you can pick it up for less than 10 dollar, it may be worth it, but prepare yourself to be bored a bit.

If you hide your location on the map it's a bit more interesting.

UPDATE:
Thanks for all your comments, it's much appreciated. I'm a seasoned gamer and spend a lot of time playing computer and video games. If you're a casual gamer and just want to have a nice experience, like a slow movie, for a couple hours,.... well no, I still wouldn't recommend you to buy the game. Just watch a play-through on Youtube.

reviewText:
Foreword: I wish there was something more than yes and no as a recommendation and I am very torn between those 2. I liked some parts of it and hated others. So my opinion of this game is a no with a heavy heart. Wish there was something like percentages... cause it's roughly 50/50 like dislike for me. Why? No, I just have to get this out of my chest - I even brought my freakingly inferior laptop to work for the night shift just to go ahead and finish the game! I was so looking forward to the endgame story I wanted to see happening, and didn't find it. The early game got me stoked, the midgame got me absolutely hooked and the endgame doused me with supercold water, giving me the proverbial Ice Bucket.

Firewatch is a game about Henry, a person whose wife suffers from a terrible sickness, and he decides to take a job as a Firewatch in Wyoming in order to escape reality, collect himself, and decide how to proceed. There he meets Delilah, his boss with a sexy voice who guides him through the entirety of his adventure.

In true fashion for my reviews, I will go through the good and the bad.

The GOOD:

1. Beautiful park to explore, consisting of caves, ravines, forest areas, mountainous landscapes, canyons, you name it.
2. Exploring the park gives you this awesome zen feeling of relaxation and puts a smile on your face.
3. The witty jokes and jabs between the two main protagonists are so fun to listen and respond to.
4. An extremely pleasant soundtrack.
5. The game is more of a walking simulator than a mystery adventure experience. It is a damn good one though.
6. You get to take pictures that would remind you of your adventure.
7. You actually have a compass and a map. I was expecting another long dark... Thank god it is not.

The BAD:
1. The story is very subpar. It has a nice buildup and it's as if they wanted to make something epic but... got scared or fell short of it. You get prepared to this big event... and nothing much happens. Saying anything more would be a spoiler.
2. The story is extremely predictable. I was sure what's going to happen, and was waiting for the big punch... which never came.
3. The soundtrack, albeit great, seems to few and far inbetween. You will be hiking for a while without any sound.
4. The game is short as hell, clocking at about 3.5 hours even if you're not running.
5. There are no multiple endings from what it seems. I have tried to approach some situations differently, and all Delilah does is change her lines and still get back to the main point.
6. Even though you get to make some pictures... that's all there is to it, and the game doesn't even tell you that you should (apart from once). I took pictures of all the suspicious things I found in order to deal with the police if necessary... Just to see them all in the credits. Thanks, but no thanks. As I said in my post on the steam forums, I even opted not to upload them, because all of them would have been huge spoilers!!!
7. The ending was not satisfactory for me... I so wished there would be more, and I hope they release some free dlcs to round up the story. There is simply no CLOSURE!
8. The replaybility seems to be all about playing again as Henry being a jackass, saying bad things to Delilah, or saying almost nothing, and so on...
9. The price tag is very high. I would totally pick it at 50% off though.
10. I tried to follow the suggestions of some people on the forums to ignore the story and just have fun. Sadly, all I found was walled off areas by bushes or thickets that you need to clear with an item that... was behind the wall of bushes. I am sorry to report that this type of exploration isn't there - at least until you go halfway through the game and a certain event.

Conclusion:

I am giving this game a no with a heavy heart. I know I had awesome time for the first 2 hours, laughing at the jabs between the the main protagonists, and having a blast exploring the the park. But then... it just pettered out. I was waiting for this huge showdown, but I was treated to just tapes and pieces of the story. There is so much buildup for nothing. No, I just have to get this out of my chest - I even brought my freakingly inferoir laptop to work for the night shift just to go ahead and finish the game! I was so looking forward to the endgame story I wanted to see happening, and didn't find it. The early game got me stoked, the midgame got me absolutely hooked and the endgame doused me with supercold water. As I said in the comments, Thing is, I don't want much :) If they have put just a simple a text screen before the credits saying what happened with whom and how they went on with their lives, my review would have been positive, but they just ended the whole thing... On the positive side, there is a lot to like about this game, and as I said in my other reviews, something or someone that puts a smile on your face is priceless. But overall, with the bad outweighing the good so seriously, I can't really recommend it.

reviewText:
I have a guilty pleasure for walking simulators and this one filled it! You play as Henry, who is accompanied by the lovely Delilah -- your only source of connection outside the forest. I will say no more due to spoilers but I was instantly immersed in the story from the get go and I adored the chemistry and voice acting of the two main characters. For a very small dev team its a big story and they did a great job!

Pros:
Beautiful graphics. The colours and the artstyle were just stunning. I could see me going back to this game to use screenshots in a showcase
Fantastic Story (the feels from the beginning). From the start the characters come to life and I was instantly immersed
The soundtrack is awesome. Most of the time there is just the life around you buzzing but when the music hits... Wow!
Voice acting is very good and the chemistry between Henry and Delilah is awesome. A few moments made me smile and laugh away. Very well done
The main story is awesome but there are many secrets for explorers
The characters are very well designed and are pretty in-depth

Cons:
Now I say this not because of me but others have considered it very short for the £15 price tag... I however feel like anything more would have ruined the impact of the story and/or dragged it out and I would have lost interest. (I don't mean it is not a very interesting story. More it did what it set out to do and I'm happy with it)
Which brings me to the next part -- the story was good from the beginning and I was captivated, conversely the ending was poorly done. I felt it left many questions unanswered and left me wanting more (and not in the good sense.) However, the progress of the journey made me happy enough to recommend the game
Some of the animations for me felt like they were a little dragged out. It is a small issue but I could feel myself just blankly staring waiting for the animation to end
Lastly, I feel the game didn't run as well as it should have (I will leave my specs down below.) But I ran this game in ultra settings and yet in various parts of the game I would drop to 34-40 fps. It was playable but it was something to look out for.
Overall, this is a solid game with a solid story and I would recommend getting it. Whether you love walking simulators(buy it full price) or you just would like to get lost in a story for 4-5 hours (maybe on sale). I would give the game a 7/10

GPU: GTX 970
CPU: i5 4690k
RAM: 16gb

reviewText:
First off, let's get it out of the way and say that yes, the game is extremely short. It took me about three hours to play all the way through the story. With no incentive to replay it, the game might not be worth the asking price for many people who read this review. If you don't want to pay $20 for a 3 hour experience, then that is fine, and respectable.

However, the experience that you're buying here is something unlike other games you've played. Firewatch, no matter what all the naysayers believe, is a very groundbreaking game. It did something no other game has ever done for me: make me feel like I was talking to an actual human being when I had conversations with Delilah as Henry. The connection you build with her is something unlike anything you'll see in another game. It just feels so... real. She feels like a real person. I believe that the feeling is amplified by the fact that you never really see a physical representation of Delilah in the game. You only ever speak to her through your handy walkie-talkie, which means the only thing I ever associated her with, was with a real, breathing human.

The story that Firewatch tells is also an extremely believable, heart-wrenching, and yet heart-warming one. I'll not go into details or spoilers, but let's just say that the story is a very human mystery, and has a few twists that leave you pondering every single thing you ever did in the game, and wondering how it was all connected. The story wasn't something that will completely blow your mind and make you rethink your life, but it is just that hint of subtlety that makes it so enjoyable. It just feels so real, man.

I believe that the price tag on Firewatch is worthwhile. The beauty of the landscape in which the game is set isn't really comparable to very many other games. The world is exquisitely detailed, and the art style does a lot for the overall atmosphere the game is going for. Photorealism wasn't something that the developers were going for, as the art has a very cartoonish, animated feeling - and yet all of the finer details in the world are still there, such as print on the back of some of the books found in the game that can actually be read. The environment will immerse you in your surroundings, and if not for your map and compass and Delilah's guidance, it would be quite easy to get lost in the extensive wilderness in which the game is set. On top of that, the voice acting in the game is probably some of the best you'll ever hear. For such a small title, it is astonishing how well voice acted it was. The voice acting certainly helped to add to the immersion of the world, but it also helps justify the price of the title, as quality like that can't come cheap.

In the end, if you're looking for a quick, hearty game that you want to make you feel something, then this game is definitely worth your time, and your money. If you don't have the cash to fork out for a game you'll probably only ever play once, then I don't think this title is for you.

reviewText:
Life is cruel and unfair, but damn if it doesn’t look beautiful as it’s burning down around you.

Firewatch is a game preoccupied with the messy, unpredictable, and indiscernible tragedy of life. Though its aesthetics and settings might lead to the perception of some natural focus – canyons and forests of the Wyoming wilderness forming a backdrop to elevate a narrative of environmental concerns, perhaps, or at least one in which the outdoors inform the game’s trajectory beyond mere blunt scenery – Firewatch is wholly absorbed in the interpersonal drama between its two main characters, Henry and Delilah.

Henry is a man running from his problems; Delilah has already gotten that far but still can’t put her own problems out of mind. Together they form what could be described as Firewatch’s soul; the humanity hidden beneath inconsistent world building and awkward mechanical conceits which holds the game together, if only insofar as people keep talking. For as tired and archetypical as its two troubled protagonists are, Firewatch is successful through its refusal to ever satisfy the player. Though it begins in a familiar place, Henry and Delilah’s story is never allowed to diverge onto the path you expect it, and most likely want it to take. Firewatch constantly dangles relief just outside of reach, situations and conversations building upon the uncertainty and anxiety of two people so completely lost in their lives looking for a way out, even if it means destroying themselves in the process.

This isn’t to say that Firewatch is grim, so much as it’s uncompromising. There is a delicate balance struck between wit and sobriety which allows Firewatch to be at once charmingly aloof and unpleasantly blunt. The only significant form of exposition comes by way of the radio conversations between Henry and Delilah, and a lot of care has been put into the way you as a third person are in both direct and subtle ways influencing and witnessing their relationship develop. Often you are afforded a personal choice as to the tone a conversation takes on, which by nature of being (if only slightly) player directed causes Henry and Delilah to feel like more dynamic characters. But it is also in what Firewatch doesn’t tell you that contributes to their authenticity, with days and sometimes weeks going by without your involvement, and scenes often fading to black before the entirety of a conversation can be told.

Again there is a willingness to frustrate the player for the sake of creating more compelling and autonomous characters, and while this could have fallen apart and left us with a game bereft of depth and cohesion it’s such a conscious and considered decision that it creates an experience that feels confident in its own ambiguity and discontent. Even up to the end after all questions are laid clean and revelations prove far less fantastical than the possibilities leading to them, Firewatch remains deliberately unsatisfying and sometimes even intensely frustrating. All to the point that the world Firewatch wishes to portray is inherently unfair and unexciting, and often the ways in which we try to find meaning within that framework are only for the sake of our own gratification and to satisfy the belief that there is a purpose to this all. Because ultimately Firewatch’s narrative is decidedly mundane even in its least ordinary moments, only taking on a larger significance in the presence of its two characters who are so very distressed and by nature feel so relatable and well realized in their attempts to make sense of the impossible.

There is the immediate impulse to feel outraged at Firewatch’s audacity to so completely reject the player, but beyond that there is something to be said for examining our own need to feel justified by the media we consume, when maybe there is more to be said by never arriving at the happy or thrilling conclusion we expect.

But for all its narrative unorthodoxy Firewatch is a far less cohesive game than it is a storytelling device. Firewatch is so careful in its exposition and dialogue that it’s bizarre and agonizing that none of that care has been put into considering the way in which the game’s world and its mechanical habits interact with one another. Firewatch plays like a string of narrative conveniences and diversions, introducing new mechanics and ways to use them in such transparent fashion as to shatter the illusion of being present in this world so much of the game is predicated upon reinforcing. Firewatch spends an inordinate amount of time reminding you of your characters body and the ways in which it collides with the natural world you need to navigate through, and yet your body is no less impervious and superlative than any given video game character. Firewatch wants you to watch your character scramble a rock wall, but also won’t deny you an endless sprint button so as to not trouble you with the need to spend any extraneous time walking through the landscape. It wants you to feel dazed as Henry slips down a slope, but worry not about dropping off that ledge, a perfect landing is always assured.

These are small things in context, but when so much of Firewatch is attempting to break away from the conventions of traditional game design they stand out as inexplicable reminders that underneath the narrative this still a fairly ordinary and unexceptional game. And that realization causes the act of actually playing Firewatch to often feel like a chore; a simple but tedious and obligatory gesture done purely for the sake of narrative.

And if playing Firewatch is uninteresting to the degree I would simply rather not, what purpose then do the vast and beautiful landscapes serve beyond extensive gaps between story beats I’m forced to run through. When Firewatch neglects to make the act of actually playing it engaging in its own right, it creates no desire to spend any extra time within its world because everything outside of the story is deemed less important.

It isn’t even that this isn’t a world I would like to appreciate, as meandering about its trees and hills so perfectly captures the feeling of being lost within the wilderness that I wouldn’t feel opposed to merely trapesing through a nestle of trees for no other reason than to watch how the light breaks through them. Firewatch is exceptional in its artistic direction and each frame could be captured and displayed as a beautiful painting in its own right. But by creating a hierarchy of purpose between its gameplay and narrative Firewatch causes time spent outside of its story to feel wasted, or at the very least as if you are holding the game up from showing you what it really wants to. It wasn’t long before I lost most of my desire to just take in the world I was walking through, as I felt constantly funneled from one story beat to the next and couldn’t shake the feeling of idleness anytime I’d stop to admire a particularly lovely vista.

Firewatch’s strength lies in its simplicity and humanity. Its uncompromising narrative is often deeply frustrating, but in crafting a world so completely mundane and ordinary populated with messy problems without easy answer, it manages to tap into a specific segment of the human experience so rarely explored in games. It’s unfortunate its mechanical foundation is so much less unexpected and disrupting, coming close at times to taking the rest of the game down with it as Firewatch’s two conflicting halves struggle to find any sort of balance. In the end its problems aren’t all that different from the wildfire that springs up early on in the game. They’re always there and keep getting bigger, but we just ignore them and hope they’ll be dealt with before the whole place goes up in flames.

You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

reviewText:
A great premise, fantastic voice acting and a beautiful setting, sounds like the perfect game, right? Wrong.
Firewatch is a “single-player first-person mystery” otherwise known as a walking simulator with dialogue. In Firewatch you play as Henry, a middle-aged man who has volunteered to be a lookout in the Shoshone National Park, Wyoming during one summer in the late 80s. The beginning of the game sets up his story in the form of a ‘text adventure’ in which the game describes a few key events which you’ll need to know to understand Henry. Once you get to the Shoshone part of the game you begin speaking to your supervisor, Delilah, who talks you through your summer job as well as chatting to you about a few things. You’re usually given three dialogue options when talking to Delilah which will change the path of the conversation (though not the game as far as I can tell) though sometimes you’ll only get one option, usually if you’re reporting something. Having been excited about Firewatch since the first trailers of it were released I was incredibly excited to get my hands on it but unfortunately I’ve been left rather disappointed.

Please note: The game took me three hours to beat, any game time further than that has either been spent getting the trading card drops or going back to unlock the first two achievements which were broken when I started the game.

Firewatch has two main strong points, its appearance and its voice acting. First up, appearance. Firewatch is positively beautiful, even on low settings as I played it on. While it’s not a unique aesthetic, as some have said it looks a tad similar to The Long Dark, it fits the game well and when there’s something like a sunset it can be quite breath-taking.

Like I said, the voice acting is also fantastic. The actors who played Henry and Delilah did a fantastic job at making two believable characters and a lot of their dialogue feels real. There were a couple of bits here and there which were a bit weaker but nothing major enough to take away from how good it was.

Moving on, we have gameplay, or in Firewatch’s case, lack thereof. It is, as has been said by others, pretty much just a walking simulator and if you’re a fan of walking simulators then that’s great, sadly I’m not. There are a couple of things to do other than walking, for example there are certain places were you need to repel down steep slopes, but the vast majority of the game is taken up by just walking around. This is made worse by the fact that there are a few points in the game where you have to backtrack or walk through an area you’ve already been through, it just makes walking through said areas even less interesting. While the bigger areas are pretty dull, especially the familiar ones, there are some areas in the game which are pretty cool and actually enjoyable to explore, they’re all tied to the story so don’t worry about missing them. Admittedly I’m not sure how they could have added any real gameplay to the game but I do think that Firewatch would have been more suited to a different format, i.e. a novel. The interactions between Henry and Delilah are definitely the best parts of the game, the longer interactions anyway, but these interactions are usually on either side of a chunk of walking in silence, which is as boring as it sounds.

Firewatch’s story starts out strong, really strong and for the most part it’s very well-written, made even better by the voice actors. Even the little text adventure at the beginning is great, it sets up the character of Henry incredibly well and it’s also like an emotional punch to the gut. The story carries on strong as Henry eases in to his summer job with some simple tasks given to him by Delilah. Sadly things take a turn for the worse when Henry discovers something he probably wishes he hadn’t and Henry and Delilah are catapulted into a rather worrying situation. The story actually remains pretty strong until you get to the end of the game at which point I found myself presented with one of the most disappointing endings I’ve encountered in story-driven games as well as in novels. There’s simply no pay-off for beating the game, I honestly think I would have enjoyed the game a lot more if they’d just cut the last twenty or thirty minutes from what is already a disappointingly short game for the price (just for the record I would have been happy with the six hours the devs said it would be before release but three hours is too short for £15 in my opinion). Without any plot spoilers I’ll explain why I don’t like the ending a little more: the problem with the ending is that it feels forced, like the devs ran out of time so they just threw something in there to tie it up nicely. Except, it doesn’t tie it up nicely, it ends with so many unanswered questions that even the characters, who have just gone through this pretty alarming experience, don't care about. In the final interaction between the two before the credits roll they act like nothing has happened at all and it made the three hours I spent playing the game feel so pointless. I didn’t get the sense of closure I want from story-driven games.  There is also a pretty major whole in the plot. Once you get to the end of the game and piece things together there's one thing in particular which just doesn't make sense, something that should have been addressed in the game.

Verdict
At the end of the day, Firewatch is little more than another overpriced walking simulator. While the story is great for most of the game the ending completely and utterly ruined the experience for me which just made it harder to look past the distinct lack of interesting gameplay. Grab it on a deep discount if you like story-driven games and don’t mind a disappointing ending but at full price I can’t recommend this game.

Lone Ranger Reviews.

El K.

Buy or not to buy?Ultimately there is nothing wrong with Firewatch - it has great music/voice actors, decent graphics, smooth controls but its way too short and lacks real content. For a game that lasted only 3.7h to complete i find 19,99$/€ price point too high. I Don't see particularry very high replay value either, while the exploration is key part of the game there is nothing to really do as in side quests or collectibles laying around the map that you could search for.

Story is rather fine, but the end result can be dissapointing same goes for the ending. I think the game gives some type of an illusion for different outcomes that can happen depending what you do or say, but overall i do feel there is so much that could have done with the story or just prolonged it pretty much.

I also do want to point out that gamepad button mapping could have been better. Zooming and keep map open at same time was annoying, there could have been toggle feature or something.

It's a good buy if you get for under ~10$ but other than that its not worth the money since i felt i kinda got ripped off by such a short game. I also felt stuff like physics engine was rather waste since it didn't bring much to the gameplay nor did the camera system.

reviewText:
Note: This review contains spoilers for the game, since there's a lot of I want to cover I will cover the spoilers with a warning so you can skip it.

Firewatch is a game whee you play as a man named Henry. Your wife Julia is sick with Dementia and moves back to Australia. You want to escape from everything and you decide to become a volunteer and become a firewatcher. When you arrive at your outpost you meet a woman named Delilah who is gonna be the only person you talk to through the entire game. You never see her and the only way to talk to her is through your trusty radio. The game also has a sub plot, but I'll cover that a bit tad later.

The dialogue between Henry and Delilah is my favorite part of the game. It feels very natural how they talk between each other and I feel like that helps a lot with the game.

Firewatch is a walking simulator and a very bare bones one at that. The game takes place over a period of 79 days ( you don't play through all of them) where you explore the forest. When you explore the forest you can sometimes find stuff that have an icon of a radio next to them and you can talk about that stuff to Delilah and maybe spark up a conversation that will reveal the more about Delilah or Henry. The game also lets you explore the entire map at your own pace, so if you want to wander off and explore you are free to do so, but Delilah will drop in once in a while to remind you what you're supposed to be doing.

The graphics are absolutely outstanding. The entire environment looks absolutely gorgeous and it's breathtaking just to go to the highest point in the map and look around at the sights which are all just amazing. The entire forest feels alive as the trees sway with the wind and the sounds of the wilderness help to build the perfect atmosphere.

The soundtrack is also amazing, when you explore the music sometimes changes to somber music to stuff that will creep you out a bit, it's all very good and definitely worth owning the soundtrack.

Alright now I'm going to the territory of stuff that I thought were really bizarre and downright poorly executed.

The texture problems in later sections of the game really are just not good and break you out of the game as soon as you see them. Also the frequent frame drops happen quite often in the end game section. Also the ending is very out of place and happens way too soon.

The game took me 3 hours to finish and I took my time off and explored the forest and not to mention I got lost quite a lot during my play time.

Alright here is the problem I had with the plot so *SPOILER WARNING*

Alright the two subplots with the missing girls and the stalker are very mediocre. First the missing girl subplot has one of the worst wraps up I have ever seen. The game sort of expects you that the stalker did something to them, but it later turns out that they were messing around somewhere else which I thought was cheap.

The stalker storyline has a very nice buildup, but the ending for the subplot felt very out of place and very weird with in tone of the rest of the game. Thinking you will end up with a satisfying conclusion the game lets you down right at the end.

*SPOILER WARNING OVER*

Overall, I enjoyed my time with Firewatch. While I don't think it's worth the full price at a discount I can safely say you can check this game out.

Final Rating:
7.5/10 - Great game, but only on a discount

If you liked this review please consider giving it a thumbs up and if you disliked post in the comments on what you disliked about the review.

For more reviews follow Snort's Review curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
Tried my hardest to explain my points without any spoilers, but still proceed with caution. If you've bought the game already, please play it before you read on.

Ever since Firewatch was announced, and I saw the first 15 minutes of this game being shown off by the developers, I fell in love with what looked like GOTY potential. The voice acting was natural, the hiking looked seamless and free, and the story looked like it would blossom into something really worth investing my time and money into.

When I finally loaded up my game after giddily waiting for a solid day for it to release, every expectation was met as I happily hiked around the beautiful forests of Wyoming, seeking ferocious fires and confiscating beers and fireworks from rebellious teens. There is no question that Campo Santo put a lot of effort into creating a stunning environment to lose yourself in, with the colourful canyons and trickling streams along with the incredibly fresh dialouge from the games protagonist and his lookout counterpart.

So why in the WORLD would I not recommend this game?

Firewatch lights a match at its beginning, throws it into a bundle of kindling and by the half way mark a raging bonfire stands before you, hurling paranoia and interesting plot developments that leave you gagging to know what comes next. But before you can huddle around the flame to envelop yourself in what feels like what's going to be a gut wrenching journey of conspiracy and mystery, the fire dies and leaves you cold and confused.

While the storytelling is superb, the execution of the conclusion is left to be desired. It frustratingly falls short in the end and I felt like the REAL ending would jump out at me when I least expected it... but it didn't. I had to sit there and ponder is this it?".

Maybe that's the kicker. Maybe that was the goal. Maybe I was meant to feel the paranoia of the characters in the game and that it was all in my head too

reviewText:
This is a hard game to review because what it did well it did extremely well but what it didn't do as well could be fixed with DLC or a free update, but it was such a kick in the teeth that it took away from everything that had been done right. I have rated this game a 'No' reluctantly.

Let's start with the positives - The characters are realistic. The dialogue is superb. The voice acting is absolutely spot on and the story starts off making it hard to stop playing because you desperately want to know what happens next. Getting into character just naturally happens. That combined with the pretty scenery, the sound effects that sometimes leave you feeling like you are being followed through the forests, and the perfect minimalist music to set the mood as events happen in the game made it very immersive and got my imagination going into overdrive.

Unfortunately the story suddenly just nose dives and all the sudden it's the end of the game. One moment you are worried every single time you climb a rock face that you will run into someone you don't want to run into at the top, or that something will happen to your rope as you repel down sheer rockfaces. You panic that someone is right behind you or just in front of you constantly... And then all the sudden it's game over. So much tension had been built only for it to end so suddenly and so unsatisfactorily. It felt like the boss poked his head into the writers office and just told them to wrap it up and that they had 10 minutes to do it in.

That is something they could fix if they wanted to though... They could expand it a bit more. Perhaps add another hour of game play or some interesting side-quests... So I rate this a No at the moment and it sort of pains my heart to do so.

reviewText: Firewatch was a good narrative. I'm sad that I had to give a negative review, but the game has to have enough content to be worth the price.

reviewText:
Firewatch is tagged with “the walking-simulator games”, like the game Gone Home. (which unfortunately I did not find engaging) But I have to say I had a very good time playing the Firewatch. The game has fully lived up to my expectation despite its relatively short playtime and to me, Firewatch resembles a post-modernism novel in telling people a story and unfolding the plot and the ending. Here are my thoughts.

The game started with a script-choosing prologue, providing the basic background of the story (basically about the early life before our protagonist, Henry). I found this part very immersive for the simple dialogue choosing mechanism and the relaxing background music, the characters are all very relatable and the twist in Henry’s early life made my tears welling up :( It is just ordinary people’s life, but it proved to be moving, especially when this initial part only took up about 15-20 minutes to present Henry’s whole life before he went to the wilderness to be a fire lookout. It was such a climatic experience and after this initial part the gamers should have a basic, yet ambiguous understanding of why Henry took this job.

The main gameplay of the game is fairly good, first the mechanism of walkie-talkie is really brilliant idea, as the name puts, it allows you to report many thing you see to your supervisor, Delilah, which you do not feel lonely while exploring the wilderness. To make this mechanism work, the voice acting is essential and it is just fascinating. The navigation system---the map and the compass combination is very interesting and works well. The major problem I have with this game is the performance, the game has glitches during the autosave when you move to the next region, and the game requires high spec for its grass&trees rendering and shadows. There are many invisible walls in the game, which breaks my immersion sometimes.

To the end of the game, some people found it “anticlimactic” and frustrating about the short 4-5 hrs playtime to “complete” it. Personally I disagree with these opinions. The longevity of the time never justifies a game when the quality is below average. This game is all about imagination, people nowadays are easily become disconcerting when something strange happened, especially for gamers (or Hollywood movie fans) who has taken it for granted that---there has to be a climax, many conspiracies and lots of twists in game’s story. The fact is, what the developers want to tell is a small episode of life involving only several character(Actually the number is 6, according to the cast list) and I think they have done a good job. There is no survival mechanism (like the one we have in The Long Dark), there is no death or failure penalty. Yet I found myself overreacting to some thrilling elements and then it turned out to be just my imagination.    --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
<Spoiler Alert>
As for the ending, yes you never actually get to meet Delilah, which is acceptable in my opinion, in the game, when you get into her tower in the end, you can found her sketch of you, which was completed only by the descriptions of how you look through radio times ago in the game. I definitely think that everyone has his/her very own image of Delilah, and so again this is a game about creativity of human thoughts, which is imagination. So I do not think the game has a mundane ending.

Personally I may play the game for several times in the future, Firewatch is more like a good book of fiction to me.If you are into readings, you shall find that the style of story’s beginning, unfolding and ending is quite close to the post-modernism. In this category, we have Murakami Haruki with 1Q84, Lisa Genova with Still Alice Jonathan Safran Foer with Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close and so on. These books, they all offered readers a basic yet vague setting, people HAVE TO use imagination to understand, to engage. The ending will not surprise you that much, but that is the real life. In the Firewatch, the same applied, maybe you can be sure to expect the ending exactly in the middle of the game, but there are still many things remains unexplored, many choice to reply to the supervisors I would like to try out. Firewatch is the very game for the late night reading time, it is immersive in the first playthrough and it shall be more of a casual journey from then on. I have already decided to close the captions in next playthrough for more immersion :)

Pros:
-Immersive story and gameplay
-Amazing voice acting
-Beautiful art style (just check community screenshots)
-Great original soundtracks (Highly recommended! Including FLAC & MP3 version)
Cons:
-Performance (frame rates drops sometimes)
-Relatively a high requirement for hardware as an indie game
Recommended especially to those:
-who loves AVG or Telltales series
-who loves Life is Strange for art style

reviewText:
EDIT-> Long story short: Expand and read the bottom statement. :)

For a person like me to play a game like this, I bought this being a little skeptical, expecting a cash-grab unfinished game with a terrible storyline and laughable attention to detail.
To be completely honest, This game completely blew me away.
Absolutely Excellent and Highly detailed visuals
Smooth-as-Butter movement and animations
An amazing and consuming narritive feel that keeps you playing
and lastly, and probably my favorite,
the Soundtrack. Perfectly compliments the mood of every scene, dialogue, and event that happens in the beautifully designed and visually stunning cartoon-y forrest that was extremely satisfying.

However, The one problem I had with this game, and why I can't recommend it for $20 USD.
The abrupt 3 & 1/2 hour end to an incredibly rich storyline that kept me playing straigh through the game.
The story within this game had Sooo much room for expansion, and It seemed to be a situation where the creators got bored/ ran out of ideas, and aburptly ended the story in the most convienient way possible (which they did very well).
This game left me wanting more than it left me with, and now I feel as though I should Volunteer in Wyoming as a firewatch to seek closure from this brutal cutoff of a very involving and rich story.

Long story short: Wait for a sale to buy this, Otherwise Excellent game!

reviewText:
Interesting art style, but worth 10€ at most. Wait for the next sale.
After the trailers, I was hyped for this game. I expected an open-world mystery / adventure game set in the middle of nowhere. What you get is essentially a linear walking simulator with nice art assets.

What looks like an open world is limited everywhere by obstacles that require a specific tool. Since you apparently did not think to bring literally anything with you, you have to collect ropes, an axe, and climbing gear when the story dictates it. This severly limits the places you can go / explore.
And even if you decide to go exploring, the only thing you can find are the supply-caches, which are marked on your map from the first minute; those usually contain a letter from someone you don't know, to someone you don't care about; writing about how they want to drink beer.

The radio is the only thing giving you a degree of choice, or the illusion of it. Often, you will be given a Telltale Games kind-of choice between 3 options of what to say, with a ~10 second timer counting down. Unlike Telltale however, these choices have 0 impact on the story and outcome of the game. You could remove the radio entirely from the game and end up with a genuine walking simulator, where you spend 10% of your time staring at the map, and the other 90% walking to the place, the map tells you to go.

This leaves the story as the only thing holding this game together, and while it starts out very intriguing, in my opinion it falls flat on its face near the end. I won't spoil anything, since this would ruin the game completely for you, but once you know the big twist at the end, the game has nothing more to offer you. This also leads to 0 replayability; I don't think anyone will ever play this game a second time.

To summarize: If you manage to stay unspoiled until the next sale, where the price drops below 50%, and if you enjoy the occasional walking simulator, then go for it. Otherwise, those 20€ could be invested alot better.

reviewText:
I have to preface this by saying that I really, really don't want to dislike Firewatch in any way. The voice acting was great and so were the characters. The graphical aesthetic was colourful and immersive. The music was subtle and excellent.

The problem lies with one specific important element that Firewatch is missing: it's not a game. I never felt like I was actually doing anything or participating in the story in any meaningful way. None of my choices seemed to make a difference - which is the entire point of telling a story through the medium of a video game. If this were a movie, it'd be a fairly decent movie. However, it isn't a movie. I spent about 50% of the game running from point to point while staring at the map. 30% was spent doing stuff that the game wanted me to do (click this. break that. pick that up. radio that object in). 20% was making small talk over the radio (arguably the best part of the game). This game suffers from 'tutorialitis.' I felt as though I was on rails and being babied every step of the way. It becomes an absurd experience when I realise that I'm a robotic function of the game. That is to say, I'm not controlling the game but the game is controlling me. It's like doing a series of QTEs but without the 'Q'.

With that said, I didn't expect challenge from this game. I did expect a story focused experience, which it was. Yet, the story was disappointing. As other reviewers have pointed out, nothing seems to be of any consequence. The stakes are raised in the middle of the game and then immediately fizzle. Every bad thing that could happen to the protagonist is reversed with absolutely no input from the protagonist. Imagine this: The rebels are about to take off in their spaceships to shoot the Death Star core, when suddenly the Death Star just blows up on its own from a malfunction. What's the point of creating obstacles that solve themselves? Is it some sort of message about futility or is it just lazy writing?

I want to like this game and as I said to begin with there are a lot of enjoyable aspects to this game. However, for the price, the core of the game simply isn't worth it. I would recommend it only on a 50% - 75% sale. I would like to see more from this developer because I can tell they're passionate and they tried to do something unique but it just didn't work very well for me.

reviewText:
Firewatch is a well made game. The presentation, voice acting, map design is top notch. There's clearly a lot of work and care that went into crafting the world of the game. And it starts off well enough. A powerful intro, followed by an interesting premise.

Sadly, the game drops off fairly quickly from the halfway point. The game's excellent atmosphere and dialogue from the opening takes a hit in the favor of a mystery-driven plot that unfortunately isn't very good in the slightest. It has its moments, but the payoff is ultimately non-existant, and the game ends on a whimper. I suppose the twist is here that... there really isn't any.

The game gives you the illusion of choices but ultimately they count for nothing in the outcome of the story. This is not really an issue, but it's worth pointing out, because this also means the game has little to no replay value. And despite what the developers claimed(6 hours long game), the game can be completed under 4 hours at normal pace. Of course, you could say, well, why not go explore? Why, of course, that sounds like a great idea! Except, there's not much to see, if anything at all. The game already shows off its best vistas and sights to you by just playing the story itself. And apart from that, there's nothing. No wildlife, no other people, no nothing.

Overall, I expected more. I expected a more interesting story, and a more involved gameplay scenario. The game drops the whole idea of you being a park ranger way too quickly, and shoehorns a mystery arc in there that is about as interesting as a CSI episode. The presentation though, once again, beautiful. And great soundtrack, too.

reviewText: An incredibly short indie walking simulator with little to offer outside of pretty visuals.  Zero replay value, a terrible ending, and frequent backtracking make it feel half baked and rushed to release.  A shame because up until the reveal it does a competent job of building up suspense and intrigue, but after that point of massive letdown, you begin to realize all the other places where the game starts down a narrative branch only to abruptly stop, bringing multiple side plots to a grinding halt.  There was so much promise in the premise, it's an absolute shame that this is the result.  I would recommend giving this a pass, or if you can't help it, wait until it's on sale.

reviewText:
Well that was a whole lot of build-up for nothing. Without spoiling anything, the ending really just kinda leaves you hanging.

The Good:
- Character development was very, very well done given you don't ever really see any of the characters until the end credits.
- The music and general atmophere of the world made for a pleasant gameplay experience.

The Bad:
- Getting from point A to point B takes such a long time, not to mention you will undoubtedly get lost more than a dozen times. Halfway through I actually had to check to see if there wasn't a fast-travel option I was missing or a way to set markers or waypoints.
- Story is very interesting which is why it's such a shame you get an ending that's rather less than spectacular.

The Ugly:
- Henry's face reveal in the end credits, not how I pictured him.

Would've recommended it if I didn't feel like I was cheated. Not worth $20.

reviewText:
So let's list the positives of this game first:
- Engaging story
- Beautiful art design
- Well crafted dialogue
- Excellent story telling

Now the negatives:
- Short. Ridiculously short.
- Anti-climatic ending, very disappointing
- No replayability
- Framerate issues

My verdict? Don't buy this at full price, wait until it's like $5-10. there are many games out there that are worth $20, this is not one of them. People hyped this game up like it was the second coming of Christ or something but really it's just another walking simulator with a nice foresty background.

reviewText:
The woods at my grandparents’ farm when I was a kid. A one time Australian girlfriend. Alfred Hitchcock films in brilliant Technicolor. These are things that made indelible fingerprints on my past. And almost eerily Campbo Santo Games has brought these things together in a small minimalist game that despite its lack of a ten million dollar budget hooked me right in like I’m sure Doom 2016 will. The game starts subtle enough, you are Henry, a man escaping a bad episode (or two) in his life by taking a summer job as one of those guys who man a firetower and watch for forest fires. The woods are breezy, picturesque, calm, and inviting.

Through the first quarter of the game a mystery begins unfolding and the woods turn sinister. The excellent sound design made me swear I could hear twigs cracking not far behind me and I found myself constantly turning around thinking someone was watching me. The only real foothold I had, the anchor which prevented panic mode was the voice on the other end of the walkie-talkie I had with me. That voice belonged to Delilah, my boss, a chick residing in another fire tower six miles away. Ah, Delilah, truly one of the most compelling characters I’ve ever encountered in over twenty years of PC gaming.

A part of me wanted the game to rush to its ending just to see my relationship with Delilah come to its fruition. Playing this hit me though, reminding me just like in real life it’s the journey not the destination. I think this is a realization shared by many who played this game and criticized the Henry/Delilah relationship aspect of it. When I finally made my way to Delilah’s firetower and my perceptions of her came face to face with her humble abode where she had often communicated with me on the radio, I found it strangely overwhelming.

The mystery istelf, slightly underwhelming. It reminded me of something out of a Lifetime movie. It was nothing grandiose popping out bigger than life, just a simple plausible unsettling event that any one of us could potentially find ourselves enmeshed in.

I don’t often replay games, the ones I have I can count on one hand; I probably will replay this one someday. Its beautiful art style prompted a screenshot. I rarely post screenshots since I consider them spoilers, and seriously, if I go back and play Crysis again, do I really need to pollute your Steam activity feed with screenies of a 2007 game? You already know what the game looks like. But I couldn’t help myself. The art style was redolent of those woods on my grandparents’ farm I mentioned earlier. That part of the game was truly a venture into my past.

The game was really short, but adequate. I completed it in just under five hours, and that’s probably longer than most. There is one consolation, stay the course and the achievements are free gimmies. It’s one of the easiest 100% achievement games I’ve played. The sour point was how the ending seemed somewhat rushed. It was if some corporate bean counter was cracking the whip to get it completed and out the door. It begs the question, is the game worth it for the asking price? I enjoyed it immensely. Don’t let it pass you by, especially during a summer or winter sale.

reviewText:
I'll be honest, this is a very good game. Much more mechanically rich than its peers such as Gone Home, Dear Esther, The Vanishing of Ethan Carter, the Witness, et cetera. As in you actually do things and work to unravel an actual mystery.

However, the game is short, and the devs fail to deliver on promises they made about the game.

Someone who takes their time and doesn't spring everywhere will finish the game in three hours. Three. That's it, that is all it takes to go from start to finish. Someone intentionally speedrunning could probably finish the game in less than an hour. The developers had promised a six hour game if one were to rush. That is most certainly not delivered on. Additionally, the game's story is decent at best and raises more questions than it actually answers - the only way the story could be worse was if it hinted at a sequel.

At $18.00 USD, $20.00 when off-sale, I can't reccomend this game. Maybe if it gets 50% or 75% off during a spring sale will it be worth it, but not at this price.

reviewText:
Firewatch is a first person exploration game. The game is about atmosphere, immersion, and exploration, so do not expect puzzles, quick-time events or combat of any kind.
You are Henry, a man who has retreated from his former life to work as a fire lookout in the Wyoming wilderness. It is your job to keep the wilderness safe. Your only contact is your supervisor, a woman named Delilah, who is in contact with you at all times over a small, handheld radio. Soon you will find out that Henry is not the only person in the forest after all. It does not take long until strange things start to happen and it is up to you to uncover the mysteries.
Unfortunately, Firewatch takes approximately only 3 hours to finish.
The graphics are beautiful.
The game offers a great narrative, Henry and Delilah are brilliantly voiced.
The soundtrack fits perfectly to the game.
I enjoyed the game overall but I missed a bit more interaction with the environment. Besides of the short duration, my only problem with the story was that the finale seems a bit too rushed and I asked myself: What that's all?"
The price of 19
date:
99€ might be too much for some people because of the short duration of the game. If you are a fan of exploration games you should get Firewatch as soon as it gets a discount immediately.

Sounds 9/10
Graphics 9/10
Gameplay 6/10
Atmosphere 8/10

If you liked my review

reviewText: So....  First of all, this is a great looking game.  It tells the story very well and it kept my interest for the most of the time i played it.  With that being said, I could not recommend this game to anyone for current price tag.  If you're thinking about picking this one up, do yourself a huge favor and just wait for a 50% off sale.  Seriously.  The story, while engaging at first, becomes a hollow cop out in the end in my opinion.  Not to mention the little to no replay value and about 3 hours of game play to complete.  If money isnt an issue, i still take the side of this game didn't get a proper thought of the story it told and the conclusion it arrived at.  You'll definately see what I mean by that if you pick this one up.  Nice build up, enjoyable story to follow, lack luster ending.  It genuinely feels like they just left out the end of this game.\n\nHowever, I did enjoy the time i spent playing this game, I'd have to recommend you wait to spend you money in this title.

reviewText:
I went into Firewatch's launch with utmost optimism. My hopes for this game were high in many regards and it fell short in more ways than one.

What this game did right was the atmosphere, it's a beautiful game and I felt involved, being able to explore around just to look at the woodland and take pictures. The dialogue is well written in most cases and the voice actors succeed well in portraying a sense of urgency or just humour depending on the situation.

The problems however ruin most of these positives. The story feels like it falls flat on its face in the closing hour. I finished the game feeling unsatisfied with what I've learned of it's twists and turns. The game has a build up to.. nothing really.

The game is enjoyable not for what it is made as being. The story isn't great but it sure is pretty.


TL;DR: Not worth it's price for the experience. Wouldn't price it over 8 euro for what you get from it, and even then it's questionable

reviewText:
Yes, this game is extremely short (I finished it in 4 hours) and probably not worth 20 bucks.

BUT: It's definitely a small, fine title, that stands out from the mass.

Especially in one point it's unique: The naturality and authenticity of the two main characters.
No stiff heroes throwing around catchphrases - just two people chatting and acting as natural as it gets.
Can't remember of any other game with such charming dialogs ...

Adding the beautiful, comic-ish art style, the presentation sums up as very likable.

However the story ending is - in a dramaturgical way - a bit of a downer. Especially, because the tension building is not bad at all, but in the end there has definitely been wasted a lot of potential.

Still FIREWATCH is a very enjoyable indie game, you can spend a nice afternoon walking, looking around an listening in.

So wait for the next sale and grab it a reasonable price without thinking!

reviewText:
Firewatch, or a short history of bait and switch

Firewatch is a classic case of an indie dev pulling a multi-level bait-and-switch scheme on players. Let's dive right in then!

First of all, the more mudane aspect of it - the game has been continuously advertised by devs as a game that runs for around 6 hours. I explored nearly every inch of its barren, lifeless, boring map, took 83 screenshots while doing it and finished it in 4.5 hours. I was reassured that if I took my time and took in the sights I could easily extend the experience well over those 6 hours. This is simply put a lie.

A beautiful wilderness environment that expands as you explore" - this is again a lie. The map consists entirely of walled-off tunnel-like paths with pretty vistas.

"Secrets and discoveries to be made over every hill" - there is quite literally nothing of interest in any corner of the map that is not directly related to the plot line. Exploring the few spots where the maps opens up a little yields quite literally nothing that is of any importance or that is even mildly interesting.

"An edge-of-your-seat mystery" - The so-called mystery runs for about two and a half hours in the mid-point of the game and is replaced by the biggest plotline bait-and-switch disappointment I ever experienced
date: swapping the non-existent "mystery" with a soppy

reviewText:
I was excited for this game, but it's let me down a little.

The game looks beautiful, introduces the characters well and really sets the mood, but the story is shallow and ends abruptly.

The trailers for the game seemed to really push the idea of an underlying mystery that the player uncovers throughout the story, which is unfortunately not the case. It's a very simple, one dimensional story, which doesn't mean it's bad, just not what was showcased pre-release.

Pros:
Voice acting.
Visuals.
Narrative.
Dialogue options.

Cons:
Unengaging gameplay.
Linear Story.
Short (3-4 hours long)

While the game is worth playing, I don't recommend buying it at full price. Wait for a sale.

reviewText:
How to enjoy firewatch:
1. Prepare enough time to play it in a single sitting (~4-5 hours)
2. Turn off the map marker in the options (so that your map and compass are actually important)
3. Take your time, explore, there are a lot of details and you can usually radio them in.
4. Don't run, unless you feel that it suits the urgency of the situation.
5. There are no wrong answers, try a different approach in your next playthrough.
6. Enjoy a strange summer break" with Henry and Delilah."

reviewText:
A beautiful and engaging story, with beautiful graphics and soundtrack... Ruined by an awful and disappointing ending.

It's hard to say what's wrong with the game without spoiling anything, but I'll try.
For the first 3/4 of the game (so the first 3 hours, since it's 4h long at most) you are interested. You want, you NEED to find out what's going on, the story behind all this... Then you do, and you wish you didn't. It's an awful revelation that undermines everything you've done in the game. There is zero character development coming from Henry and Delilah, both finish the game exactly as they started. Nothing meaningful happened in those woods for 4 hours and then it's over. The end.

Don't buy it unless it's at least 50% off.

reviewText:
I purchased this game on the day of release and I completed it in just over 3 hours. However what this game manages to do in 3 hours is something that games 20+ hours long often lack, and that is deliver an interesting and exciting story.

Depending on how you play the game may only last 3 hours. However if I had spent the time to explore, admire the scenery, read all the notes and listen to all of the dialogue availible the game would of easily lasted me 6+hours.

Regarding performance I use a GeForce GTX 660 graphics card, which is a mid-range card and is nothing compared to higher end graphics cards and I can run the game on high settings at 50-60 fps. If I want to sacrifice some fps I can play on ultra at 30-50 fps.

Overall is it worth the price? - Yes

-Essentially 3-4 hours long but you can make last much longer depending on how you play
-Stunning visuals
-Exciting and interesting story
-Beautiful Landscape to explore!

reviewText:
This game is a little piece of art.

It can be categorized as one of the story telling first-person games like 'Dear Esther' or 'Gone Home'. But this take a more 'living' approach by giving you a companion via radio chatter, while you work as a fire lookout in a national park during the summer months.

This game offers wonderful visuals, realisitc dialogue, a good story and some nice gameplay elements. So for me this game is worth its full price, even with its relativly short playtime of 3-4 hours. The only things that are negative for me are the lack of animal wildlife in the scenery and the missing opportunity of exploring the (small) world on your own.

Beside this there are something that a possible buyer might think over:
Even sharing a similar look with 'The Long Dark', this game is more or less the complete opposite. The game is very short and has a lack of replayability ... even if it offers different dialogue options, there is no feeling of a possible different impact of the story. So take it - as initaly said - as a piece of art, as a book or film ... nothing more.

reviewText:
Firewatch: a short narrative driven video game that, in the 6 hours it takes to complete, engages the player in several scenarios that are up to you to discover what is happening.

In this 4 hour game, you wander around a forest cleaning up after unruly guests, taking in the attractive scenery, and stumbling upon a mystery that you can choose to solve (or completely ignore I guess.)

I can't really say much else without spoiling the story, but if realistic, humorous dialogue with very human reactions and interactions are your cup of tea, and a 2 hour completion time doesn't sully your view, then Firewatch is a nice little treat for you.

I, however, requested a refund as soon as the credits rolled. 2-3 hour completion time that left me with no interest in replaying does not to me a justified $17 price tag make.

EDIT: Firewatch has been successfully refunded.

reviewText:
Before I begin there are NO spoilers in this review.

Firewatch is a great game with an amazing look, unique art style and great voice acting. However I am disappointed to say the game is short in length, high in price and has an anticlimactic end.

Before you start your first person adventure in the Wyoming wilderness you are introduced to yourself, well the 30 year old man you are going to become. It's strange to think how well you can feel for this character after just simple decision making and text based scenarios, and this is one of the things Firewatch does well, you can bond with every character even the ones you know very little about.
You learn about you life leading to the time you take the job; A Firewatch - you monitor the forest from a tower named 'Two Forks'.

The person you will spend most of your time talking with (Over Walkie Talkie) is your boss, or superior, a women named Delilah. She is there throughout your whole journey as you connect the dots and explore the amazing landscapes of the Wilderness from lush wood lands, to majestic meadows and the amazing natural wonder this game has to offer.

However...
Even though this game is one that I couldn't stop playing until I had finished it has it's issues.
As many other reviews say, this game cost me £14.99 ($21.76 and 19.34 - This isn't exact as I used Google to convert the exact amount.) and only lasted me 3hrs, yes 3hrs. I didn't play fast as I didn't always follow my mission straight away, I often took the time to look around at this games wonderful art and speak with Delilah as the conversations are realistic and brilliantly acted.
Another negative, even though you often have to choose your own dialogue there's no consequences, the game didn't take a different turn due to what I said and as a result it has no replay value.

Overall I loved the experience but I do not agree with the price. I feel some issues could be fixed with free DLC (even though I can't see how this is possible, and could ruin what has already been made) or a lower price tag, this would be the better option. I would recommend this game, if you are willing to pay a large amount for a small game, even though I feel the storyline came to an anticlimax it is still a great build up and has a strong mystery and im still thinking about it and wanting to talk about it now, that to me is a good game overall and maybe it does last longer than you think.

Personal rating:
8/10

reviewText:
With a heavy heart I'm pressing the thumbs down button on this one...

Firewatch does many, many things amazingly well.
It's beautiful, has great art direction, the voice acting might be the best I ever heard in a game and the melancholy soundtrack fits perfectly (and is sadly underused). So why the thumbs down?

I don't mind a game-that-is-not-a-game". I don't mind a very short playtime. But I like my walking simulators to actually bring a provoking story or setting to the table. And Firewatch simply did not deliver for me in the end. It failed to deliver the main thing I was looking for... (just like Gone Home btw).
