reviewText:
The original review can be seen at   RogueReviews	[theroguereviews.com] with gifs, video clips and captions.

TL;DR
An exploration game based in the forests of Wyoming where you play as Henry, a firewatcher who finds he is being closely watched by mysterious strangers. You and your trusty sidekick who is only available to guide you through your walkie talkie must get to the bottom of this.

Pros

+beautiful aesthetic
+wonderfully crafted and memorable world
+great dialogue and voice acting
+great soundtrack
+turt reynolds

Cons

- quite short
- mystery plot feels a bit convoluted

Firewatch is a game that truly shows what indie devs are capable of putting out these days, with it's phenomenal art design and great soundtrack it makes you wonder where the budget is going in some of the bigger triple A titles. Firewatch impresses you the moment you boot into the game and hit the menu screen. You are presented with a beautiful backdrop of crystal blue skies and a watchtower overlooking the forests below on the mountain it resides atop of.

Once you're in game, the soundtrack kicks in as you navigate through a Choose Your Own Adventure styled story of how you met your future wife, Julia, at a bar while you were a bit too drunk. You make multiple decisions about your life with Julia and these decisions feel major, as if they could change the course of your game. This definitely feels influenced by the lead writer Sean Vanaman who is well known for his work on Telltale The Walking Dead Season 1, which has a similar CYOA feel to it. While you make these choices, you see glimpses of Henry getting into his pickup truck, with a huge backpack in tow and slowly hiking through a forest with what seems like no end in sight and no real destination.

Escapism is a constant theme in Firewatch, every character is in one way or another running away from their problems, too afraid to face them head on. Henry finally makes his way to his destination, a lonely watchtower in the middle of nowhere. You head up the stairs, turn on the power and grab your radio to introduce yourself to your fateful companion for the rest of the game. Her name is Delilah and she immediately asks What's wrong with you?"
date: certain that people only take this job to get away from something with Delilah being no exception. Everyone in this game in one form or another is running away from their problems
recommended: escaping into the vast wilderness in hopes of finding answers
hoursPlayed: or at least some sort of distraction from their thoughts. The characters feel human and vulnerable
voteText: allowing you to empathize with them in a deeper way you can't normally do with action man saves the world from inevitable destruction tropes. Firewatch is firmly rooted and grounded in reality like the nature you observe around you
helpfulPercent: giving you ample opportunity to find the answers you so desperately seek. Sometimes in life though
votesHelpful: the answers you get aren't always the ones you hoped to find and the closure you desired just won't be given through another person but through your own willingness to just accept that life doesn't play fair.\n\nDelilah is your emotional lifeline throughout the game
votesTotal: being the only source of contact with the outside world that you have. You play as a fire lookout

Being a lookout comes with the monotonous repetition of just sitting around and doing nothing for most of the day granting Henry the freedom to use his antique typewriter that his stepsister bought him. His monotonous routine is soon broken when he comes across a strange shadowy figure after exiting a cave heading back to homebase and he finds his typewriter was thrown out the watchtower's window along with his entire room being ransacked. Henry is convinced this is no mere coincidence

reviewText: Firewatch clocks in at around 4 hours of gameplay (or 6 if you're directionally and navigationally dysfunctional, like I am), and it's worth it. It's an incredibly well-done game - albiet small - but it relies more on character and story than anything else.\n\nThe one complaint I've heard others voice is that there are plot holes and the ending is a disappointment, but I don't quite see it that way. There were unanswered questions, and a few points that straight-up should have been explained FAR better than they were (which was not at all), but many of the holes" people talk about are really "fill in the blanks." For example
date: Delilah's character never reveals a particularly rich history
recommended: but it's about what she doesn't say
hoursPlayed: and what the player interprets that that makes Delilah especially interesting: she can be a very different character for each player.\n\nI personally liked that the plot of the game was open-ended in a lot of aspects
voteText:
because when in life is everything really wrapped up so neatly?

If you're looking for something with twists and turns that ends with everything wrapped up - this is NOT the game for you.

If you're looking for a great experience with character depth

reviewText:
PRO-The game was interesting at first, with prefection cartoon graphics with a inner personality to relate to. Being an indie game it was outstanding, I was truly amazed of how well put the dialogue was and the many choices.

CON-For a indie game the slapped on price tag of 20 bucks is huge, mostly with a game giving you roughly 5-6 hours of content depending on how often you play. The Ending will be very disappointing.

BUY?-Buy the game to watch the graphic thrive and the many relations you will make. Beware of the story details.

SPOILER ALERT-The Story is the games backbone, at first you start out as a ranger, the story drove to a great start. With Henry's many interaction with Deliah ;), but the game lacks in a proper ending, EVEN a resolution to a semi-conflict. As Henry you assume someone is stalking you and Deliah, which is right, but why do it in the first place. Ned (a guy whose son died in a rope climbing incident" and a former ranger) was stalking both of Deliah and Henry's conversation. Henry follows Ned's track and leads him to his dead son. But Why show Ned's dead son than suddenly disappear without a trace. Yes you find where Ned was hiding previously but why show it if there is no resolution and even a hint on how to erase what Ned did. Its like suddenly everything Ned was threatening to do fell into place and solved itself!? First were the girls which went missing and later found somewhere irrelevant and all of the mixed meaning recordings. Such as Deliah imposing on burning a camp down
date: which was later burnt down by Ned. All those threats were suddenly resolved by a fate or never explained (the recordings). The game's ending was pathetic

The game felt very rushed at the end

reviewText: Unfortunately, I cannot recomend this game. It simply is not worth what they are charging for it, as there is a total of about 3 to 4 hours of gameplay. There is no reason to repeat, as the only difference is the occasional different dialogue options. The reason I say that it is unfortunate that I cannot recomend it, is that the beggining and middle of the game were amazing, and I had lots of fun, and enjoyed the story they were laying out for me. A part of me even liked the end, and how different it was from what I expected, but the end came far too soon. The story felt like there was a whole saga planned, as though it would keep going, but instead you skip days. The game even shows you skip days, going from 2, to 9, then to 64, ect. The map was fun to explore, but there just was not enough of it TO explore. If you intend to have an exploration based game, you have to have a map of similar size to TLD, or Arma 2 or 3. When I started the game, and as it pulled me in, I began to expect a story on par with Alan Wake (1, not the abomination that was 2). I expected the game to revolve around the story, as it was simply a platform for the story to be told on, and in the begging it did, but then the story got rushed, pushed along to fast at the end. The build up was good, but then it suddenly ended and you were on the downhill, then it was over.\n\nI loved the game, and had lots of fun playing it, but there simply wasn't enough, of anything. There wasn't enough map to explore, there wasn't enough story, there weren't enough different options.

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game and for a good half of the game I actually did. I really did like some snippets of this game, but it wasn't enough to win me over. When I got further into the game and eventually beat it, I felt pretty empty and betrayed. Firewatch builds up a pretty interesting story and characters just to ruin it at the end and throughout.


What I liked:
-The voice acting was very convincing and felt very genuine. Very charming game.
-This game made me feel  emotions, joy, sadness, suspense, something I crave from games but rarely get.
-The visuals are gorgeous, quite possibly one of the most beautiful games I've played. (I've spent alot of time taking screenshots)
-The soundtrack was beautiful and played at very appropriate moments. Guided the  players' emotions.

What I did not like:
-The game was very linear and more often than not did not feel more open, rather it had the illusion of being open.
-The story fell flat on its face toward the end and halted to a stop abruptly. A giant build up just for nothing (very disappointed personally)
-Player choices did not matter at all. the game doesn't take any turns if you choose a certain line of dialogue. (at least thats what I gathered, I may be wrong)
-Very short, I usually enjoy short games, for example Dishonored. With this game, it was too short for its own good and could have been longer so the story met a satisfactory ending.
-Price tag is a little too high for this game, I felt like I paid too much for what I got.
-Boring achievements. Congrats you did something mandatory to finishing the game!

Some of my additional opinions:
-The main  characters, Henry and Delilah, should have tried to fix each others issues rather than continue to just point them out, some character progression would be nice.
-Their chemistry got a bit stale for me, but never got annoying.

Conclusion:
I don't want to tell you if you should get it or not because I don't feel like I have the authority to do so. Take my points into consideration and come to your own conclusion. Because I can't give a neutral review on steam I will give it a negative review since I'm teetering more on not recommending it. I don't hate it since it did give me some enjoyment even if it was followed by disappointing. I really wish there was a better ending to Firewatch. Maybe wait until a sale.

Thanks for your time!
voteText: 35 of 50 people (70%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Firewatch is a first person exploration game. There's not much interaction with the world besides picking up and examining some items. You play as Henry, a volunteer fire lookout at the wilderness of Wyoming. You keep contact through a radio with your supervisor Delilah. And this atleast for me was the best part of the game, the well written dialogue between characters where you can make choices how to react and what to say. These choices won't affect the actual plot of the game, but ofcourse will shape the relationship between Delilah and Henry. The voice acting is magnificent. The actors make everything sound so natural and real. I wish there were even more dialogue choices to make, too often there were no options at all.

The world looks beautiful and is quite fun to explore with a map and a compass at hand. Unfortunately the world has very little if any wildlife. I suppose it's ment to highlight the feeling of isolation, but it would have made the world less static and bit more interesting. The music in the game is used very sparingly, but always adds to the already great atmosphere.

Because of the short nature of the game, around 4-6 hours I won't talk about the story and plot points. It's all better left for the player to discover. There are big tonal shifts throughout the game, it starts with brilliant heavily dramatic text based intro and goes to jolly first day at the job. There's bit of a romance and suspense. There has been complaints about red herrings and dissapointing ending. But in my opinion, the game did really good job of putting me in Henry's shoes. I felt paranoia, joy, remorse and also dissapointment with him. It wasn't dissapointment about the game. The story, just like the characters felt real and mature. There's also have been people pointing out plot holes, but that's mainly because they weren't paying attention or were excepting something different. Though there is one thing I personally can't explain but nothing too major.

Firewatch is a good start for Campo Santo as their first game. I know they can do even better so I will be getting their next game day one also. Ofcourse this game is nott for everyone, since it could be called as glorified walking simulator. But personally, im open for more narrative driven even quite short experiences when the price matches that.

[Score: 84]

reviewText:
Firewatch is a prime example on how to hype a game, that is decent, but really nothing juicy or groundbreaking in any way. It's a walking simulator through and through, but with outstanding voice acting.

+ GREAT voice acting
+ decent art style
+ a little bit interesting

- short (you've seen it all in less than 4 hrs)
- no replay value
- no decisions
- linear
- not worth 20 bucks, maybe 5-10...
- weak ending

If you can pick it up for less than 10 dollar, it may be worth it, but prepare yourself to be bored a bit.

If you hide your location on the map it's a bit more interesting.

reviewText:
This game looked like a unique, stunning, fun, casual game you could play for hours, and try to solve the mystery that was presented near the beginning of the game, but what it turned out to be was a massive disappointment

Pros:
- Stunning graphics, with the same design as games like Team Fortress 2, and Hurtworld
- Voice actors delivered very well and some of the best parts of the game come from the conversations
- The soundtrack sounds very well at times
- The game starts out great

Middle:
- The atmosphere really helps the game at times, like when you begin and you haven't experienced a game like this before
- Walking around the map and getting through some places is the most challenging part of the game

Cons:
- The game is probably one of the shortest I have played
- The ending is very unsatisfying
- The dialogue choices don't matter at all
- The price for what it delivers
- The replay value that you hoped you would get for the little time you put in the entire game.
- The game starts out strong with backstory, and gets your hopes up, but when you realise that this isn't the game that was presented to you, it's already to late to turn back and refund it.

TL;DR Firewatch is a game with great graphics and exploration, but falls short with the story and replay value, the price is way too much for the money you will put into it.

Final score: 5/10

reviewText: Loved the game a lot from the begininning, and was really hyped when i saw it in the development phase. But, after playing the 3.2 Hours i did in one night, not rushing at all, I won't ever touch the game again. Don't get me wrong, i absolutely adored the art style and interesting setting. That along with the character Delila's communication between the player, Henry, are the only good points in this demo-lenght game. The game is technically open world, in the sense that you can, at any point in the story, traverse the unblocked paths. However, it is just that, only paths, no real exploration is ever presented to the player aside from clicking on different objects in a tent. The story is very entertaining and has a good draw to it from the start, but it begins to falter into the later third of the 3 hour game. Overall, the game is definitely not worth the $20 asked for it. You could just as well go on the Firewatch website and order a print for around the same price, and that would have more value to you in the end than this game, which might as well be an expensive point-and-click title, ever will.

reviewText:
I think after playing this all the way through, I can't help but feel like it was rushed out. As if it went overbudget and they just wanted to ship it by wrapping it up ASAP. The story, art direction (albeit lazy) and voice talent is nice, but the rest of it just falls flat:

Early on you come across a camera which you can use to take photographs of evidence -- which is deliberately hinted as something you should be doing -- but it doesn't actually amount to anything. I forgot I even had it later in the game, but it turns out it doesn't matter anyway because whatever you do with it is never referenced again.
Illusion of choice is a recurring theme. At one point you get to choose between starting a fire and not starting a fire. If you don't, it'll coincidentally start anyway because reasons. It's the worst example, but it is moreorless a metaphor for the entire game.
There are a few visual bugs, such as floating grass, one-sided rocks and in some cases prematurely unloaded areas that ruin the immersion a bit.
A minor subplot is suddenly the main focus at the last minute of the game. The kid being found dead in the cave was the least interesting plot and didn't hook me as much as the main mystery.
Are you seriously implying that Delilah wasn't going to wait five freaking minutes to meet Henry face-to-face after nearly three months of bonding just to get on a helicopter a little earlier, even though that she knew that the helicopters were going to come back and she even said they were making the rounds"?
The ending is really abrupt. It just... ends.
If you want to play a good mystery game where you play as a man who loves typewriters

reviewText:
I loved the sound, the music, the voice acting and the graphics....and the story kept me interested all the way til the end.  I can't comment on the story without spoiling so I'll just say there are things I liked and things I didn't.

The reason im saying no is that this game cost me approximatley 17 usd.  My personal template is 1 dollar for 1 hour of entertainment however Im willing to pay more if I think the game is really special.  I beat the game in something like 5 hours (sorry I didn't check how long I played)...and 1 hour of that was literally trying to find the correct path or area I was told to go to.  At one point I walked to an area seeing a very obvious object that seemed out of place but nothing happened.  The event later triggered as I walked deeper into the area after wandering around for 15 minutes.  I liked the rappelling part too but at some point it just kind of became annoying.  You spend probably another 20 mins rappelling.  So there is really only about 3 to 4 hours of game play for a 17 dollar game.

The interactions between Deliah and Henry are great...and the voice actors were superb.  I just can't see this game being worth more than 5 bucks right now and I hate to say that because I know these guys worked hard and I want to encourage devs who break away from cookie cutter designs but id really hold off on this one until there is a sale of at least 50%.

The graphics can be breathtaking, the dialogues are realistic and will hold you on to the story as much as any other things do that happen.
10/10, seriously. Just buy it. Play it.

reviewText:
The game was excellent at first.. the first part was kind of like a choose your own adventure game.  And then.. the choices got harder and harder.  And by the time that i was actually able to walk around i was fully invested in Henry's story.  I will admit, the scenery was quite lovely and the dialogue between Henry and Delilah was entertaining.  However, i dont think it was worth its price. If you do decide to get this game, wait until it is on sale.  I felt there was not enough content for it to be worth its full listing price.. or even its sale price (which was 17.00 when i got it.)

Sad to say, i ended up not enjoying much of the scenery because i was glued to the map the entire time, making sure i was going the right direction.  There was all this suspense towards the end.. and i was floored the entire game long, waiting for something amazing to happen something to be revealed.. some deadly secret everyone was keeping from me.  But at the end of the game.. six hours in.. the ending left me feeling dissapointed.  I needed more answers.. the abrupt way it ended just felt.. wrong.. the whole time i expected more.. but there was nothing.  Honestly, the game end made me feel like someone ripped the middle and parts of the end out of a really good book and then just left me with the scraps.

Not to mention i spent nearly an hour stuck on a set of rocks, glitching out with invisible walls which didn't seem like they should be there at all.  Why let me climb a rock and then not go back down the other side when its touching the ground.  It was rather frustrating.

In the end.. this game is a walking simulator.. which i tend to enjoy when they have a story.. but this one.. felt dull and lifeless.  I mean.. it wasn't really bad because i was glued to the screen the entire time i was playing.. but the ending.. just felt like a huge cop out.  So.. in the end.. i would say only play this game if you are looking for nothing exciting to happen.

reviewText:
I came in not knowing anything hyped about this game, just that it was a game people were playing.

The first hour was fantastic but it all goes downhill from there. For a 4 hour game (a fact that I'm okay with) you spend too much time on things that take too much time from the main storyline or they are so loosely tied to the storyline that they seem to be random events. In fact, for most of the game I was wondering what the main storyline was and what the message was. Is the character supposed to be finding something out about themselves? Do they go through some adversity or gain some kind of insight to better understand their problems? All of those questions are hard to answer given the entire journey. At the end of the game, I'm still confused as to what the point of the game was. The first hour really allows you to empathize with the characters situation, but everything after that is so rushed or brief that you barely have time to process it.

The more I thought about it, the more disappointed I was that this game got so close to being a GOTY game to a mere afterthought.

reviewText:
I came into firewatch expecting a walking simulator and boy oh boy was I right. This is not a bad game, its beautiful, has an engaging plot and characters who are incredibly well written and voice acted. The walking itself is done well, animations can be janky but its easy enough that your mind can wander but the hiking element forces you to be engaged just enough to pay attention to whats going on. The game has its mystery moments, its kinda-but-not-really action moments and its moments where you very genuinley just pause and go... ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.
The ending unfortunatley lets its down, great potetntial but wimps out and goes for the easiest option possible. A shame but eh, nothings perfect.
GOTY 2016? Probably not.
But it is a damn good time waster and one I would reccommend for that sole reason alone.

reviewText:
Short Review (Spoiler Free)

Pros
Nice Aesthetics
Very good voice work and dialogue(Only bright spot for me).
Relatively bug free
Charming characters

Cons
Short 2-4 hours (I explored a lot and I hit 3.4 hours...I mean wow)
Very Weak Story
Story Problems
- Lack of characters
- Manufactured Suspense and Mystery
- Poor choices on story development
- Failure to tie up loose plot points
- Poor Pacing
- Bad Ending that has ultimately has little to no meaning
Lack of Wildlife
Pointless interactables (Eating, Fishing Pole, etc.)
No camping, hunting, fishing stuff to do for fun

All and all, it’s walking simulator with a short, terrible story.  I'd advise against buying the game unless it's $5 or less...and I feel like I'm being generous.




Long Review (Some spoliers)

Firewatch is everything an indie game should strive NOT to be.  It’s short, has no replayability, no game mechanics and a bad story.

It's a slice of life tale that is fed to you from the start as a man whose wife develops Alzheimer's in her 30's and is ultimately taken by her family to live in Australia.  The protagonist is Henry a tortured man that takes a job as a lookout for the summer to watch for fires alone in the wilderness.  This is explained all by unvoiced text at the start of the game.

Thus begins the story in where you are greeted by Delilah(head lookout) over the radio who will be the only other character this in game.  The game is really linear so you are pushed on to immediately tracking down people setting off fireworks.   Overall a decent start, you get down there and you fine 2 drunk college girls skinny dipping in the lake.  You return home and catch a glimpse of mysterious man making the player curious.

At this point the game does a fine job of building tension and suspense.  The main problem the story some scenes exist purely for setting a tone of suspense or danger.  The player doesn’t realize this at first and is only made aware of it at the very end.

For example, a lot more happens with those girls(supposedly) and they vanish from the story after they are reported missing.  No follow up or anything, all of tension and suspense around them vanishes and they become so unimportant the devs didn’t even mention their fate, yet are made out to be potential players in the mystery.

The worse crime the devs committed was the ending, it totally ruins the story in so many ways.  To the point it poisoned the whole game for me.   After playing the game, I wish I had never played it….it was that bad.  It cheapens the whole experience which was the length of a long movie.  The game should have been way cheaper and the reviews are deceiving.  I’d be happy to go over my thoughts in detail on the game/steam forums but they appear to ban topics of criticism of this very flawed game.

Don't get me wrong, there are good things about the game such as the dialogue and voice acting but that isn't enough.  That doesn't make the game.

TL;DR?
Firewatch is the MOST overrated game I’ve ever seen based on the reviews and has one of the worst stories of any game I’ve ever played.

Edit: Some spacing and grammar.

reviewText:
You might ask, what even is Firewatch? [Even though that tag is mysteriously missing from the store page]

Its a Walking Simulator goobai.

Alright fine. Let us parse the branches in this experience.

You play as a forest ranger in the state of Wyoming. Your job is simple. Look for fires and report them and also don't die.

The game begins with a series of text bubbles that set up the background of Henry, who you play as; Now, everyone is going to have a slightly different experience at this junction. As far as I understand this is also the case for the rest of the game. Each person will have a unique impression and take away from each time dialogue choices are made. But I have played 1 and 1/3 times through this game at the time of writing this and the through line is quite linear but the subtlety comes from each dialogue choice. I should also mention at this point the games primary interaction is with speaking with one specific character through a radio. Presumably located in another tower.

Now, I will not say ANYTHING specific as the games bread and butter is exploration and well... figuring out what this game is exactly. I will say that this is one of those games where I could literally just sit at the edge of precipice and just relax, listen to the wind blow and be extant. At some point you additionally start to know the park without needing to take heed of the compass and map and that's when you start to take some ownership in what you are doing.

There are a lot things that are alluded to throughout the narrative that never really come to fruition or a satisfying culmination but that doesn't really take away from what does happen. I believe the writing is intentionally misleading. You need not look far for red herrings.

THE GIST
I REALLY like this game but like most walking simulators they need to played without any sort of spoilers and that makes it very difficult to write about. It has very adult, mature themes. Again I don't want to say anything. I will not be responsible should anything get spoiled for you. But this game is very potentially depressing. It has very prescient issues in today’s world despite taking place in the late 80's as a lot of humans have relationships with other humans who do not actually have much physical proximity. It deals with ideas of isolation and paranoia, the real kind. Not some supernatural put on hokey pokey crap. I do think it ends rather abruptly however, there is definitely more I want to know. But obviously the game has to end at some point. I can't wait to see what Campo Santo does next.

reviewText:
A little over 3 hours of playtime for me, though some people are closer to 4 hours.

The story starts out to be very promising and emotional, but seems to drop off from there, and can't seem to find a good direction to go. The ending is a bit underwhelming.

The game looks beautiful, and is a pleasure to explore, but unfortunately there's a limit to how much you can explore. The game is very linear in your choices, and with what you can do each day.

The game limits where you can go, and can be buggy with it (I got stuck on small rocks a couple times and couldn't walk off of them). I encountered a few minor bugs, nothing that really affected the gameplay.

Worth playing, but I'd probably wait until it's on sale for more than 10% off.

reviewText:
At the full price, no, I would not recommending buying this game.

First of all, it was a wonderful story. The narration between the two characters, including all the backstory that is revealed felt like reading a good book.

The game was everything I expected. It was very professionally done, no major glitches with a clean release. It was a nice adventure/story game.

The downer to me came when I completed the game in 3 hours. While I did not catch every easter egg, I did explore the whole map, all the boxes and took my time taking various routes on the map. The bottom line, for me, is $20 for 3 hours just isn't worth it to me.  Had this game been priced at $5 or $10, I would have been more than happy with a positive review.

The worst part was that at the 3 hour point, it falls just outside the time limit for a steam refund. It is almost maddening to know that maybe if I hurried the story along quicker, I could have beaten the game in full AND recieved a steam refund!

reviewText: The best way I can describe Firewatch is that it is the grown-up version of going to camp for the summer. It's about the kind of relationship you can forge with a person when being so far away from your real life and the kind of mysteries that seem so grand and terrifying when you have nothing else to do but dwell on them. Above all, though, it's about the feeling you get when the summer comes to an end and it's time to go home. Do you feel disillusioned? Did the bonds you form mean anything? That's for you to find out.\n\nFirewatch is a narrative experience that lasts roughly five hours, and it's not something I'd particularly want to play again. However, I loved this game and my experience with it will be something I'll talk about and think about in the future when I think about how games can do things that books and movies cannot. I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Firewatch is perfectly named because the title fully describes the experience of playing it.
The experience can be compared to setting fire to two sculptures and watching them burn down.

At the start, you are roped in by a novel idea and you marvel at how nice it looks. As time moves on, you enjoy the nuances of how they behave, change and interact, and there's a certain thrill involved in the process, but the novelty is starting to fade since you're not doing much else than watching it burn.

About halfway in there's not much new to see, small variations of the thing you've already been looking at for the past hour or two, and it's not getting any better, there's actually less of what you liked when you first began.

By the end you realize how short-lived the experience was, that there was little to no pay-off from watching it unfold, and you wish something else had been done with the two sculptures, because this seemed like a poor way to use them, in hindsight.

reviewText:

reviewText:
Firewatch is pretty damn amazing as a story. It makes you care about Henry, it makes you care about his need for peace. It makes you care and rejoice his friendship with Delilah with the power of a handheld radio.

It makes you want to see more, hear more, find out more, it makes you involved, and in that regard the game is a story that unfolds with an amazing pace and building suspense.

There are basically no bad things i can mention about this game except one: i really feel the ending was rushed & the game is VERY short with limited replayability.

The game's performance is pretty nice and works pretty well at 60FPS on a GTX780 on max settings and most of the game looks pretty amazing overall. The draw distance is pretty great and the level of (stylized) detail is defiantly there)


It's almost perfect in what it tries to do: a mystery focused on the story and the pacing in a unique settings with some of the most amazing characters and voice acting I've ever had in a game. The price is very steep for it's length, might want to wait on a sale.



You can see my full review on youtube:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PYujpocc1_I&ab_channel=GuyLogic

reviewText:
The thing that infuriates me about Firewatch is that it has so much going for it, but fumbles with its content that barely fills three hours to a predictable end.

Opening with a text-based sequence that knocks the emotional appeal of the game out of the park, coupled with a simple tutorial sequence that furthers the story and shows off the game's aesthetics: I was impressed when I started playing Firewatch last night.
Rounding off that intro and getting through the first day of protagonist Henry's new job, I was stunned by the immensely appealing aesthetic qualities of the game, which you can clearly see in the screenshots for the game. As I continued on, getting stuck into an intriguing mystery and some great voice acting, I found myself only being drawn further into a story that seemed to slowly expand over time and could seemingly spring in any direction unexpectedly. The paranoia and honest moments of fear that emerged were great, really amping up the beauty of the canyons and forests into a fearful wilderness.
But as each day of the game passed, the story narrowed itself down in a way I had already spectulated for myself and I increasingly saw through each day of the game as less of a continuation of the story but more of a level of playing the game - very simply moving from place to place without feeling anything more of that space. The story became more so a string in the forests to be picked up and followed, trivialising the agency of my character and discouraging a more organic and free exploration of the space.

The colour palette and visual appeal of Firewatch is genuinely extraordinary. I don't think I've seen anything quite like this before in a game, wherein I look at my surroundings and this environment and really feel that I'm there: one man in all this nature. The singular lighting, the intense colour through the trees, the distant horizons and lush fauna: Firewatch is a beautiful game. Even if the appeal wears off over time, the beauty and finesse with which the environments have been composed is great and should be commended as one of the best features of Firewatch alongside its voice acting and soundtrack.

The story of Firewatch is very much so the Hitchcock-ian thriller, deconstructed in part. The lingering notes of people missing, things left in precarious places and that can't be right" moments that fall down to you give a great sense of mystery to the story and fit the bill quite well. The issue is that they only expand so far
date: in the end ultimately being given up for sake of a rather predictable pursuit of characters that we don't feel connected to. Likewise
recommended: Firewatch lets go of its emotional bedrock that starts the game off very quickly and only ever returns to it briefly in order to reassure some kind of feeling that I certainly didn't have halfway through the game.\nA disappointing aspect is that whatever you find will ultimately be relevant to the central story in a way that diminishes the overall effect of the game. For example: there is one cave in the game. Just the one. And something is in the cave because you found that one cave. Nothing gets left lingering or tying itself up. Everything falls down to this ending that really isn't that appealing: the conversation from which it comes up in originally just rolls off like every other conversation you have in the game. It's disappointing to know that the game world
hoursPlayed: although feeling big
voteText: is actually just as small as any other nowadays. It diminishes its appeal massively and in the end throws the majority of it away.\n\nThe voice acting is grand
helpfulPercent: despite treading the convoluted story over time. Given more time
votesHelpful: I'm sure the true emotional range of these characters would blossom in a way that fees more developed and mature for the story's themes. But instead
votesTotal: Delilah tells you of cripplingly stupid decisions she's made that make zero sense in such a small timeframe. The to and fro that her and Henry engage in is wonderful but unfortunately often lacks the depth that I feel it aspires to with its emotional backstory.\n\nI wish Firewatch was longer. After three hours
votesFunny: I didn't feel like I had gotten £15/£19's worth of an experience. In parts it felt rushed and painfully so

reviewText:
I purchased this game on a whim. Remembering back to the E3 information about the game and thought the idea of exploration and mystery would make for a good premise plus the sale price reduction was worth a purchase.
I was so very wrong.
The game starts out very strong with establishing the characters and setting the scene, covering the few glimpses shown during the E3 footage (girls at the lake) and goes along a day at a time. It seemed to be setting a good pace for a few sessions of play and it was engaging enough to warrant that.
Then the time skips happened.
Before you know it wham 6 days have gone by. Cut to short dream sequence. WHAM more timeskip to day 15. Blink and you missed everything up until day 33.

Now these massive skips in time and rushing of the game wouldn't matter too much if there was some decent development going on right? well sorry you instead get only slivers of information about your single companion during this time. The irony of this is that later in the game dossiers of information are found which provide more information about Delilah than all of your conversations up until that point.

Dont even get me started on the glitches, the climbing is buggy as hell and I often found myself clipping onto rocks with no way to get down due to the lack of a climbdown or jump function, I have had multiple problems with the world not loading and then springing into exsistence often leaving me off the predetermined trail meaning another reload. For a game as short as this at least 6 reloads over the space of 2 hours for somthing with simplistic gameplay like this is unacceptable.

This game was a big letdown, it says it has an emotional lifeline with Delilah but ends up feeling shallow. It says you have the Wyoming Wilderness but only gives you rigid paths to walk on. It says it has great scenery but this is only a thin coating on the barebones box you walk around in. It says it has mystery but every mystery except one is solved over a single conversation at the end of the game.

If you want to play an extremely short visual novel with forgetable characters, simplistic mechanics which are poorly implemented and an ending which essentially puts you back a square one as if the game never happened then this $20 disappointment is for you.

reviewText:
I really hate marking this as 'Not recommended' but I really wouldn't tell my friends to go buy it.

The pros:
+ it's got great humour
+ it's pretty to look at
+ it's going to get you hooked
+ the atmosphere it makes is just wonderful

The cons:
- it's short
- the ending is underwhelming altho i would say it fits well

I just can't bring myself to recommend a game that costs £15 full price and you can finish in 3 hours (I was afk for about 1.5hr and left the game open) when I have played flash games on newgrounds that have entertained me for far longer for free. Yes the experience in Firewatch is amazing, I just can't justify it.

reviewText:
I echo the sentiment of others. At the end of the day, this game has only 3 hours of content with little to no replayability. Buy it when it's on sale for $5-10. At that price, it's a game interactive story worth playing being part of. At $20, it's alright at best.

Price tags shouldn't really influence how good a game is, but in this case it does. For example, a AAA title with only 20-30 hours of gameplay (the low end) at $60 is still worth it if the hours are fun (Shadows of Mordor is a good example). In this case, however, I can't seem to justify paying a third of a triple-A title with only one tenth of the gameplay, if that. Something just doesn't feel right.

Anyway, price rant over, here's the actual review, with a warning that some of this may be considered minor spoilers given the nature of a mystery" game:

Without getting too involved in the plot

reviewText:
Theres no neutral button so i have to go for not recommended

Played the game from start to finish, liked the game for what it is but at the end of the day I felt very disappointed.

Firewatch is a beautiful game, the story is ok, it has the mystery and will keep you engaged for the duration of your playthrough until the end, you figure out theres actually no mystery and more of a cop out...
The banter between the main character and Delilah is great and witty, it really gives them both a personality.

I think the game falls a bit on the short side is because the game is way too short, it was described as a 6-7 hour long journey by the developers but you could finish it between 3 - 4 hours, give or take (took me 3 hours and 45 minutes). That was me exploring every corner of the whole map. I kinda feel cheated on this aspect, not cool to advertise it as 6-7 hours when it's clearly not.

The map / landscape feels dead, there is honestly not much you can do other than just walking around and enjoying the scenery, theres not much wild life and almost no interactions other than silly examine" this where you rotate objects etc and opening supply crates. No gameplay other than just walking around and proceeding with the simple story.

Still i think the game is good enough but I can't justify €20 for such a short game
date: totally worth buying during a big sale and people who are intersted in the game should wait for one before buying. You honestly won't miss much for not playing the game now."

reviewText: I just finished my first play through, and I have to say. I don't think I've ever sat alone in my room and gone through an emotional rollercoaster like that. The critics will say what they will but I get it. I get everything. All the things that people will inevitably complain about in this game is there for a reason. The developers have laid out an amazing, interactive and immersive story about a man who goes to seek solitude in the wilderness, and instead finds an outlet for his emotions. In the end, I would like to believe that Henry and I both found exactly what we were looking for. We discovered that being alone is not the same as being lonely and human interaction is what you make of it. There were times when the story was so tense, and there were times when it was heart wrenching, but I understand. It's there for a reason. All said, this piece of artful storytelling leaves you craving for more, but that's what good storytelling does. I will miss Delilah and I may even revisit this game again in the future, just to hear her voice and indulge in her wit. Great Job, I was definitely satisfied with this game.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rno9cq_H810

Firewatch was developed and published by Campo Santo on the 9th February 2016. The game is priced at £14.99. A press review copy was provided for The Hidden Levels.

Firewatch is a first person action-adventure game set in the awesome Wyoming terrain. You play as a ‘Firefighter’ in which your job is to protect fires from starting and always being alert and vigilant to the terrain around you so that you prevent major fire accidents. The game goes way deeper than this though and you’re forced to make choices which can in tandem change the outcomes of the story.


Things I liked:

Graphics – The graphics on this game are gorgeous with the unique artstyle making exploring around the environments rewarding and fun. There have been times in game where I would just freeze and stare at the landscape.

Story – The story starts straight away unique, playing like a visual novel for the first fifteen minutes of the game, giving you a deeper understanding of the main character and giving you a more intricate bond. I don’t want to give away too much because spoilers but the story is very hooking and addictive.

Main character – I felt an instant connection with Henry and since the first conversation in the tower with Delilah (who is your supervisor in the game) enjoyed his humour and slight sarcasm to the full extent. He seems to be a very caring guy who tries to shrug everything off like he is laid back.


Things I disliked:

Thrown in the deep end – The game slowly tries to edge you in but before you know it, you’re thrown in the wilderness and not a clue where to go if you miss some vital text. Once you get your feet back up from the floor and find out how the system works you then can start to progress further into the story.

Controller options – The controller works great, when you’re using it and it still gives you the Keyboard buttons is what is not so great. There have been times when the keyboard buttons have come up on screen for me to be confused and have to press random buttons on the controller until I learn them.


Being alone is very scary and I was quick to learn this on Firewatch. The game is really unique and a breath of fresh air and I fully enjoyed being thrown from one life to another. Delilah really helps you along with everything and becomes your guardian angel almost and it is scary to think what it would be like without her (hehe).

The whole genre and game is new to me, I’ve not played much of the same type games for instance Long Dark, Kholat. If you enjoyed those games or are looking for a unique experience I can wholeheartedly say that this game is definitely worth it.

Score: Buy it now!

reviewText:
I played this with my spouse and we felt it was very pretty and the tricks with the outdoor terrain to make it feel bigger were nice, but the story lacked depth, completion, and closure.  We felt a little cheated in the end and Unity attempted to turn my GPU to slag for the last 4 maps of the game.  Our bedroom got so hot we turned on a fan to cool it down because we began sweating. The endings we very much wanted to see and expected based on the gameplay did not happen and were not options. The finish was anticlimactic and unsatisfying.

The environments were beautiful but not immersive. I expected to encounter raccoons or other wildlife spoken about in the game but did not, also bears were alluded to but absent. In fact, I think there was only one visible NPC the character interacted with. Most environments didn't feel lonely or expansive, just empty or lacking polish, with modeling errors which broke the suspension of disbelief (tube steel modular construction on a 'communications tower with all kinds of equipment. ' which lacked any antennae, but had an anemometer. Textures, shaders, use of lights, and navigable terrain were good, but the rushed feel of 'hurry up and wait' didn't make us want to explore and enjoy the details. Most of the details looked like thinly disguised 'invisible walls' binding the player to a very small area.

The last third of the game felt rushed to meet a release deadline, the story was at times very depressing and the options for endings are sobering and pessimistic. This was enhanced by the contrast created by the serene natural environments which made me feel happy just long enough to feel bummed out or confused again. I wouldn't say I enjoyed it overall because of this. I feel worn out after playing, I want to go play something... fun and less sad. I wouldn't recommend it at full price.

reviewText:
A Story or a Library?
I began playing the game thinking it was not as good as The Long Dark… because of the scenery, you know? The scenery is great, but TLD is more so. But, as I played I soon realized it was nothing like TLD. Firewatch is unlike any game I’ve played. It is not like the text-based choice games I’ve played, and as one of my friends said, it’s not like the Tell-tale games. And, that reticle! It’s in your view from the time the game starts, until the end.
I’d classify it as an adventure mystery game. It’s totally uncontrived. Everything you do and explore involves real-world exploration activities you might find in that environment, like in Stanley’s Parable. Instead of contrived puzzles, most of the game is spent using a map and a compass to navigate around a series of paths through a State Forest in Wyoming.
The dialogue is sensitive, and besides the f-bombs sprinkled throughout, various topics such as suicide are discussed. So it is not really a game for younger players. The dialogue uses quite a bit of foreshadowing. Their world is outside the real world, disassociated and cut off from phone lines. At times you are not sure whether to trust either character. But, you soon realize they both feel cut-off from the world; Henry by his wife’s loss of awareness, and Delilah by her inability to attach.
If you like mysteries, if you enjoy dialogue and rich story interactivity, if you ever took trips using a map and compass, or just wish you could; this game is probably for you. However, the game has numerous issues that may be problematic in the eyes of some “gamers.” I will be giving some spoilers, so you may choose to not read the rest of my review until after you’ve played the game.
Henry’s wife is a college prof diagnosed with early onset Dementia. For various reasons he runs away from dealing with this, and ends up in the forest watching for fires. It seems he can’t deal with the loss of self-identity more than anything. While there, he falls into a routine of a radio conversation/romance with Delilah, another Firewatcher. It’s a definite source of comfort to him. But, he’s dealing with a lot of guilt over his wife who is living with her family back home. Ultimately he abandoned her. He has a run-in with some college girls/teens who are shooting off fireworks and skinny-dipping in the lake. One refers to him as just “a sad old man in the woods,” which hurts his feelings and tends to lead you to believe the girls are grad students and are recording their conversations and studying them. That never panned out in the ending I got.
I felt the graphics were very well done, the drawing was beautiful, and the game played well, though it was quite linear. The mechanics were fun, and not forced. But most of the issues I found related to the story. Actually, I saw what I thought was a spoiler in the forum before the game was released. Some guy randomly announced that everything that happened was a figment of Henry’s imagination and that Delilah was not real. I was disappointed to have it spoiled before I even played, but soon found out I came up with a very different ending than that. I asked a few friends who played the game, and they all got the same ending I got. It certainly seemed to me that there were certain “collection points” where regardless of how you chose your answers, you were pulled back into the same story line with everyone else.
Sometimes, things happened the opposite of what you had chosen. For example, I told Deliah to go ahead and go when she asked if I minded. A friend told her to wait on him. In both games, she was gone when we got to her tower at the end of the game. It didn’t really seem to matter what you chose to say to her.  In the words of another friend, it seems that little things change, like how you describe yourself or dialog. (Thanks James!)  I would have preferred choices to make major changes in the endings.
Another issue I had with the story is that everything points you to conspiracy theories… the allusion to JFK on the cover of one book; the whole idea of government sponsored tests using radio signals, like with HAARP; and the mentions of Ronald Reagan’s policy of dealing (or not dealing) with forest fires.
So, there are a lot of easter eggs “littered” throughout the story… literally. Primarily, there are books skewed about everywhere you go, and the titles seem suggestive, if not a little familiar. But, only one had a name that I recognized for sure… Jane Eyre by Charlotte Bronte. I believe most of the others were fake books to give hints the storywriter wanted to use to lead your thinking in a certain direction… toward conspiracy theories.
There were a number of books around the map by a Richard Sturgeon, who I’ve never heard of, but they all have numbers in their titles. Death Strikes at Two, Eight Rolled the Hard Way, The Fourth Estate, Terminal 7, One Chance to Die, Three Blind Rats, and Five Degrees North.
Of course, the 4th estate is a term used in America to describe the media. Eight rolled the hard way would be rolling eight in a game of craps without getting doubles. It’s considered a hard roll, because there is only one way to roll it. The rest, your guess is as good as mine.
Other books found include: The Singular Mind –Jonas Allard, Glory – Michelle MacManus, The Birds of Wyoming – George Sinclair, The Patriots – Donald Anderson, The Accidental Savior – Terrence Greenbriar, Jane Eyre- Charlotte Bronte and Black Band Comics.
Notice that Jane Eyre is definitely a real book, though I’m not sure about the others. In Jane Eyre, the lead male character has a “crazy wife” who he has locked away and basically abandoned. He is trying to remarry, and experiences much guilt over this, much as Henry feels guilty over abandoning his wife in the game. Also, Delilah seems slippery, much like Jane Eyre, seeming to turn Henry away in the end, suggesting he go see his wife.
There were other things scattered throughout that seemed suggestive, but were certainly loose ends. The “Escape from Two Orcs Map” seemed to lead you to the idea that some evil force lurked in the forest. The Polyhedral dice (d20) similar to those from Dungeons & Dragons games only showed Bryan liked fantasy stories. Like the FireFinder  and Medicine Wheel, they just seemed to be included for atmosphere, perhaps to lend a reason for loving the forest, which goes up in blazes in a very dramatic conclusion.
Many of the days are skipped automatically. To thoroughly explore all the items found in every location, you have to ignore the mission mentioned in the map until you are finished looking at everything. Otherwise you will jump ahead to the next day in the sequence.
It has a sad ending, and feels hollow. But, it plays beautifully, and you feel engaged throughout. There are a few additional features, like an in-game camera that will provide actual prints of the photos you take. I did not feel the need to buy the sound track in this game, though the music is nice.  I just felt it wasn’t used in the game very much. The sounds were mostly nature ambient sounds.
I felt like the pieces were left unresolved. But, I would definitely play it again, simply because it was a lot of fun playing, and the conversations between characters (who you never see) are so real and personal, in a way that few other narrative games approach. It is certainly not an “Answers” story.
With all of that said, I do highly recommend the game. I loved it and spent a lot of time playing it. Most gamers seem to be completing it in just 3 to five hours. I spent over 20. But, I do not consider myself the average gamer. For all the reasons I mentioned, I think Firewatch may be more of a niche game with awesome graphics.

reviewText:
SPOILER alert about the ending as an answer to a lot of negative reviews.
Everyone is rambling about the ending, why it is rushed and does not give a proper solution, does not ties up everything.
I think it is wonderfully suspended, as it is just as fallible as humans. There is no relief for free, everyone has to make his or her decisions and take the responsibility for it.
As for Henry, it is still up to her whether he will look for Delilah or goes back to his wife once more (or regularly).
In overall, this game is (and the ending especially) is about life and the tragicomic aspects of it particularly. There is nothing black or white, and there is always a silver lining.
Enjoy this beautiful game, with open headphones if possible, and just ask yourself, what would yo do in Henry's place.
THAT'S the moral of the story. YOU.

reviewText:
hmmm....I was going to wait for a while to play this game, but it was on sale this week and I just decided what the hell, might as well give it a go. In retrospect, that was an excellent decision as this was a quality game well worth peoples time.

Although a walking simulator (a genre I already enjoy), the dialogue was outstanding, and as real life natural as it possibly could have been. The voice actors really did great work on this game. Visually, it was also a beautiful game, but in a more muted way than you might expect from a game that released within the last year. It was evocative, and really added to the story without getting in the story's way.

In every way, this was a thoughtful journey through mid life crisis and dramatic change in a pair of individuals lives, the way in which they tried to escape their realities, and the way they started to sort through their issues via communicating with each other over walkie talkie. The subplot, presented as the main plot throughout, was a mystery surrounding a stalker and possible murder(s). Although at the forefront, as I said, this was really the subplot, the main plot being one of self discovery through adversity and communication. A catharsis of the human spirit if you will.

All told, the game weighed in at about 4 hours, and I dont really feel that there is any replay value. However, the game was strong enough to be worth the asking price for a single 4 hour experience in my opinion, so strong was the writing and the character development.

As far as gameplay, fairly standard walking simulator/exploration game. Walk, run, jump, pick up and examine items. There is a photography feature offered about half way through the game, and that was a nice feature IMO.

I have also heard complaints about the ending, but in my estimation, it ended exactly as it should have. There was really no where else to go while staying true to the story. I thought it worked perfectly.

All told, I would give this one 8 out of 10. Not epic material, but really good and worthwhile experience.

reviewText:
Firewatch.. what an amazing game. The scenery is absolutely gorgeous, the world is pretty big and relaxing. The music in this game is perfect, the sound effects are just amazing and the game feels really polished.

The voice acting.. oh man the voice acting, this is basically what the game is about and where it shines. At the beginning of the game you get to choose your characters backstory and from that moment on you get sucked up in the story.
While you're out there in the woods your boss talks to you through your walkie-talkie. After a while it really feels like you build a relationship with your boss and the story can even get emotional at times. The story also has a few twists that make you think about the choices you made, and wonder how it is all connected


Overall, i would highly recommend this game to everyone that likes story driven games, with beautiful environments. Although it only takes you around 4 to 5 hours to complete this game, the hours are well worth it.

reviewText:
I've got to say I'm quite disappointed in Firewatch. I was looking forward to this one for a long time, and while the environments themselves are very beautiful, it really has very little else going for it. Far too linear - you only ever travel from point A to B to C. There is no true exploration - I even turned off my map locator to make the experience more immersive, but it didn't help much. You can't stray far off the beaten path.

The story is quite weak, treading ground done MUCH better by The Vanishing of Ethan Carter. I'd recommend that instead, or the also excellent Gone Home.

Lifeless, bleak, boring. Sorry Campo Santo - I really wanted to like Firewatch, but it fizzled out in the end.

reviewText:
Firewatch is a great walking simulator. So great, in fact, that many gamers (including myself) at times wanted it to breach the walls and actually have more 'gaming' elements. This game really has the whole package; the artwork, music, voice acting, animation and atmosphere are all expertly crafted. The storyline is moving, to say the least.

The two major shortcomings in my mind are 1) the game is quite short (3 hours to 'finish' the story), and 2) there is little replay value. I will elaborate on both.

Although the twenty dollar price tag has become fairly standard for quality walking simulators (a la Gone Home or Dear Esther, among others), you only get a measly few hours of enjoyment out of it. The hours are top quality, though. After I was done, I kept asking myself why they couldn't have added in more achievements or side quests to fill out the time and add more incentive to replay. Sure, there are little 'easter eggs' of sorts littered throughout the map, but its certainly not enough for me to justify the large-ish price tag. Achievements would incentivize this; for example, I earned all the achievements in my first 3 hour playthrough.

Beyond that, everything is great. The story is wonderful and the experience is divine.  Just realize that this is a walking simulator proper. They may tease you with finding an axe, but there is no game here. Thats ok, but I think some of us wanted it to go to that next level.

It was most likely created to be a short experience on purpose, though. For example, while the map feels large and sandboxy at first, it quickly shows that it is quite limited. Once again, thats ok, but it merits being mentioned. The map is not as open-world as it may have us think. Its a series of 'tunnels'. Very beautiful tunnels.

Pros:
+Stunning artwork and scenery
+Truly great voice acting
+Outstanding story-telling
+Music is excellent
+Its short, but what is there is powerful

Cons:
-Its short, with a fairly steep price-tag (albeit par for the genre)
-I wanted more 'game', but thats like asking for more guns in Minecraft (hey devs take that as a compliment, because you really made something wonderful that could go in any direction)
-The map really needs more life added. I didn't see a single bug-swarm for example. I could go on and on about this, but you get the idea.

Walking simulator fans really need to play this for the experience. Even with only 3 hours of play time at this moment, I don't regret a single dollar spent.

reviewText:
WARNING!! THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS ON LATE POINTS IN THE GAME'S STORY!!


This game can one thing really good. And that is building atmosphere. From the intro to right before the ending you go through a lot of feelings.
Sadness, Comfort, Happyness (kind of), Anxious, Feeling of Dread, VERY ANXIOUS, Sadness.

But after these 3 hours it took me to complete the game I felt a sour aftertaste in my mouth. The story is nice, especially how it ramps up early - mid game, but to the ending it just falls short. There is no really big twist (there is a twist it isn't just that great though), no great secret. One plotline just blatantly ends & leaves you dissapointed.
I won't talk much about the gameplay, but I expected a bit more from the trailers.

If you want a very atmospheric game great dialogue then buy it for 5-10 €/$ when you can. It's not really worth the 20 original price.

A game with great potential, that just missed it.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OdOcgxJMNvU

Unfortunatly, Firewatch is the prime example of a story-driven game that really started to build up during development, only for them to realise that there was no way to make the specifically threated story any more interesting than it could have been in a different medium, such as a movie or a book.

This accounts for both the story itself and the gameplay. Easily summarised: Flat, boring and a complete waste of high-quality resources with potential gone to the trashbin.

PRO's:

- Excellent graphics
- Superb voice-acting
- Engaging story for the first hour

CON's:

- Downright boring gameplay. Nothing to do, except to interact with hike objects that might as well have been automated
- Illusion of free choice and liberty: It's all linear, nothing turns out different and you will meet dead ends all the time.
- Emotionless ending that completely destroys everything you listened or walked for around.
- Pricey for its length (just a little tad, it's not a heavy con IMO, we've just been lied to).

I cannot recommend it, especially for story-driven gamers. Reviewers keep praising the story and saying that ESPECIALLY story will drive you, but it's quite the other way around.

reviewText:
I rarely buy games right away and heard this game was extremely good/hyped.

I didn't know what to expect with the gameplay. One would expect there would be some sort of combat, or AT LEAST puzzle solving, item finding, etc.. etc.. There's nothing. You press space sometimes or use your walkie-talkie, that's it... There is literally nothing to figure out, you're told exactly where to go at all times. All you need to do is use your compass and look at your map.

I beat the game in 3.5 hours because I was exploring dead-end paths (the game is extremely lineer but trys to hide it by making convulted pathways you get stuck in). There are no collectables, there is nothing to discover or explore outside of the main quest. Had I known the game was like this, I probably could have beat it under 2.5 hours no problem.

The story is actually not good, and has very little pay off, not to mention extremely unplausable.

I would not pay more than $10 for this game, even that is kind of a stretch.

reviewText: This game is fantastic. It holds your attention and doesn't let go until it's over. It looks stunning and plays extremely well, not to mention the witty banter between the characters. It's a short game, but it didn't need to be any longer. Its the kind of game where you should set aside a few hours, sit down and play the whole thing from start to finish. I'm at the point now where my only disappointment is that I'll never be able to play it again for the very first time. It's worth the money for me because for a few hours I was sucked into the story, the likable characters and perfectly paced gameplay. In all honesty I don't have anything bad to say. If you feel like escaping reality for just a little while, just buy the game. You won't regret it one bit.

reviewText: Unfortunately I'm giving this game a thumbs down, when really in many ways it does derserve a thumbs up.\nHowever, like many other players I feel as if there was no pay off with it being so narratively driven. As the story builds and the plot thickens my overactive imagination took so many different courses as to what my fate would be. I suppose this is a spoiler (of sorts) so look away, but I really thought I would be completely abandoned to fend for myself at some point in the game. Kind like a survial segement of the game. Going incognito to protect myself and figure out the mystery. Collecting all those notes, taking all those photos, learning more and more about the plot and being unsure of whether to trust Delilah....it all seemed to be going somewhere. It's really such a shame for me because the voice acting is brilliant, the visuals stunning and it really does have so much potential. Ultimately this game felt more like a demo for me.

reviewText:
Ok, 1st thing to notice in the game to those using Laptops with Dual Graphics or PC with Dual Graphics or anyone using it, you need to force intergrate the game to run on NVIDIA and not on Intel. Thus the reason people will get some weird frames.

Now for the game. Its beautiful not just the graphic but the music, the ambience, the atmostphere and the story itself is......Ok not going to spoil but the opening intro of the game is so DARK and SAD!!! T^T Like literally. My heart ache for what happen. You get to choose 2 decision how you life story is. Like a Visual Novel intro but in a beautiful sequence yet sad tale.If I were to tell you how the game looks like and acts like, imagine Life is Strange combine with The Long Dark and Stanley Parable. In a very good way because of how it shows and opens up itself. During the day and night.
There is a lot of humor to go around and it gets very interactive and immersive when you explore everything. Like picking up and Pine cone and examining it and I'm like Damn this Pine cone looks Beautiful" and other silly things to go around which is fun.
In the game you also get to talk quite a lot of everything with Delilah and the way how both character humor each other is very quite amusing yet adorable until you try to remember the Intro which is sad yet still adorable and yet....T^T Man this game brings out the feels.

So is it worth your money? Yes if you want it for the Story and Interactive it has to offer."

reviewText:
I enjoyed the 3 hours it took to finish Firewatch. But I have a deep well of dissatisfaction concerning its single unchanging plotline. Let's be frank here, there are indications there was more to the story and the developers copped out. Sold the story and real effort down the river for a game that barely passes the refund playtime mark.

**Spoilers ahead**

The story was alright for what it was, it had some very interesting twists, but it should have been more. The evidence for this is the fenced off area and Ned supposedly set up this whole conspiracy social experiment thing... to what? scare them away from finding his son's body? But he treks all this chain fence and super expensive radio tower equipment himself? That he buys weird tracking devices and leaves them in a way that leads to two lost packs with the keys to the cave he stole 3 years ago?

All of that. That's not realistic. His actions are what set Hank on the trail to find the kid's body in the first place. If Ned had kept the cave keys on him... or not carried his clipboard of notes away from the ham radio setup he used to eavesdrop... or setup a campsite with tracking devices that you leave transponders for with your super important backpacks. WTF is this developer doing that he thinks I believe all these objects and assets were not part of some part of the story that got scrapped?

Hey ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, if you are reading this you could have done so much more with this game and you know it. I hope you feel like ♥♥♥♥ about its wasted potential, it's OBVIOUS wasted potential.

The best thing you could have done was at least had a twist at the end. D's tower could have been obviously someone else's tower. You could ask they guy on the chopper where she went and he could have said some other person's name that worked there. Or you could have had a dinosaur fossil in the cave that ned discovered and a backstory about how he was trying to cope with not wanting to get or famous from leading people to his son's body.

You heavily implied the tracking devices and observation material could suggest tracking bigfoot in a few ways. That would have been cheesy and far fetched, but anything is better than this half ♥♥♥♥♥ attempt to cover up your laziness.

reviewText: It is a little on the short-sideIfinished it in about three hours. I enjoyed the story, but the ending was meh. You had spent the whole game conversing with a character. You created a bond depeneding on how you played, but at the end it was just thrown up in the air. I am disappointed with the ending. They wrap up the mystery story which was pretty interesting for the most part. It was well written, but it's just the fact that you never meet Delilah. I wish the game had some short of after credit scene that gave closure to Henry and Delilah's relationship, or what paths they both took. In summary the game is a very good game. It is well written. It has  a great art style, but I cannot stress how much of a letdown the ending is. This game deserves a rating of 5/10. It would get a 9/10 if the story had more closure.

reviewText:
The reason I am not recommending is the length/price ratio. My main gripe is the length of the game - this is a GOOD game, but way too short for the price tag. Took me 4.9 hours to complete. Wait for this in a sale.

I waited over a year for this game to come out, and then I finish it in one short sitting. was hoping there would be some more to it!

+ Great story, great visuals (well done Olly Moss)
+ Great voice acting

- Wayyy too short though (5 hours for me, and I took my time and explored)
- Felt there was too little interaction with the things you can pick up. There's no real reason to collect the things you find, but the game lets you keep certain things and not others, for no particular reason. Nothing really comes in useful, or lets you store it in your tower, or do anything with it at all.
- It can be a little glitchy walking around and getting stuck on things.
- Little to no replay value.

Ending is love/hate with everyone it seems, but I thought the ending was good.

reviewText:
I was among those who really wanted to like this game. And that's not to say that there aren't some great aspects. The atmosphere and art is fantastic, the interactions with Delilah are fun, and there's a few moments of genuine tension...

But I agree with many other reviewers here that it's just another (very pretty) on the rails walking sim with no replay value other than looking at the nice scenery, a story that sputters out like a dying balloon at its end, and it very clearly depends on the 'wandering around lost' factor to pad out its gameplay time to make up for a short and honestly rather lackluster plot. On one of your MANY trips that send you from one ♥♥♥-end of the map to the other, I found myself repeatedly thinking 'Boy, they're really trying to make sure you go over that two hour limit, aren't they?'

I like some aspects of Firewatch, but I can't recommend it to anyone at this price. Get it on sale.

reviewText:
This game is great, really great, and I had much fun playing it.
I like the art style, the storytelling is compelling, and the story itself is good. The audio is good, and the game is very immersive and makes you feel like you are actually out there.

But, and this a a great but, the game has *zero* replay value. once you know the story, there is no reason to ever touch the game again. And the stry is way too short. I spen less then 4h completing it. Thats at least 5€/h gameplay. That is significantly more expensive then going to the cinema. If you compare that with similar priced games which offer dozens or hundreds of hours of gameplay,, then it is simply way overpriced for the content is actually has to offer.

I'd not recommend buying it to anyone. You can get more fun per buck elsewhere.


tl:dr; Good idea, nice done, just not enough content to be worth it.

/edit: I actually think the content of the game is designed to last just about 2h so that you are still having fun when the refund time runs out, but it ends shortly after that.

reviewText:
Finished on launch day. Too short. Lovely atmosphere. Great characters. Amazing art style. Disappointing ending. Overall, 6/10. Worth a playthough but get it on sale.
One massive plothole. Spoilers below, don't keep reading if you don't wanna know. Spoilers. SPOILERS. STOP IT.

NOPE.
STOP.

Okay ready?
GO
When you find the tent in the fenced-off area there are files in there with Henry and Delilah's personal information on there... But the site which the tent is on is run by a university, you can find notes in the tent and surrounding area talking about the uni. They have nothing to do with the guy who's kid died. So why were the people on the site monitoring Henry's conversations with Delilah?? As a friend pointed out, it could be to leave room for a sequel, but the characters storylines have already wrapped up; they have no reason to return to the forest. And they both seemed oblivious to the fact that there were two parties monitoring them in the woods.

reviewText:
The trailer makes you feel you'll live the daily adventures of a Forest Reserve Lookout. You'll not. There are no dangers, no challenges, no wildlife. This is a walking simulator, pure and simple. The story goes on as you walk and barely interact with the environment using clunky keyboard controls.

The beginning atmosphere is perfect, graphics are awesome, the dialogs are very well acted, but all the story buildup archs and expectations turn out to be absolutely pointless in the end. They lead to nothing. Also, the story is really simple, and according to the reviews I've read, It doesn't matter which dialog options you choose because there are no story branches. I can't be bothered to sluggishly walk/run through the same environments back and forth just to listen to a set of slightly different dialogs.

I beat this in 5 hours, but I don't care if a game is short, as long as it makes up for it in other respects. This doesn't.

reviewText:
So I wanted to recommend this game. But I cant. So let me break this down.

Pros
Gorgeous world.
Witty conversations.
A mystery for you to solve.

Cons
It's not as open world as it looks.
Characters do not really develop past the first 10 minutes of the game.
the mystery solves itself by the end if you don't solve it yourself.
Builds up really well, in fact so well I was ready for an epic ending, but that didn't happen.

This game had a lot of potential, had the ending been a satisfying one it would probably cause an uproar the same way Life Is Strange did.

TL;DR
the story of this game is someone making a house of playing cards so large that its about to beat the world record, only to be completely destroyed before the final card is placed.
