reviewText:
One of the best interactive story games I've ever played. The gameplay mainly consists of walking around looking for stuff, so don't expect any skill-based gameplay, but obviously it's not about that. Still, it's enjoyable all the same, thanks to the incredibly beautiful environments. Seriously, the art direction in this game is wonderful.

The story is told mainly through radio conversations with Delilah, another watcher. The voice acting and dialogue is superb, it's a real treat to listen to (and you very frequently get varied options for responses), and the story itself is really gripping. It's full of mystery and it feels like you have personal stakes in the events, nothing like those certain other games where all you do is plod around some dump and listen to recordings. The fact that the game makes you feel like you're solving something, without actually having any puzzles in it, is a testament to the writing quality. Sure, the story as a whole has issues and doesn't quite end as satisfyingly as one might want, but it more than makes up for it in the minutiae of how it's told.

The story takes about 5-6 hours (if you try to take in the game a bit rather than trying to speedrun it...), really well paced so that it neither outstays its welcome nor gives you too little time. By the end, you'll be intimately familiar with both the surroundings and Delilah.

reviewText:
Deep in the evening of the Wyoming wilderness, a burly pair of arms pushes an overhanging branch aside and claps eyes on the towering lookout post of Two Forks. You're looking through the eyes of Henry: wearily middle-aged and about to begin a summer stint as a firewatch ranger in a national park. Your boss, Delilah, introduces herself over the handheld radio. She is, to put it politely, an oddball; sarcastically intrusive but good-humoured and well meaning. Your relationship with her will become one of the most engrossing ever mapped out in gaming to date.

To state what might not be so obvious to some, yes, Firewatch can't claim to be much outside of a walking simulator for the most part. It's far bigger than most, rewards extensive exploration and you won't be able to experience every path if you just rush from objective to objective. There won't be any gunfights or QTEs to mash your way through. You are largely just holding a series of conversations with a disembodied voice on the other side of the radio.

That really makes what Firewatch accomplishes all the more impressive. It manages to conjure moments of hilarity, poignancy and skin-crawling intensity through little more than some hazy silhouettes, discarded camping equipment and an unbelievably well written and award-worthy acted script.

The ending's a bit soggy, be warned, but if you're somebody like me who's forever bemoaning the state of dialogue, voice acting and story pacing in gaming, prepare to be astonished.

I covered the first couple of chapters a few days ago in the preview copy. Feel free to check them out.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ROXS-K5n-eo
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eVUV9g5E3eg

reviewText:
There are other reviews that say it better, and go into deeper detail, but I find myself a bit too deflated to dwell on it too much.  When I saw previews for this game months ago, I kept it on my radar because it looked FANTASTIC.  The premise of a story-drive narrative in a gorgeous world really drew me in.  And it did deliver, on some parts.  I think the game looks amazing, though frame hiccups were prevelant and slightly annoying, and the voice acting between Hank and Delilah was top-notch, with great witty dialogue.  However there's not really much dialogue, not much of anything at all to be frank.  There are a few cute diversions, such as digging through ranger bins or finding a turtle or a burned shack ( which literally nothing is said about...no back story, no point at all from what I could tell )...but by the end, all these little nuances that I had been filing away for the end to see how they measured up instead began to give me a stark, depressing realization...they had no point whatsoever.

What should have been factoids that added to the overall story instead, at the end of my 3.5 hour journey ( I paused and took an hour for dinner ), felt like just enough added weight to hold me over the 2-hour refund limit.  No, I'm not being overly dramatic...I honestly think most of the extras in this game are just there to make sure you cannot get your money back.  The story climaxes in a very oddball, unoriginal way with a paltry plot point and an abysmal ending that just sorta...happens and leaves you there with nothing to show for it.  I paid 20 dollars for a 3.5 hour game that gave me nothing in return, not even a good wrap-up of the meager story I had invested in.

So no, I would not recommend this game at all.  You can literally go onto youtube and watch a full playthrough of it that ends at somewhere short of the 3-hour mark and get all the story, all the ambiance, and miss absolutely NOTHING in the process except a 20 dollar bill...I hate sounding petty, but I am reporting this to Steam and petitioning for a refund.

reviewText:
Imagine life as a secluded fire lookout in a national forrest. There is nothing around you for miles, except nature and gently-cut trails. Your job is simply to identify, observe, and track wildfires as they move through the area. Sounds pretty mundane, right?

Well, you're not wrong. There isn't much action aside from the occasional rock-climbing. That said, this game isn't about action. It's all about the story.

Firewatch is an interactive story, more than a traditional game. Thankfully, this is Firewatch's strength. It is well-written, and the voice-acting is excellent. There are times when you can get absorbed with taking in the scenery, and others where the scenery is blurring by as Firewatch dials up the tension. Even the casual controls help keep your mind off what your hands are doing, and focussed on what you're experiencing.

I've seen a lot of complaints that it's short (I finished in just under 5 hours), but there's no point to dragging it out. The narative is what is presented, not the mechanics. Would I say it's a fun game?" Maybe not. But it's definitely an enjoyable experience

reviewText:
Originally I gave this game a positive review, however I feel I originally rated the game a positive to try and justify the price I paid... This game isn't worth the asking price right now; you'd be better watching it on YouTube. Firewatch doesn't have any real gameplay elements; it is as many would say a walking simulator; however you don't play a game like this for the gameplay, you play a game like this for the story; this is one of the games' strong points and also its weakest... This games' story is very interesting; the execution is perfect and combined with the isolated setting it quickly pulls you into the story and gets you immersed into the story, around half-way through the game is when stuff gets really interesting and will really hook you in... The ending however is very disappointing; now there might be some alternate ending but after reading other forum posts and watching others it appears there is only one. There is all this build-up for nothing...

The voice acting is excellent; it's one of those games where I wanted to hear every piece of dialogue just because every scenario was done so well; both characters feel natural - The voice acting doesn't feel forced, cheap or cheesy. It can be witty, serious or depressing depending on what you choose in-game. It should be noted what you choose in no way affects what actually happens in the game, you will just get different dialogue - All outcomes are the exact same, unless there is a secret ending but as I said there probably isn't.

A lot of people complain this game is quite short and I can see why; many users are reporting 2-4 hours (which seems to be the average) - It took me 4 hours, mainly because the map in this game is so annoying to use and navigate with, I got lost all the time. The world itself has many different routes, shortcuts and areas that can only be accessed certain ways... Combined with the awfully confusing map which sometimes just seems to change at random this means it can take 10-20 minutes just to find a certain area or navigate back to your tower. This only added frustration to my playthrough.

I like the voice acting, and the story did show promise but I cannot recommend anyone to pick this game up right now - Watch it on YouTube or wait for it go get really cheap in a sale; if a friend has it ask for a family share but it simply isn't worth the asking price - Especially considering most will beat it in 2-4 hours (speedrun record is currently 1 hour) and there isn't any replay value; not unless someone does find some secret ending or extra story stuff comes out.

reviewText:
[Mostly spoiler-free review]

I know that Firewatch doesn't have a bear in it.

Well, probably.

Well, maybe.

I trust that Firewatch doesn't have a bear in it. I trust this because I don't feel I've been effectively equipped to deal with a bear. And I trust this because I know that modeling and animating and programming a bear is a lot of work, and if Campo Santo had put a bear in Firewatch then there would probably be a bear in Firewatch's trailers.

But an hour ago, my offscreen boss Delilah asked me to keep an eye out for bear tracks in the area, and now I'm inching through a cave, terrified that I'm about to come face to face with a horrible grizzled grizzly.

---

Firewatch is a tricky game to describe. It's not exactly a Gone Home, not exactly a The Walking Dead, and not exactly a Far Cry 2. But all those elements are in its DNA, and they combine to create something intriguing, memorable, and extraordinary.

Don't listen to anyone who says Firewatch is a walking simulator. If anything, I'd call it a talking simulator. The core mechanic—communication with an unseen colleague via a handheld radio—functions something like a combination of The Walking Dead's timed conversations and Dishonored's Heart, and serves not only to advance the plot but also to provide color and humor and a degree of player expressivity.

I won't say much about the plot here, as it is hard to do so without treading into spoiler territory. It's a mystery story, and a story about the relationship between a man and a woman. In both regards, the worldbuilding is exceptional: the principal characters play off each other well, and there is a real tension while the mystery is sustained. The worst I can say about Firewatch is that I wish I could spend longer in this remote part of Wyoming. The first half of the game feels like the greatest TV pilot in years, and the second half is like fast-forwarding to the series finale.

---

I loved everything about Firewatch. The gorgeous art, the stellar voice acting, the beautiful yet disquieting soundtrack. Highly recommended to anyone who enjoys narrative-driven games.

Just watch out for that bear.

[Disclosure: I used to work with one of Campo Santo's developers and have hung out with a lot of the team at industry events.]

reviewText:
No spoilers.

I have been excited for this game ever since it was announced.
Unfortunately I have ended up personally a bit disappointed, and for the amount of gameplay I would recommend waiting for it to go on sale.

The positives:
The voice acting is great, you really do feel connected to the characters.
There are a few things scattered around that build the story outside the main arc.
The music.
The opening is done beautifully.  Reminded me of Disney Pixar's UP.

However, I personally just don't believe there is enough substance.
The story builds up as you expect, but the second half let me down a fair bit.
The game looks nice, however it started to feel a little repetitive in the design a hour in.
I was hoping for some hero shots of scenary to be scattered around that would make you wow as the game is marketed for its exploration potential, I just didn't get that.

Lastly, I completed the game in 3 hours, and a good part of that was because it was just walking to and fro a lot of places.  This would be fine if there was more going on in the world, however it got a little tiresome as there was not much to discover apart from boxes scattered here and there.

I personally would expect this to be a $5 or $10 max game, and recommend waiting for the sales before taking on your new job as Firewatch.

reviewText:
Let me make this clear. The ending is paramount. It's purpose is to give meaning to the events that happened before it.

Firewatch's ending does not do that. It is without a doubt in my mind, the single worst ending to an otherwise enjoyable game I've ever seen.


But let's start out with the positive.

+This game is simply stunning. The art style and color palette are so fitting for a game like this.
+The dialogue is incredible. For a game that's only dialogue is between two different characters, it all feels fresh and real. There's also a suprising amount of choice within dialogue.
+What's equally incredible is the voice acting. Both Rich Sommer and Cissy Jones are fantastic and make you feel like Henry and Delilah are both real people really talking about real things.
+The game really kicks off early. You WILL begin to feel paranoid that something isn't quite right with what's happening around you.

And now onto the cons.

-A lot of your time will be spent backtracking. This isn't all bad considering that you're generally always talking with Delilah, but considering that the game is under 4 hours long, it's not really acceptable that about a third of that time is spent going through the same places.
-Gameplay is almost none existent. Yes I understand that this is a story based experience and I am completely fine with that. But it is worth noting that if you were expecting any gameplay that poses any form of a challenge, you will not find it here.
-I saw like 3 animals across 80 days in the woods. What?


Now onto the elephant in the room. The ending. No spoilers.

Well yes, I suppose this is technically a mystery game. But you don't really solve it. The suspense grows and grows until eventually you are just handed the answer of who dun it" with what is supposed to be an emotional gut punch. But all it really is
date: is a cop out. All the paranoia you felt for the last 3 hours just completely disapears and you realise how truly pointless the game is. It doesn't deliver upon the quality that it started out with in any form.\n\nWhere was the character development? What did the character learn about himself from his time in the woods with another woman? What happens next? The answer to all of these questions is left up to the player to decide. Which isn't a bad thing
recommended:
but doesn't at all play to the strengths of the game.


TLDR- An ending that doesn't live up to the quality set by everything before it.

4/10

"

reviewText:
Was looking forward to this game for a long, long time. Really wanted it to be good. And it is good, at certain things. The first hour or so of the game is wonderful, thanks to the chemistry between Henry and Delilah. It's some of the best writing and voice acting I've seen in a long time.

Then it turns into an episode of the X-Files, and all the chemistry between the two leads vanishes.

I'm not going to spoil what twists and turns the story takes. Instead, I'll point out that the story starts out great and ends up falling flat, largely because of two things:

1. The pacing. The game starts with a slow burn. You're learning about the two characters, about the world, and occasionally a weird thing here, a weird thing there. That's fine. Then, all of a sudden, there is an abrupt turn into crazytown. I felt like I was just starting to settle into the groove of Hank 'n Delilah, when all hell breaks loose. Suddenly Hank and Delilah are bemoaning [spoilery thing I won't mention] plaguing them ALL SUMMER LONG, and I'm like Wait
date: what? All summer? It was Day 2 of summer ten minutes ago. Then you jumped to Day 30 something
hoursPlayed: and now we're here." The game doesn't actually build a solid foundation between Hank and Delilah; it pulls the equivalent of "Two months later..." and expects that time to add weight to the proceedings. It doesn't. You can't just skip months of time and then have the characters say "Oh
voteText: all that time we've spent together" as if it means something. It doesn't.\n\n2. The quality of the writing. The first hour is phenomenal. Hank and Delilah have charmingly awkward conversations about their pasts

reviewText:
I wish I could recommend this game. The voice acting, the writing (for the most part), and the visuals are all great... but it left me disappointed. I enjoyed it right up until the end, even though I was expecting a bit more of an actual game. You basically just walk around and left click to advance the story, which is fine, I enjoyed Dear Esther after all (I'm just a little annoyed that Firewatch wasn't advertised to be what it actually is).

But that's where we reach Firewatch's biggest problem. For a completely story driven game, there is no payoff and no resolution of any kind. Everything is wrapped up in the last 10 minutes in a shockingly uninspired way. Considering how well done the writing was up until the end, it feels like the last half hour was heavily rushed causing the story to fall flat... it almost feels like an Episode 1".

This is one of those cases where a simple "Yes/No" review isn't really appropriate. I'd like a middle ground here. All I can really say is that I don't feel that I got my $18 out of this game. If more work was put into the ending scenario of this game
date: I'd likely be singing its praises... as it stands

reviewText:
[Mostly spoiler-free review]

I know that Firewatch doesn't have a bear in it.

Well, probably.

Well, maybe.

I trust that Firewatch doesn't have a bear in it. I trust this because I don't feel I've been effectively equipped to deal with a bear. And I trust this because I know that modeling and animating and programming a bear is a lot of work, and if Campo Santo had put a bear in Firewatch then there would probably be a bear in Firewatch's trailers.

But an hour ago, my offscreen boss Delilah asked me to keep an eye out for bear tracks in the area, and now I'm inching through a cave, terrified that I'm about to come face to face with a horrible grizzled grizzly.

---

Firewatch is a tricky game to describe. It's not exactly a Gone Home, not exactly a The Walking Dead, and not exactly a Far Cry 2. But all those elements are in its DNA, and they combine to create something intriguing, memorable, and extraordinary.

Don't listen to anyone who says Firewatch is a walking simulator. If anything, I'd call it a talking simulator. The core mechanic—communication with an unseen colleague via a handheld radio—functions something like a combination of The Walking Dead's timed conversations and Dishonored's Heart, and serves not only to advance the plot but also to provide color and humor and a degree of player expressivity.

I won't say much about the plot here, as it is hard to do so without treading into spoiler territory. It's a mystery story, and a story about the relationship between a man and a woman. In both regards, the worldbuilding is exceptional: the principal characters play off each other well, and there is a real tension while the mystery is sustained. The worst I can say about Firewatch is that I wish I could spend longer in this remote part of Wyoming. The first half of the game feels like the greatest TV pilot in years, and the second half is like fast-forwarding to the series finale.

---

I loved everything about Firewatch. The gorgeous art, the stellar voice acting, the beautiful yet disquieting soundtrack. Highly recommended to anyone who enjoys narrative-driven games.

Just watch out for that bear.

[Disclosure: I used to work with one of Campo Santo's developers and have hung out with a lot of the team at industry events.]

reviewText:
Walking Simulator 2016: Now with climbing, rappelling, and the prettiest environments you've ever seen.

It's just you, your tools, and your radio to your boss, alone in the Shoshone National Forest. Except when you're not alone.

Firewatch adds some menace and mystery to typical walking simulator fare and tries to make the Wyoming wilderness feel more real. Your UI is you literally holding up a map and compass; your dialogue requires you to hold radio buttons like you might in real life. It makes slight concessions to accessibility by adding text readouts of notes you'd otherwise have to squint at and giving a real-time you are here" marker on your map
recommended: Firewatch tries to eschew artificiality and really immerse you into the role. For the most part

reviewText:
An over-hyped and over-dramatized take on the walking simulator trend.

It baits you with beautiful graphics, isolation/redemption plot, or forest hiking and navigation mechanics. Well, out of these... yes, the graphics are quite pretty stylized, that's it. It has very little to do with mountains or even fire-watching. The fire-watchers in this game don't use hatchets, binoculars, or compass, and they come to mountains for entertainment and use the same language they talked in their big city bars... The story told by Firewatch hasn't enriched the world much, either (but has hooks for you such as mentally ill loved ones or text-based intro).

Eventually the whole thing falls flat with inconsistent, silly story and lack of both research and polish. Ultimately it is all about nice packaging and smart marketing (or should I say luring - how to name speaking to such low fantasies as phone sex, err, adult conversations about adult things"?). Most games are
recommended: but then - they don't aspire to be art. Firewatch explicitly does. If we want games to be treated as art
hoursPlayed: let's review them as art. Hence Firewatch

reviewText:
So when i saw Firewatch at E3 2015 i was very excited it was presenting itself to be like a mystery game with maybe a bit of wilderness simulation on the side, it seemed like it was going to be very good I had high hopes.  When I did finally load into the game I was very pleased as expected I enjoyed the characters the story was exciting and keeping me on edge it was esspecially nice to see that my choices made an impact on the way the characters interacted.  Unfortunatly this game goes by very fast and I was on the final level with pretty much no answers to any of the storylines i had been told, Then the game just dropped answers on me left and right most of them very obviously rushed or just there to tie up loose ends the game never came up with a good ending for.  So unfortunatly I can't reccomend this game to anyone it is a game that could have done with a much longer time to tell its story, but it's potential was stifled by a play time that was half of what it should have been

reviewText:
Firewatch is a single player, first-person walking simulator. You play as a man named Henry, who due to unexpected circumstances finds himself taking a job as a fire lookout in the Wyoming wilderness.

While I am recommending this game, before you make the decision to purchase or not please keep in mind that it's very short. It took me 4.5 hours to complete - half an hour longer than most people are reporting. It’s worth playing, but I'd wait and get it at a discount unless you have cash to spare.

Firewatch is an interactive story. You progress by exploring the environment and using a handheld radio to communicate. How you choose to respond to dialogue effects how the person on the other end of the radio responds to you in return.

A lot of love went into this game and it shows. They did a very good job of making everything in a particular setting (music, lighting, background, ambient noise) work towards the mood and general theme of the overarching story. The graphics are outstanding. The voice acting is superb and the dialogue is, in my opinion, probably the strongest part of the game. After spending time on various Telltale products I particularly like the way the controls are set up and the fact that you can save at any point while playing.

The overarching plot isn’t perfect - I’m still not sure how I feel about the twist, but after some consideration I think it fits with what the game was going for. The writing works hard to make you feel increasingly isolated and paranoid while playing, but still manages to keep the beauty of the environment and being out in the wild at the forefront of the story. It feels like walking through a strange, hard section of someones life. The end wasn’t what I was expecting, but I think maybe that’s the point.

reviewText:
Firewatch is a game with fantastic story telling, dialogue and a beautiful world.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=83GlQsZWrXQ&feature=youtu.be
The main attraction about the game is the great writing. The characters feel very real, and that's complimented by the good voice acting.
Your job in the forest is to make sure everything is calm, and safe.
At times in the game, you will be left to yourself. You can explore the gorgeous forest, find stashes of stuff, climb walls and look at creatures. To keep track of where you're going, you use a map and compass. It's intuitive and fun to use.

You also have a walkie talkie with which you communicate with your colleague. You may choose how to respond to her, which many times includes not answering at all. The dialogue really immerses you, as choices you make alter different things.

As you explore the forest, you can even bring up random topics with her. If you look at a beautiful vista, you might have the choice to compliment the land, or make a smart-♥♥♥ remark about how there's nothing interesting here. Both mian characters have a sense of humour, which makes it fun to hear the conversations.

The game has quite a lot more interesting stuff to it that is best discovered for yourself.
I personally am loving the journey so far, and can't wait to finish it.

reviewText:
First off, I really, REALLY, enjoy these types of games. The exploration aspect mixed with mystery in the middle is a fun concept and there was a point halfway through the game that made me feel like I had to keep going to find out what would happen next. However, the problem is halfway through the game was 2 hours. Despite the good visuals, voice acting and intrigue, the game is just far too short to recommend. If it was a couple of hours longer it would be worth the $20 but it takes barely half the amount of time to beat than what the developer said it would take (5-6 hours).

TLDR:
Great visuals, style, voiceovers, and feel. But there just isn't enough content.

reviewText: First of all I'd like to thank Campo Santo and Panic for this game I waited for so long. Now I'm happier than before, because this stunningly beautiful piece of art is just brilliant. It has everything I like so much about games: touching story, unusual setting, beautiful graphics, calming gameplay and - it was a surprise for me - innovative controls (radio, looking at objects and of course the map). I feel like every piece of puzzle is created with love and patience. This is the place where you can just go and explore territory or watch animals in the woods. Or go doing tasks, that's also very interesting. I never thought Firewatch to become one of my favorite games ever so fast. Thanks a lot, xoxo

reviewText:
PROS
+Great graphics
+Brilliant voice acting
+Can get a pet turtle

CONS
-Predictable twists
-80% of the game is just the gameplay mechanics, and the gameplay is just alright
-The big map is actually very restrictive (4 canyons with some small open areas where paths split)
-Disappointing and abrupt ending
-Developers claimed '6-8 hours of story minimum', 3-4 hours in reality
-Dialogue provides the illusion of choices that will stick but in reality there is one ending (There is also an ending if you don't do 'the thing' at the end but it's a very minor change and was probably only made by the devs as a side thing)
-Game is linear
-The 'funny' bits you see in the trailers are the only funny bits
-Ending makes no sense and isn't well explained
-You will end up paying around £3.75/$5 per hour of gameplay (assuming you spend 4 hours on it).
-Story seems rushed
-No replay value since there is only one ending
Overall, the game was very over-hyped, on the surface, this game seems amazing, but once you've gotten more than 2 hours in, you realize that there is little more than climbing up and down stones and being prompted to radio in everything. I would not recommend you buy this game, unless it is well discounted during a sale.

reviewText:
False advertising. This game allows you to watch MUCH more than just fires. For instance, I watched:

FireWORKS. (These are NOT fires.)
Water. (Basically the OPPOSITE of fire.)
Naked teenagers. (HOT, yes. FIRE, no.)
The unfolding of a compelling character driven drama. (Not a fire.)
A fire. (Okay, to be fair, this was indeed a fire.)
Raccoon.

So, out of six things, only one of those is fire. Shameful. They should have called this game Fire and Not Fire Watch.

Still a good game, though. I like how you wear shorts.

reviewText:
Firewatch is a beautiful atmospheric adventure that has some mystery elements, and plays like a walking simulator with amazing dialog.

Check out my Quick Game Review here: https://youtu.be/dLNAgIH9UM4
In Firewatch, you play as Henry, and you are looking for an isolated escape from your regular life. You spend a lot of time hiking, and climbing through the terrain to complete your objectives. You can explore different areas, and interact with different objects. With just your backpack and a few items, you are practically alone in nature, and the only other person you have to talk with is on the other end of a walkie-talkie. While talking on the walkie-talkie, you will have a finite time to reply, and sometimes have different choices in dialog selection. Different dialog selections prompt different responses, but none of which will impact the outcome of the game.

The story is a linear. The dialog and circumstances throughout the game are very realistic and believable. There are some mysteries in the story as well, and it added a nice touch on the game overall.

Pros:the controls are fully customizable, and the game has full controller support
immersive and beautiful graphics - nature is absolutely stunning, and everything feels so alive with the grass and trees moving and swaying in the wind
background music, and ambience sounds of nature are really well done
believable characters with dialog and voice acting that are incredible
Cons:the story is too short for the price tag
the ending was done well, but I have mixed feelings about how it ended (it was what I expected would happen, but not what I wanted to see happen)
The game took me just under 4 hours to complete. After I finished it, I went back and played it again to experience the different dialog choices, but other than hearing a few new lines here and there, there wasn’t any other reason to replay it.

I really liked the game, and I would definitely recommend it to anyone who enjoys an immersive experience with really great voice dialog. It was a wonderful game, but the price is too high for how short it is, so I would advise picking it up at a sale price.

reviewText:
This game was fun but not worth the full 20 dollar pricetag. It had good visuals and voice acting and a very interesting story Until the end. The story leads you up to a big reveal at the end and then the reveal is kind of bland and like EH. They could have done much more interesting things with the ending. The ending is always the same. Also, You CANT effect the environment. SO, it has a good story but if you could seriously just read about what happens in the story and not even play the game and get the same thing out of it besides the voice acting and nice environment.

You walk to a location, you talk on your radio or listen to your radio or find some object. Thats it.
SOOOO, The game was fun and beautiful but only worth about 10$ not 20$ because of the short playtime and lack of content

reviewText:
There many superb things there are about Firewatch, sadly the bad wins out.  The voice acting is excellent depending on how you proceed through the story is excellent (to a point).  Although there is little in the way of music, when music was present it set the tone quite well.

Firewatch is as much about the story as its about a conversation between two people.  If this happened to be either cheaper or longer or both I could recommend it however, Firewatch is neither of these things!  I will say this it does (sort of) live up to the trailer videos the humour is the almost all the way through.  If you allow yourself to be drawn in by the story you will have a better experience.  There was only one point in the story where there was a major failure.

Final thought on Firewatch is if you really want it and you like the trailer, do yourself a major favour don't go search of any spoilers and wait for a steam sale.

reviewText:
Pro's:
Clean Vibrant Art Style
Believable Characters
Great Voice Acting
Initial plot is compelling
Manages to be unnvering and tension filled without resorting to jump-scares or load noises.
Good soundtrack (not a lot of music but it is good nonetheless and used sparingly)
The camera is a good feature and being able to print off the pictures you take in game is nice.

Con's:
Only around 2-3 hours for the standard playthrough (Could be lessened to about 1 1/2 hours on a second playthough)
Not an true open world game.
Map is almost deceptivaly small.
Nothing to do apart from the main objective.
Illusion of choice within the dialogue system. Ultimately you get the same backstory with the same ending no matter how much of the dialogue you change.
Compelling plot goes no-where in the final act (Don't set your expectations too high).
Ending leaves more questions than answers.
They clearly never learnt their fire safety from Welphant the Fire and Safety Elephant.

7.5/10

Might be worth at a reduced price. Read up on the game and judge for yourself wether you are into the idea. I would read a few spoiler free reviews and if this sounds intresting then wait for a Steam Sale.

reviewText:
Pros:

- Voice acting is great.
- The game looks beautiful at times.
- Great controller configuration. (Glad the Steam Controller got it's own button layout.)
- The atmosphere is great.

Cons:

- Very short. Took me about 2-3 hours to beat the game, the rest was for cards.

- The ending ruined the story for me.
- Lots of backtracking, the map seems big, but is actually very small.
- Decisions don't change much. The ending from what I've heard is the same no matter what choices you made.

Conclusion:

6/10 - I can't recommend this game at $20. The start of the game showed promise, but in the end the story seemed rushed and the ending was pretty bad. I'd suggest waiting for the game to drop to $5 to $10 before even considering to purchase it.

reviewText:
Firewatch is a First-Person exploration story based game where you take a job looking over a Forest to watch out for fires. I won't say anything more about the story other than it is very well written and also very funny and charming with good character development. With a game thats basically all about story, thats really all you need for a recommendation. You'll know if this kind of game is for you or not

To those complaining about length, its a $20 exploration game. If you expected 15 hours out of this, you must not play this genre very often. You have to be okay with a few hour experience. I finished after 4.5 hours while doing moderate exploration and trying to get as much dialogue as I can. If you can't rationalize $20 for a game like this, by all means wait for a sale, but for a lot of people including me, its already worth the 20 price tag for getting basically a longer, better written movie.

Some of the downsides, its a first person game without an FOV slider. Not sure why they left it out, but I did get a mild headache. Its possible it was because I played for almost 5 hours without stopping, but be wary. Also some people are experiencing performance issues and glitches. For me though, I only had a few minor graphical issues. Lasty, I'm not going to talk about the details, but some people have issues with the end of the game and its definitely hit or miss, either you might not like it. At first I wrote that I liked it in my initial review, but on recollection the ending is not great compared to the rest of the game. Definitely disappointed at the end.

Overall, FIrewatch is a great Exploration/story based experience thats worth a playthrough. Don't spoil yourself! Its a story worth playing through on your own

If you don't have strict $1-1 hour preferences:
Buy At Full Price
If you do:
Wait For A Sale

reviewText:
First and foremost: It's a very short game. Steam says I put in about 3 hours and I completed it. I didn't explore or anything since I was invested in the story but just beware that it is a short game. If you're interested but the price is too high then I suggest waiting for a sale before picking it up. If you're unsure then you should just wait for a sale to pick it up.

The game is fantastic though. I got really invested in the characters and story which is why I ran through it so quickly. The voice acting felt realistic to me and while the writing may have been a bit flat or subpar side characters, the relationship between Delilah and Henry (your character) feels realistic and fluid. There's banter and humor and emotion in every line and it feels like real people just having a conversation rather than some people in a studio reading off a script. It's what elevates this game from mediocre to fantastic for me.

The graphics are really stylized and pretty. It's got a cartoonish feel to it that looks great and keeps the forest you're wandering in feel colorful and alive. The lighting plays an important role because there are many moments right at sunset where the sun is shining through the trees and it just feels and looks majestic.

The audio is a good mix of ambience and music. When you're wandering through the forest you'll find that the only sounds you hear are the sounds of your footsteps and the wind. It's very quiet and lonely. When something dramatic is happening the music quietly comes in and becomes a part of the scene, creating emotion and driving you forward. I highly recommend buying the soundtrack because it's extremely good.

Without spoiling anything, the ending feels hollow. Not in that it's a poorly written ending or anything like that. Rather it makes you feel hollow, like this journey you've been on is coming to a close and it's not exactly the ending you wanted. It's not happy, it's not sad, it just is an ending. It's fitting and while it's not the most satisfying, it's the most fitting.

After all I've said praising this game there are some problems. Invisible walls and artificial barriers are prevalent throughout this game. Some of the barriers can only be cleared after you've progressed so far into the story, which is fine but still feels like the game is limiting your exploration abilities. By the time I could theoretically explore everywhere, I was far enough into the story that I didn't have the desire to explore anymore since I wanted to see how things ended. There were other small barriers that annoyed me. One example is a trail by the lake. I got lost and there's a literal wall of dirt and rocks that separates you from where you need to go. Instead of being able to climb over this mound (which was definitely possible mind you) I instead had to walk around it to end up on the other side. It's not major but it's annoying in a game that's about exploration.

There's also a lot of glitches and bugs in the game. Frequently I got caught on rocks and branches and things like that and had to back up and move around them like I was a car or something. I found a lot of seams in the world where they failed to properly connect them so I could see into the void below. I also saw a couple of rocks that had no bottoms. It's a lot of minor stuff like this.

Overall I enjoyed this game and plan to do another run through at some point to fully explore the environment. The presentation is spectacular and the main characters are realistic and engaging. The invisible walls and glitches take away from the overall experience but the glitches will be patched out.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Firewatch, a game based on dialogue and characters. Thank goodness, a story that players actually care about and become invested in for once (cough cough triple a titles). Firewatch is an experience that is unlike other games.Walking simulator? yes it most certaintly is but its the best walking simulator there is. The graphics are beautiful and change based on the rising action in the story. If your looking for a experience based on characters, dialogue, mystery, and STORY get this game.

However there are some turnoffs:
-Very short (3-4hours)
-A little pricey for the amount of content
-More animals (birds,more deer, bears, beavers, fish, etc.)
-Ending is anti-climatic and a bit abrupt
-You never get to see D (not really a turnoff but i wanted to at least see her)
If this game was double the amount it takes to finish with more side story style tasks, it would have been phenomenal. But still a incredible game none the less

reviewText:
While I cannot recommend this game because it feels deliberately extended to avoid the Steam Refund clause, it's not a terrible story. It has an interesting way of developing drama and the overall plot to create some strong tension. But the game is easily an hour too long and just drags on in parts. I wish I could request a refund for the three hours I put into the game but I can't, but on the flipside if the game had been much shorter I would've had a much greater experience.

Ways the game artificially expands the length:
-Certain days end abruptly, while some others carry out much longer for seeming no reason
-The controls are clunky and if you want to know where youre going and have the map out you cannot run at the same time
-There are arbitrary restrictions on where you can and cannot run
-The invisible walls dictate a finite amount of paths you may or may not take through levels

All in all the narrative is very interesting, but the length of the game makes me wish I had requested a refund. If the game was shorter I would've enjoyed it much more.

Edit: It should be noted that every exciting moment of the video game is literally in the trailers.

reviewText:
Just completed Firewatch and i may say from what i have read and heard from the game its not really what i expected, but still a very good game.

At some moments throughout it felt more like a short movie with interactions now and then and being able to control your character. At time didnt understand the story of the game and dont really want to explain much but really of your characters wife having alzheimers after being with her for a few years and then you moving away to a new job that bascially stops forrest fires but also becomes strange within the process and talking to Delilah more or less all the time about life and why you came here and her life.

But when in game it is absolutely stunning and very well graphically made and love having to decide on what to say to  Delilah through the walkie-talkie and the choices to say to her. Love the way the game also uses the map, shows that you actually have to keep looking to find where you need to go and follow the correct route rather than fast traveling or making waypoints and following them.

Only thing I found dissappointing was the lengh of the game as a whole, i thought it would of been longer and liked how it planned out by day by day until it got to around the third or fourth day then started jumping greatly to Day 15 then Day 50 and so on until you relised he was there for that long and knowing that something will happen or it will keep going.

All and all though love the screenshots that i ahve captured from the game and i wouldnt say it was replayable again unless they brought out a second one to add on from what happened at the end.

overall...

7.5/10

reviewText:
So here's my review of Firewatch: it's a pretty damn good game. Started it last night and finished it in about 5 hours. It's relatively shorter than most games in that aspect but it's only $20 so it's a pretty reasonable price for the content. At the same time it doesn't overstay its welcome with sidequests, things to collect, or achievements. You play as Henry, a fire watcher employed at a national park in Wyoming. You have little to no physical human interaction as you spend the entire game talking over a handheld radio to your fellow firewatcher, Delilah, who is stationed on the other side of the park. This, in my opinion, is one of the best things about the game because it allows the player to emotionally connect with the two main characters without knowing anything but the sound of their voices. It tells its story in a quirky, down-to-earth narrative that has dialogue options making you feeling like you ARE your character. Seriously, the dialogue in this game feels so natural and unscripted that it's like I'm talking to one of my friends. The graphics are pretty decent for games these days but what really stands out is the color schemes. The oranges, yellows, and reds of the Wyoming landscape beautifully contrast the azure sky giving it a nice, warm feeling as you hike throughout the park. The game has a linear story and although the park is pretty large there's a lot of hiking between areas that will quickly become familiar, which is cool because it makes you feel like you've worked there a while. Even so, backtracking is never wasted since the story continues as long as you are headed the right way so hopefully you have a good sense of direction. I won't spoil any of the plot but as you progress, you find out that you're being watched by something or someone and things go south from there. Overall, the game is beautifully crafted for one so short and its simple controls and linear story make it an enjoyable experience. The only gripes I have are the occasional bugs (game crashing, getting stuck on terrain, etc.) and the mildly disappointing ending (maybe I was just expecting more closure). For all it's worth though, I give this game an 8/10. Bravo, Campo Santo!


EDIT:
Now, I did say that this was MY review and it's based off of what I thought. I've noticed a lot of the other reviews and comments all talking about how the game is way too short and isn't worth $20 for its length. However, ME PERSONALLY, I didn't mind paying that much for an enjoyable experience. Would I pay a full normal-release price of $60 for something like this? Hell no. Would YOU pay $20 for this game? That's up to you. I'm just here for a review, not to make you buy it. If you want to wait till it's on sale to pick it up, go for it! All I'm saying is that it's a good game and that's why i'm recommending it.
voteText: 45 of 85 people (53%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Beautiful, frightening, engaging. Those three words describe what this game is about. At the same time, so much of the game is uncomfortable, and it brings out real human emotions in us, as we interact with the dialogue. We only have a few choices at any given time, but the game will progress as you are more and more emotionally invested.

I would describe this as a first person interactive novel adventure. Normally, I am not into that sort of thing. But for the sake of live streaming on Twith, I picked this up. But I cannot describe how happy I am to have bought it. One of the best games I have played through and streamed on cast, ever. That is really saying something for me.

This game makes us question our sanity, our morals, and our empathy. As linear as it is, you still feel completely in control.

Immerse yourself, and get this game!

reviewText:
Welcome to your first day, FireWatch.
This is a game about sitting back in your comfortable chair on a free, cold day in front of your Computer and just relax.
The story, the atmosphere and especially the conversations make this game unique and special in its own way.
Let's put it this way: You had expectations, you play the game, you're overwhelmed and maybe a little sad at the same time. Depends on how attached you get.
I recommend to ONLY play this game if you're really into short story exploration games!

The dev's say the game takes 6h, it took me 4 with exploring almost everything. Put, I almost rushed it a bit towards the end because I had no free time.
But If I had another free day, I'd totally replay it. No questions. No regrets. Just, FireWatch.

The story is mostly what you will take it. Aside from the amazing looking terrain and the atmosphere that will change throughout the game. It adjusts itself to the story and it does so perfectly.
Henry does so too. Or, you do. You are Henry and you're just on a trip away from the reality you used to know, from your old life.
You'll meet" an amazing person and explore a huge terrain of wilderness and trees. Of course

A controlled burn of mid-life angst

The affliction of isolation, be it physical, ideological or - in the case of Firewatch - a heady blend of both, can be a powerful narrative crux if exploited properly. It's a readily recognizable concept; I'd wager that very few of us haven't felt the pang of true loneliness or social disconnect at least once in our lives, in any of their broadly varying and often soul-crushing forms.

It's a facet tapped into superbly by Campo Santo, who use the desolate, amber-waxed wild of the Wyoming countryside as a backdrop for their poignant reverie of disillusionment and human connection. So, of course, not complete isolation. As your proverbial lifeline, the disembodied but gregarious cadence of Delilah will greet you almost immediately, and the strikingly dynamic relationship that ensues should be the main draw card for any gamer with a taste for this budding strain of mature, melancholic storytelling.

You play as Henry. In the stark but finely-tuned opening 10 minutes, a series of text cards reveal that Henry's wife, Julia, has fallen victim to early onset alzheimers. After taking charge of her care for a number of years, Henry suddenly find himself alone and without responsibility when Julia's family steps in and request that Julia move back home to Australia with them. This brings Henry to where we meet him: Hiking to a lookout post to spend the accompanying summer surveying the surrounding Wyoming rainforest (dubbed 'Two Forks') for any potential fires or anomalies. A mundane job, maybe, if not for the perpetual presence of Delilah, your closest fellow lookout, filtered entirely through the 2-inch speaker of your CB radio. She's peppy, charming, sarcastic and utterly loveable. Over the course of the summer you'll develop a delicately grounded relationship with Delilah; refreshing is the lack of any pretentious understatement or gauche melodrama. These are two intelligent, mature-aged adults who interact and react accordingly, who's desires and motivations are clear, authentic and beautifully realised. Your conversations with 'D' segue seamlessly from light-hearted jives, to existential ponderings, from the quietly romantic, to the devastatingly candid, and everything in between.

Unfortunately it's juxtaposed with a slightly awkward murder-mystery sub-plot involving a father and son who disappeared hiking the surrounding area many years prior. It's engaging enough and, once fully revealed, not without poignancy. But it's staying power pales in comparison to any one of the most intimate moments you share with Delilah. For that, it feels like a somewhat convoluted artifice added for the purpose of propelling the core narrative but without actually enhancing it. I can understand Campo Santo's reticence to rely wholly on the wistful ruminations of two forty-somethings to hold our attention, but I honestly think it would have served Firewatch for the better.

Hindering subplots aside, the only other reservations I have about the game are ultimately trivial. I experienced a few occasional texture pop-in moments, but hardly enough to break immersion. One too many invisible walls make traversing the map far more frustrating then it needs to be and the faint, poorly illustrated map doesn't really help matters.  Also, Henry's character design is comically crude; his body resembles that of an ill-proportioned, morbidly obese toddler. It's slightly bizzare.

Any graphical shortcomings inflicted on your avatar is more than made up for by the radiant artistry of your surrounding environment. The Wyoming wilderness is filtered through a rich mosaic of reds, golds, greens and ambers; a brazen color wheel that veers dangersouly close to 'overdone' but thankfully never crosses that line. Trees, ravines, rivers, ponds, mountains, bluffs, and open fields pockmark every corner of the map and they're all stunningly crafted. But most importantly, they're cohesive. Two Forks feels like a natural, dynamic location; nothing seems over-designed or out of place. It's a truly hypnotising landscape to traipse through and it's ambience is only bolstered by the audio design, a simple but polished medley of melodic breezes, rustling leaves and Chris Remo's superlative, Gustavo Santaolalla-inspired soundtrack. Beautiful.

But for all the technical flare, it's Henry and Delilah that stand above all else. The passion and unadulterated empathy Campo Santo has managed to conjure for these characters is no small feat in any medium. You feel for these two and their quiet, common struggles; a compassion develops so thick it's almost tangible. There's a solemn yearning at the heart of their relationship; a primal hunger for any vestige of feasible human intimacy that simultaneously guide and haunt them through the summer. It's wonderfully soulful stuff, and it all leads to an ending as wistful and restrained as the game that preceded it. Some feel short-changed for Firewatch not having delivered a more definitive conclusion, especially in the wake of a game that can be finished in 3 hours. Too short and no resolution" they say. I know of someone who might shrug off such criticisms - "That's life

reviewText:
I’ve actually been looking forward to Firewatch for years now, long before it was announced. Once I heard that the head devs for two of my favorite games, Walking Dead Season 1 and Mark of the Ninja, had founded their own studio I knew I had to play their first game. Firewatch didn’t disappoint me at all.

Firewatch is a narrative driven adventure game that has you play as Henry, a man working in a national park looking out for forest fires, seemingly trying to get away from his normal life. His only real contact to anyone else is his superior, Delilah, who’s stationed in another outpost miles away. The game focuses on how you develop your relationship with them, as well what kind of guy Henry is. There’s also some good amounts of exploration as well. The dialogue is fantastic and reactive, and you will probably make a habit of calling in everything to Delilah just so you can have more of their interactions. It's overall a fantastic character piece video game and the first ten minutes alone illustrate this from the get-go.

While the plot is set in stone, their relationship and who Henry is is not. The plot is also engaging and has an air of real mystery to it. The ending is ultimately quite satisfying and bittersweet, practically all loose ends are tied up and it can end on a melancholy yet hopeful note. It also has really good pacing, people may whine that its short, but some gamers just don’t seem to appreciate tightly-paced games. (And really its not that short, it took me almost five hours to complete it, also give me quality over quantity any day.)

Also the game is gorgeous and walking around the forest is great. The soundtracks is also really good too and adds to the atmosphere.

Overall Firewatch is a great adventure game and while I’m still mulling it over if it’s one of my favorite games of all time, its most definitely going to be one of my GOTY.

Despite what everyone seems to be saying, this is pretty much your standard Indie Walking Simulator, set in the Wyoming Wilderness in 1989. Great sound design, good visuals and fantastic voice acting can't hide what is a game that largely holds your hand and misses its full potential with an anti-climactic ending.

Needs to be about half the price too, considering it lasts only 2 or 3 hours.

reviewText:
TL;DR I didn't really like the game. It was shallow and with caricatures as characters, and had badly designed area maps. The graphics are pretty and the voice acting is nice.

Longer review:
I didn't mind that it was short, I didn't mind that it looked like a sandbox but the map was on rails, I didn't mind that it was a story told through voice acting and props. I didn't mind that Henry and Delilah don't ever meet face to face.

This game's fan base seems to almost entirely revolve around people who think the voice actress is sexy. She has a great voice, but that's not enough to make up for a mediocre story and a terrible ending.

The main characters Delilah and Henry are not broken people with a strong interesting story. They're broken people with a maybe interesting story that implodes in on itself when you reach the end. There's no growth or character arc. They learn nothing from their experiences. They're the same toxic and self-absorbed people at the end of the story that they were when they started.

The dev team defends this as being realistic. That might have worked better if about 80% of the story wasn't focused on a ridiculously unrealistic conspiracy that seems like it was pulled from an old episode of the X-Files. Or if they'd included a relationship that was build on some sort of respect or affection rather than lust and appeasement.

There are a number of interesting and thought-provoking ideas brought up in the prologue. Adults making selfish choices, alcoholism, early-onset dementia, partners enabling bad behavior in each other. Then they're all dropped in favor of a Scooby Doo mystery. And when you pull the mask off Old Man Smithers you get a thinly veiled lecture from devs on how Escapism is Bad Kids, M'kay?

So there's no story scripting to pursue the interesting adult topics, and the only story is to particpate in a Bad Escapist Mystery that teaches us Escapism is bad. How about instead the devs provide a game that looks at the interesting adult topics they promised during the publicity tour and prologue?

None of the decisions you make in the dialogues matter to the story. There isn't even the illusion of choice. According to their own statements, the dev team wanted to provide an environment where they told a strict linear story with no player agency and almost no game-play elements. It would have been better served as a machinima movie. The driving force behind playing games is to have some sort of active involvement in game progression. If we wanted a purely passive audio-visual experience we'd choose a different medium.

As far as the gameplay goes, it took me 8 tries to finish the game. I got stuck in invisible walls 7 times, in 7 completely different locations. I can't tell you how I did it (I didn't *try* to get stuck). I also spent almost all my time lost. The terrain was poorly designed (I kept following side paths that went nowhere) and inconsistent. In some cases, I could jump across wide gaps but couldn't step across narrow ones. In other cases environmental barricades (trees/bushes/rocks/fallen trees) were passable and other times they weren't.

The map was not aligned in all places to the paths. Sometimes I needed to be on" the red line of the path
date: other times I had to be to the left or right of it. Time of day was calibrated to reaching certain story points
recommended: so it was hard to use the sun to track direction. Holding up the map and compass blocked the interaction symbol for most items
hoursPlayed: so I used them as little as possible. With a bad sun

reviewText:
Umm

I guess all I have to say is...

Wow.

Firewatch blew me away. Everything from the visuals, the story, the dialogue, the soundtrack (oh my god the soundtrack), was beyond everything I had hoped. This game exceeded my expectations in just about every area, and that's saying something seeing as I usually find exploration games dreadfully boring.

However, Firewatch brought more to it than explanation. Instead of just aimless wandering with the hope of finding clues, you're given a narrative. And a fantastic one. Delilah guides Henry throughout the wilderness in an attempt to find out just what exactly is going on (im not spoiling anything). Through this you find tools, locations, loot, and notes which further expand upon the backgrounds of certain characters and the overall story.

Delilah also served as more than just a boss for Henry. Throughout the game you see and hear their relationship strengthen immensely, and at times I was angry at Henry for being married because I wanted them to be a couple so bad.

Apart from the story itself, one of the best things about this game was the soundtrack. With beautiful nature visuals must come a beautiful and emotional soundtrack, and that's exactly what this game did. The exploration of the woods accompanied with soothing piano, acoustic guitar, or the beat of drums (in more intense moments) did wonders to add to the mood of the overall game.

The only negatives are, as many reviewers have stated, the short length (3-4 hours), and the fact that this does not feel like a complete game". The ending was abrupt
date: what seemed to be major plot points were ignored if not completely discarded. It seems as thought it should be called Firewatch: Episode 1
recommended: rather than being the complete experience. However

reviewText:
A character-driven narrative game disguised as a hiking simulator, Firewatch tells a story that is compelling until it attempts to resolve itself. While the plot's climax may subtly relate to the game's stellar (and deeply sad) intro, it can't support the weight of the events leading up to it.

Firewatch is beautiful, the art style is striking, the voice acting is superb. A few rough edges are present, but forgivable. It can be completed in four hours or so. There are no challenges or traditional gameplay to speak of: your choices are entirely narrative in nature. Time advances as dictated by the story. Exploration is rarely rewarded.

Sadly, through no fault of its own, the game's narrative is shackled by the near-total absence of animated human beings. Being a small studio, it seems Campo Santo determined that they didn't have the budget for animated people, and designed Firewatch around this restriction. While their attempt should be lauded, the character-centric story they are telling ultimately suffers from it.

I'd recommend this to people that like narrativist gaming or are craving a survival-free first-person adventure game experience... but I'm still mad about the ending, so this gets a red thumb from me.

reviewText:
The atmosphere and music in this game are gorgeous and immersive, but what truly makes this a must-play is the voice acting. This is a dramatic gaming experience in which you are completely alone in the wilderness, but still you get attached to your main character and the voice on the other end of your walkie-talkie. You even let them mess with your head as a player because you truly care for them.

It's just the right length to keep you engaged in the story but leaves you wanting more. You want to hear more of that excellent voice acting, uncover more mystery, spend more time with the main characters and learn more about them.

I've just finished my first playthrough, but I cannot wait to do it all again. This is a beautiful and heartfelt, adult game you have to experience. Support these devs!

reviewText:
TL;DR I didn't really like the game. It was shallow and with caricatures as characters, and had badly designed area maps. The graphics are pretty and the voice acting is nice.

Longer review:
I didn't mind that it was short, I didn't mind that it looked like a sandbox but the map was on rails, I didn't mind that it was a story told through voice acting and props. I didn't mind that Henry and Delilah don't ever meet face to face.

This game's fan base seems to almost entirely revolve around people who think the voice actress is sexy. She has a great voice, but that's not enough to make up for a mediocre story and a terrible ending.

The main characters Delilah and Henry are not broken people with a strong interesting story. They're broken people with a maybe interesting story that implodes in on itself when you reach the end. There's no growth or character arc. They learn nothing from their experiences. They're the same toxic and self-absorbed people at the end of the story that they were when they started.

The dev team defends this as being realistic. That might have worked better if about 80% of the story wasn't focused on a ridiculously unrealistic conspiracy that seems like it was pulled from an old episode of the X-Files. Or if they'd included a relationship that was build on some sort of respect or affection rather than lust and appeasement.

There are a number of interesting and thought-provoking ideas brought up in the prologue. Adults making selfish choices, alcoholism, early-onset dementia, partners enabling bad behavior in each other. Then they're all dropped in favor of a Scooby Doo mystery. And when you pull the mask off Old Man Smithers you get a thinly veiled lecture from devs on how Escapism is Bad Kids, M'kay?

So there's no story scripting to pursue the interesting adult topics, and the only story is to particpate in a Bad Escapist Mystery that teaches us Escapism is bad. How about instead the devs provide a game that looks at the interesting adult topics they promised during the publicity tour and prologue?

None of the decisions you make in the dialogues matter to the story. There isn't even the illusion of choice. According to their own statements, the dev team wanted to provide an environment where they told a strict linear story with no player agency and almost no game-play elements. It would have been better served as a machinima movie. The driving force behind playing games is to have some sort of active involvement in game progression. If we wanted a purely passive audio-visual experience we'd choose a different medium.

As far as the gameplay goes, it took me 8 tries to finish the game. I got stuck in invisible walls 7 times, in 7 completely different locations. I can't tell you how I did it (I didn't *try* to get stuck). I also spent almost all my time lost. The terrain was poorly designed (I kept following side paths that went nowhere) and inconsistent. In some cases, I could jump across wide gaps but couldn't step across narrow ones. In other cases environmental barricades (trees/bushes/rocks/fallen trees) were passable and other times they weren't.

The map was not aligned in all places to the paths. Sometimes I needed to be on" the red line of the path
date: other times I had to be to the left or right of it. Time of day was calibrated to reaching certain story points
recommended: so it was hard to use the sun to track direction. Holding up the map and compass blocked the interaction symbol for most items
hoursPlayed: so I used them as little as possible. With a bad sun
voteText: bad map
helpfulPercent: bad compass
votesHelpful: and bad environmental barricades
votesTotal: I spent most of my play time wandering in pointless circles (or restarting after getting stuck
votesFunny: and playing the same conversations again and again).\n\nThis was just a bad game. I'm sorry to put it in those terms
commentsCount: I'm sure the development team worked hard on it
column16: but it was not worth the money I paid for it nor the time I put into playing it."

reviewText:
The game is beautiful, intrigueing, interesting, mysterious, ... and so much more. It reminds me of those beautiful warm summer nights, spent in the woods. Even though I was sitting in a freezing cold room playing this game, it almost felt like I was walking through a forest in the evening sun, you can almost smell it, it just has that much atmosphere.

The story itself is great as well though it did leave me with a lot of questions and no way to answer them.

All in all, I would definitely recommend this game! Not quite like any game out there and the conversation is really entertaining (and I'm not one for a lot of conversations in games!). I do have to admit that I find the price somewhat on the higher side as it is quite a short game.

reviewText: Basically I have been hyped for this game for quite some time and was counting down the days to the release. I was on my way to an objective and on the way there I noticed part of the world was not loaded, I restarted my game and still had the same situation. Excited to progress I began to run and noticed that I was going nowhere as I had been glitched inside a rock. As you can probably imagine I could not escape the rock and there was literally nothing I could do thus I began searching YouTube for a solution after a while of scrolling I found a video! But unfortunately it spoiled the entire plot of the game in the title. In a nutshell I am extremely ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off and have to start the the entire game again just to get to where I was last. Honestly I cannot quantify how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off I am in one review but I thought I would let everyone know about my great experience!\nThanks for reading.\n

reviewText:
A character-driven narrative game disguised as a hiking simulator, Firewatch tells a story that is compelling until it attempts to resolve itself. While the plot's climax may subtly relate to the game's stellar (and deeply sad) intro, it can't support the weight of the events leading up to it.

Firewatch is beautiful, the art style is striking, the voice acting is superb. A few rough edges are present, but forgivable. It can be completed in four hours or so. There are no challenges or traditional gameplay to speak of: your choices are entirely narrative in nature. Time advances as dictated by the story. Exploration is rarely rewarded.

Sadly, through no fault of its own, the game's narrative is shackled by the near-total absence of animated human beings. Being a small studio, it seems Campo Santo determined that they didn't have the budget for animated people, and designed Firewatch around this restriction. While their attempt should be lauded, the character-centric story they are telling ultimately suffers from it.

I'd recommend this to people that like narrativist gaming or are craving a survival-free first-person adventure game experience... but I'm still mad about the ending, so this gets a red thumb from me.

My review! I bought the game about 3 hours before it was released without knowing too much about it. I started playing as soon as it was released and i havent stopped playing! I finished the game merely moments ago.

reviewText:
This game is a very human one
This review may contain some spoilers, likely no direct spoilers, but those that are will be blocked by spoiler text, I'll also indicate when I begin to speak about spoilers.

STORY

This is a game about people, about human nature, about the actions we take and the ones we don't or can't take. The characters are likeable and relateable, the plot grips you tight as a vise for about 3-4 hours and then releases you into reality.

If you want a game for plot and characters moreso than for just action, by all means buy this game, but if not, it's probably best to avoid it.

GAMEPLAY

Controls are easy to get used to. This game doesn't have much in way of gameplay, otherwise, and at times it may feel a bit tedious. There is quite a bit of getting lost and having to backtrack (probably one of my biggest gripe with this game, it's never fun to backtrack)

GRAPHICS and AUDIO



This game looks and sounds amazing:
Graphically speaking it's simillar to that of Borderlands as in it is not traditionaly beautiful (i.e realistic visuals) that being said it is still an incredibly beautiful looking game, the art style is amazing and it really does help to immerse you even further. Lighting effects are stunning. And beyond that the audio really helps to immerse you as well, the soundtrack is great, and the sounds of the forest are realistic and only adds to the atmosphere

IN SUMMARY


This game is beautiful and immersive, the plot and characters are all very well writen. Gameplay wise it's lacking, and at times tedious.
What I'll say, in summary, is buy this game if you love narrative driven games or gorgeous visuals (even if at times gameplay may be a bit tedious). If not, then you may want to forego buying this one.



PS....  it was illuminati all along

reviewText:
This game crescendos about half way and decrescendos the rest of the way both in story and plot points.

+ Voice Acting
+ Environment / Atmosphere
+ Points of excitement

- Choices do not affect ending
- Points of excitement typically met with utter disappointment
- Length of game (2-4 hours, your milage may vary).

Over all this game had so much potential. Like a swiming pool of possibilities filled with several glasses of the best water on earth... and then left. Just like that. Before you know it you're collecting every pinecone in the game and bringing it back to your tower. All the little things left in the supply boxes that you've painstakingly brought back with you. They mean NOTHING. There's no story to them. There's no reason to collect them. I bring this up because it's literally the ONLY interactive activity outside exploring and following the plot of the game... and it was a complete waste of time.

5/10 - I'm half expecting the other half of this game to be released as DLC. It's actually a very beautiful game otherwise. It could have been one of the greats.

reviewText:
I typically don't write any reviews for any of the games I play, but I feel like I need to write one for this game.

Pros: 1. The game looks really good, graphics cranked up to ultra look really good, and i love the art style.

2. The gameplay is pretty unique and i havn't seen much like, it fits  perfectly for the length of the game.

3. The story and plot are pretty tense and exciting ( at first).

4. The interaction between the characters is pretty funny and the different choices you can make in dialogue would give slight replay ability.

Cons: 1. I beat the game in around 2 hours and with little to no replay value. For 18 USD (almost 1/3 of a full retail                               release) there just isn't enough here.

2. Even though the story is interesting at first once you find out who or what is causeing it disappointed me.

3. Besides the feelings of tension you get from the story and the surroudings, the game consists of mainly slow walking/slow jogging and boring interaction with the items doesn't give a whole lot to do in the game.

Overall I would not recommend this game for $18, but if it went on sale or discount later on I would say this might be a good buy for 50% off.  SCORE 5/10

reviewText:
I feel ripped off. Totally ripped off.

I went in knowing as little as possible on purpose, and was sold on the screenshots and artwork. In return I get an incredibly short and boring experience. All the buildup, the mystery, falls flat on its face. This game ends up feeling more like an intro level AT BEST to a REAL video game.

I can't stress enough that this game and story feels more like a psych experiment to see how many people you can sell a $20 game to based on nothing other than a few short videos and pretty screenshots.

I would pay no more than $5 for this. Do NOT support this currently, unless you want more of the same (from this and other companies).

I did really enjoy the game, but at this point in time I don't think I can recommend it. Wait until the price comes down, or see if additional content is added (but I don't think this is likely at all).

reviewText: I really wish I could recommend this game. My first three hours with this game were amazing: the environment was drop-dead gorgeous and despite being a bit of a walking-simulator, the beautiful scenery, great dialogue and interplay between the main character and Delilah more than made up for it. I don't want to spoil anything for people, but when other reviewers are saying that the ending of the game was lackluster... it really was. There was just no pay-off for the suspense the creators built up over the course of the rest of the game. It didn't even leave me feeling like I'd learned something about myself or life in general, as many of these smaller more narrative-driven games do. It's such a shame because if the ending had been done better - if the way they'd attempted to draw together all the different threads in the story had been done in a more rewarding way - this would have been amazing game. As it is, I enjoyed a few hours of beautiful vistas and funny dialogue, but I couldn't recommend this game, especially at the current price for what's really about 4 hours of gameplay at most with zero replayability.
