reviewText: Whereas the developers promised a 6-7 hour game if you rush, what you instead get is a 3-4 hour game where the mystery was better than the actual story itself. I am perfectly fine with a short game/experience if the story could live up to the expectations set up in that regard, but Firewatch falls flat in that department. I don't want to say that the story was rushed, but it certainly seemed that way when there is a heavy focus on certain events which took place early on in the game that never really had a satisfying payoff - in fact the entire sequence with the two girls shown in the promotional material is just an afterthought in terms of the story, and the conclusion to the mystery went from large-scale conspiracy to small-scale petty vengeance in the blink of an eye. There is an entire game mechanic (taking pictures) that is stressed to be important when documenting the mysterious goings-on in the forest, but that's essentially tossed out the window when any and all pictures you took did not matter in the slightest nor were ever brought up outside of the obligatory mention of the fact. On the topic of things in Firewatch that at first seemed important but later turned out not to matter at all, there was a sequence in the game where the main character hallucinated that the person on the other end of the walkie-talkie was his wife, and a brief reference later it was never brought up (or happened) again - I would chalk that up to wasted potential in terms of where the main character's personal story went. It reminds me of Gone Home in this regard, which suffers from similar issues that I am unable to justify paying the same price for. Unfortunately, as I am over the two hour limit and have completed the game, I am unable to request a refund. If this were the beginning of the story - because there is clearly more to be told regarding both characters and their respective histories - I would give this a better review and the benefit of the doubt. As this is not the case, I would not recommend the game at the price it is being asked for currently ($20). Sure, the conversations between the main character and his sole lifeline" are somewhat entertaining
date: but they never really go anywhere special/different in the long run - and that's what disappointed me the most
recommended: as I was initially sold on the game concept because of the personal relationship between two characters from the initial promotional material."

reviewText: I really wish I could recommend this game. My first three hours with this game were amazing: the environment was drop-dead gorgeous and despite being a bit of a walking-simulator, the beautiful scenery, great dialogue and interplay between the main character and Delilah more than made up for it. I don't want to spoil anything for people, but when other reviewers are saying that the ending of the game was lackluster... it really was. There was just no pay-off for the suspense the creators built up over the course of the rest of the game. It didn't even leave me feeling like I'd learned something about myself or life in general, as many of these smaller more narrative-driven games do. It's such a shame because if the ending had been done better - if the way they'd attempted to draw together all the different threads in the story had been done in a more rewarding way - this would have been amazing game. As it is, I enjoyed a few hours of beautiful vistas and funny dialogue, but I couldn't recommend this game, especially at the current price for what's really about 4 hours of gameplay at most with zero replayability.

reviewText:
I was highly anticipating this game. I preordered it as soon as it was available on Steam.
I would love to give this game the recommendation but unfortunitely I can not.

The beginning is amazing, the feels man... The feels... Started off great, I was hooked, started to get very compelling and then it finally hit a wall when I came to the realization of what was happening in the mystery of the game (no spoilers, some people might find it interesting). It just all boiled down to one big let down in the end.
I felt like the developers had all the right ideas and they were on the brink of a game that could really stick with you but they came up short. In my opinion so many things could have been added to the story and gameplay to make it amazing.

Don't get me wrong it was still a decent play and you could tell the Developers put alot of heart and soul into it but it just left so much to be desired. It was too short for the price tag but if it drops down to at least $10.00 on a sale I would recommend it.

reviewText:
I typically don't write any reviews for any of the games I play, but I feel like I need to write one for this game.

Pros: 1. The game looks really good, graphics cranked up to ultra look really good, and i love the art style.

2. The gameplay is pretty unique and i havn't seen much like, it fits  perfectly for the length of the game.

3. The story and plot are pretty tense and exciting ( at first).

4. The interaction between the characters is pretty funny and the different choices you can make in dialogue would give slight replay ability.

Cons: 1. I beat the game in around 2 hours and with little to no replay value. For 18 USD (almost 1/3 of a full retail                               release) there just isn't enough here.

2. Even though the story is interesting at first once you find out who or what is causeing it disappointed me.

3. Besides the feelings of tension you get from the story and the surroudings, the game consists of mainly slow walking/slow jogging and boring interaction with the items doesn't give a whole lot to do in the game.

Overall I would not recommend this game for $18, but if it went on sale or discount later on I would say this might be a good buy for 50% off.  SCORE 5/10

reviewText:
I feel ripped off. Totally ripped off.

I went in knowing as little as possible on purpose, and was sold on the screenshots and artwork. In return I get an incredibly short and boring experience. All the buildup, the mystery, falls flat on its face. This game ends up feeling more like an intro level AT BEST to a REAL video game.

This is totally unfinished, and ultimately looks and feels like a Unity engine game despite the unique art style. Performance is poor relative to what's being rendered on screen. I can't stress enough that this game and story feels more like a psych experiment to see how many people you can sell a $20 game to based on nothing other than a few short videos and pretty screenshots.

I would pay no more than $5 for this. Do NOT support this currently, unless you want more of the same (from this and other companies).

reviewText:
Firewatch is a good game, but not a great game, and not one that I'd recommend at full price.

Let's get started with what the game is not, because I think a lot of people expected based on previews more than what it's offering. It is not really an open world game. Yes, you have access to most of the map at all times, but the objectives are linear and mostly punctuated by taking you back to the tower once you complete them. The world is pretty, but there isn't anything in it. Aside from a few lockboxes you find and objects specifically related to your current objectives, there's nothing you can interact with in the world or see besides trees and ♥♥♥♥.

This game is also not a choice-based story in the vein of Life Is Strange. While you do have dialogue choices, they will not impact any in-game events or the game's ending in any meaningful way. It only affects the dialogue you hear back from your dispatcher.

This game does not have challenges in its gameplay. There are no puzzles, no combat, no way to die" or fail your objectives. You are simply going through a story in first person.

While none of these things are by any means requirements for a game to be good
date: it leaves us only with the story
recommended: which unfortunately isn't as good as I had hoped. The idea of the game is that you're alone
hoursPlayed: and because of your past you're emotionally unstable and susceptible to paranoia
voteText: and weird ♥♥♥♥ starts happening that you have to figure out. The game does an amazing job with the setup
helpfulPercent: and an amazing job of making everything feel creepier and creepier. But the big discovery about what's happening is super disappointing and anticlimactic (though I'll give that it's interesting and unexpected). I think they had a great opportunity to take it a step further and they didn't. And then everything that happens between that and the ending is really dull and unsatisfying."

reviewText:
Look, I never leave reviews, but with this, I just feel so let down from the developer claims. The 17 minute developer preview video that they released last year with narration essentially covers about 15% of the entire gameplay!

The story telling, the simple choices you make at the start that carry through the story, the voice acting (oh god, Delilah!) are all amazing. I have no real issue with the linear nature of the game, I really enjoyed being part of a progressive story featuring you as the lead.

reviewText: This game kind of hit the dead middle of the road for me. While the graphical aspects of the game were pretty solid, and the plot just enough to keep me going, it falls way short in the department of gameplay. I finished the game in just over 3 hours on my first playthrough with basic navigation and finding pretty much everything there was to find. Overall, the game felt like a cartoon movie based around adult themes. However, it doesn't cost me $20 to go to the movies, so I see no reason why a game that lasts just a bit longer than a movie should cost more than $10. If you don't care about spending $20 on a movie, then by all means go for it. However, the game lacks any kind of replayability, and you can probably get the same enjoyment out of someone streaming it on Twitch as owning it.

reviewText:
A character-driven narrative game disguised as a hiking simulator, Firewatch tells a story that is compelling until it attempts to resolve itself. While the plot's climax may subtly relate to the game's stellar (and deeply sad) intro, it can't support the weight of the events leading up to it.

Firewatch is beautiful, the art style is striking, the voice acting is superb. A few rough edges are present, but forgivable. It can be completed in four hours or so. There are no challenges or traditional gameplay to speak of: your choices are entirely narrative in nature. Time advances as dictated by the story. Exploration is rarely rewarded.

Sadly, through no fault of its own, the game's narrative is shackled by the near-total absence of animated human beings. Being a small studio, it seems Campo Santo determined that they didn't have the budget for animated people, and designed Firewatch around this restriction. While their attempt should be lauded, the character-centric story they are telling ultimately suffers from it.

I'd recommend this to people that like narrativist gaming or are craving a survival-free first-person adventure game experience... but I'm still mad about the ending, so this gets a red thumb from me.

reviewText:
I wanted so much to like this game, and I did at the start, but by the end I was feeling nothing but emptiness and disappointment.

The Positives:

The Art Direction and Visual style.
The Voice Acting and Dialogue in general is well done, and I did feel some realistic chemistry develop between the main characters.

The Negatives:
The game is WAY to short. I finished in just over 3 hours and I was not trying to rush.
Nothing very interesting actually happens, and by the end I just felt empty.
There is very little actual gameplay. Everything is deceptively linear, and interaction / things to do are extremely lacking.
The story which starts promisingly, is BORING overall, and the ending is extremely underwhelming.


If you want to try it wait until its on sale.

reviewText:
If this game was a movie, it would be considered one of those art movies where the story lies more in the presentation of the characters and setting, than on the actual plot. The interaction with the ever clever and mysterious woman over the radio is the best done part of the game and deserves an award. But as the story continues it soon begins to feel rushed and the ending appears so quickly that you think they must have left part of the game out. The settings is done well but they could have surely done better if they converted it over to an open world exploration game with less restricted paths. In addition the developers fails by not allowing different ending depending on the choices that one has made. It would have changed the overall approach to the story significantly. In conclusion I credit the developers with taking a risk as the game touches an artistic point that is not felt in another games I have played, this is a great mystery game to purchase under $10, as the game currently sits  it is easily completed under 6 hours and the replay value is very small.

***The negative review is purely related to the price of the game at launch and I would recommend it for $10 and under***

reviewText:
Is the game good......sort of?
Is it worth the money?.......At the current price no. Wait for this to drop to price a bit, then pick it up.


Ok so let's get this out of the way instantly. This game can be completed in 3 hours (took me 4 because I got lost a few times). Don't belive me? YouTube already has a full playthrough up that chocks in at just over the 3 hour mark.
Some people will play through multiple times or may want to explore every nook and cranny so mileage may vary but keep in mind you're not getting a drawn-out epic here.

What I will say is the game is gorgeous. From the art style to the musical score (which is a little loud honestly - you'll turn it down) and not to mention top notch voice acting you will be drawn into this world and you will more than likly enjoy the experience....until the ending. I was let down. No way around it. This game had me captured and I just couldn't put it down. It had all the hallmarks of a amazing game and I did really enjoy my (all be it brief) time with it. Just wish I didn't buy this right away. I feel like its about the length of One episode of a TellTale game (of which there are usually 5 per game). Anyone who's played any of those will know what I mean.

So ya, good game, could of been amazing if longer and with a redone ending.

Don't buy it now unless you really must see this game (movie?) for yourself so you can make your own choices.

Once it's on sale (probably in the summer) pick it up.

reviewText:
Stunning if cartoony graphics and mind-blowingly beautifully handcrafted dialogue make this a memorable game. The relationships and characters this game supplies are believable and genuine, the emotions and suspense truly grip your heart. The ending may not be as big a twist as you may have been hoping for, but it seems natural, a logical consequence of everything that's happened, not contrived in the least. The music makes an amazing and fitting counterpiece to the happenings of the park.

I have noticed some minor gameplay glitches and some few graphic artifacts, but apart from that my only real complaint would be the short game time. If you explore absolutely everything, you're looking at 6 hours at the most, and that's if you're going at a very sluggish pace (not that that's a bad thing; quite the opposite really), more likely 4-5. Still, the realness" of the heartfelt dialogue more than make up for it in my opinion.

Be aware
recommended: that this game focuses on character and its development most of all. Exploration

voteText: and even story are only minor concerns

reviewText:
So, a few minutes ago i finished this game and don't really know what to say.

This game is beautiful and depressing at the same time.
Conversations between Henry and Delilah made me feel they're alive. Voice acting is really great.

Graphics are nice and enough. The art style of Firewatch is heartwarming.

Story is good but obviously short and it's like it wasn't really enough. Maybe if it's 2 or 3 hours longer it'd be better. It took me 4 hours to finish.

Overally, i liked this game. It's a different experience and it's all about the story. You'll follow orders from Delilah most of the time and you have to read the map in order to find your way.

If you're looking for a different experience, if you like some mystery and deep games, you'll like it.

reviewText:
Hey, why don't you try this lovely storytelling / mood- curiosity candidate of the year? It totally enchanted me into its comforting scenery, solitude and deliberate simplicity.

The story and the characters felt believable to me - they were mature, 30-45 years old, and also acted like it. That's still pretty uncommon in videogames, and it felt very refreshing. Guns and saving the world is all nice, but I feel like there are so many unexplored possibilities for video game narratives and Firewatch is enforcing that feeling.

The dialogue, script, voice acting are all superb, it's obvious a lot of time went into fine tuning that part of the game, which is really a central mechanic. Its amazing how the game accomplished to enchant with its fairly simple mechanics. The moods in the art are wonderful, too, if not necessarily the most polished part of the game.

I feel like the game is a step forward from the telltale games - not a huge step - but definitely a step forward in the art of interactive digital storytelling. Its so exciting to see the media evolve, and I can't wait to see what they cook up next!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Great writing, gorgeous aesthetics, excellent sound design, and doesn't pad itself out unnecessarily. I would love to talk about the game more in detail but I would spoil the story, and while it's not the ~ultimate best story in video games ever~, it was not only highly enjoyable but also grounded in reality in a way you don't often see in games.\n\nI think it's a strong contender for game of the year and we're only in February, so... really, play it. (yes, even at full price")"

reviewText:
Firewatch is extremely pretty game, it also features good voice actors with a range of different dialogue paths to choose. None that I can see majorly changing the storyline. The story starts off strong and gets incredibly intense around halfway through, you're on edge pretty much everywhere you go. After that it just seems to dwindle, things start to become predictable. To my surprise, the storyline and gameplay time is very short. Only around 4/5 hours long, would of liked to seen it streched longer. The ending was anticlimactic, again slightly predictable, could have spiced things up a bit as it started to get boring and tedious.

£14.99? It's a bit steep, but for a game I've been following in development for nearly 2 years. I had to buy it. If thinking of buying I would recommend buying it when it comes on sale. If you're not into the art side of games, I would avoid this, it doesn't have any replay value.

The one thing to keep in mind when buying this is remembering it's a piece of art, it's highly unique to any other game I've played. It's just based of 2 characters with no motos or hero like aspects. You can just spent time walking around and listening to the soundtrack, which I would of liked more of aswell. Sometimes you'd be walking across the map and only a 1 minute track would come on. Also, great sountrack for the game.

I want to say that I loved this game, it's pretty, started off great. But it just fell short.

I like it. 7/10
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The game is too short to be worth $20. I finished it all in one sitting and really wasn't worth the money. Feel sorta scammed.


On the bright side though the game was pretty good, not as pretty as I had hoped, but still pretty decent. The conversations are fun to listen to, but there are too little when just walking around and too many when doing things. Needed to be more balanced.

The developer also promised something like 6-8 hours of gameplay. I got lost almost every single turn, I went to the other side of the map multiple times and I finished it in 3 hours exactly. I listened to all the dialouge, always answered the radio etc. No possible way you could get 6 hours out of it, and it's not like this game has any replay value.

Only buy when on sale, worth $10 not $20.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I find it hard to give Firewatch a bad review because it does so many thing right but I just can't say I would recommend it to anyone. The game has a fantastic atmosphere and a beautiful world matches with some of the most natural voice acting I have heard in a video game, the connection between the characters is very dynamic and believable and is a one of the strongest points of this game.

The problem lays dorment with the story (no spoilers) they try to set up a gripping mystery and at the start this slowly unfolds and is very much the case, the problem becomes apparent as you progress a little more and the story gets more and more interesting then suddenly it's over. The climax of the game feels extremely hollow and really leaves you disappointed because in all honest I wanted more. It feels as just when things are starting to get real interesting the story cuts off and so much more could have been done with the plot they set up.

I see a lot of people complaining about the games length and I personally don't see this as an issue, I will replay the game to look around a bit more and to try earn the achievements that decided not to pop but all in all this is a good game with a disappointing ending.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I had to think hard about if I would recommend this game or not and in the end I have to say don’t buy it at least at the current price tag. Wait for it to become a 5 dollar game.

This game has very nice stylistic visuals; the story is somewhat interesting and the atmosphere keeps you playing but does not pay off at the end.
While the art is pretty the world is kind of empty, don’t expect to see other people except in the distance, wildlife is almost non-existent, this game only has the bare minimum amount of art needed to tell the story which is kind of a let-down and comes off as lazy.

The gameplay consists of you talking on your walkie talkie with a fellow ranger (which is the high point of the game), walking from point A to point B and inspecting things when you get there, there is nothing more to it which wouldn’t be so bad if the story was much more compelling.
This is not a survival game nor a real exploration game, it’s an on rails game with the illusion of freedom so please keep that in mind when you purchase it.

The biggest gripe that me and I’m sure most people would have is that the game is very very short, I took my time, looked at everything I could in the locations I visited, spent time to talk about everything I saw through my walkie talkie and I still completed the game in 3 hours and after a second playthrough completed it in about 1 hour which is much too short for a 20 dollar price tag.

This is not a terrible game so I can’t say you won’t like it but keep this in mind before you buy; its runs nice, looks nice, has good voice acting and is interesting to play till the end but it’s also a very flawed game that feels rushed, lazy in its execution and content, it’s far too short and way over priced for what you get, if you are ok with all this then this is the game for you.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I was so excited for Firewatch. I'm a forest firefighter, and seeing a game in this setting was unusual, and really got me interested. I watched every gameplay video and trailer that came out, which got me insanely hyped for it. I even preordered it, which served as a healthy reminder for me to go back to my personal policy of not preordering games.

I'm pretty disappointed, to be honest.

The trailers gave the impression of a creepy thriller set in the wilderness, and probably the first hour and a half (if that) lived up to that hype. I was on the edge of my seat, blood pumping, jumping at loud noises. The plot had grabbed me, it was creepy and interesting, I was suspicious of everyone, even Henry himself.

And then it just fell apart. It's like they were writing the plot outline on a friday arvo, thought ♥♥♥♥ it
date: let's wrap it up so we can head to the pub for beers
recommended:
and hastily wrapped it up into a very tidy package. No mystery, no puzzles, nothing to solve. Once it started to wrap up, i lost interest. I wasn't scared, I wasn't curious. I finished it in like two and a half hours, and that's reading every document, taking it slowly.


Don't get me wrong, it's got good points. The design and aesthetic is awesome, great setting. very basic gameplay, but that's not a bad thing in every case. in this game though, it feels like a tool so you can wander through the bush and collect items.
You can adopt a tortoise. Dialog is witty, well written and well voiced. Too bad it seemed like the options had no impact on the outcome of the game, which honestly in hindsight makes the dialogue seem so useless.

I wish I was defending this game, because i waited so long for this to come out. If the plot was deeper, or choices had impact on the outcome of the game, or the game was longer, then maybe I would be recommending it. But for 20 USD (more in AUD), I can't. that's like 10 dollars an hour! If it was 10 bucks or less, maybe I'd recommend it. Wait for a sale or something if you want to play it.

tl;dr:  buy when cheaper
cons: Shallow gameplay, short unfulfilling plot, choices have no impact on outcome of game, too expensive, conclusion was weak and disappointing.
pros: witty clever dialogue, great setting, nice aesthetic, you can adopt a turtle, first hour and a half is gripping and thrilling
buy when cheaper

I'm so sad now...

As I'm sure many reviewers have pointed out, the graphics are beautiful, the voice acting is great, and the ability to induce feelings of suspense and isolation spot on. At the end, I found the story forgetable and rigidly linear, leaving the game with little replay value.

reviewText: Well... I was really close to give this game a positive/recommending review.Because for people wanting an intriguing story that has mystery to it with some pretty visuals and a good soundtrack for what it is. I would recommened it. But It's too dam short. 3.1 hours as my steam says, played in one playthrough. Also the ending did annoy me, no dam satisfaction for me at the least. I would say that this game would be better if it were longer with more than one mystery to it. It didn't take the full potential of the wilderness and maybe murder/slasher/dissaperances mysteries and only presents you with one story which for a 'walking simulator' like this isn't very good. Now don't get me wrong, the characters are real, interesting and if you put your heart to it lovable. But, even though of the characters back story, I didn't feel attached.\n\nThe soundtrack is great and can be bought seperately (that's a + in my head as I collect video game soundtracks), the visuals are simple but appealing (if an ENB ever comes out for this game I'm 100% playing it again) but the narrative fell short in not exploting the mysteries of the wilderness and previous Firewatcher[s]. Watch someone play it on Youtube or wait till it's on a sale for 5$ or 5/7£ cause you can have some fun with it. It just falls too short .

reviewText:

You play the role of henry, who is a forest fire watchmen in Wyoming. This game has a rich story, that will tear at your heartstrings and not let you put it down. The game style allows you to make your own decisions to make the game progress in different ways, this leaves different endings for different people.

The cool option they provide is the ability to allow you to take in game pictures with your disposible camera and have them developed into printed images and mailed to you for $15, the graphics in this game provide for some GREAT photos.

My opinon; IT CONTAINS SPOILERS:  I just wish we would have been able to have met delilah rather than only being in contact with her via the in game radio  I also feel it's such a short game to pay $20 for, so I would reccommend this game on sale for closer to $10

reviewText:
Set your expectations and you will be fine.

* The dev team was 12 people, this is an indie game
* There is a shallow, but complete feature set
* There is no gameplay, in the traditional sense of the word
* Yes it is short, more like an interactive movie than a FPS
* There are no guns, no monsters, no aliens and no video game cliches
* Often choices are made for you; days end when the story dictates, dialogue happens and the main character does things on his own every once in a while that you cannot influence (some of these are in the trailer btw)

One thing this game does really well, is it puts you in a specific mood at the end or it did for me.  Like some of my favorite movies that I watch over and over.  If you are looking for a reason to replay it, don't expect achievements or unlocks.  Play it again because you enjoyed the story and how it made you feel.

Take it for what it is, not what you want it to be.

reviewText:
Well, where do I start? First of all, the game is about 3 1/2 hours long. Maybe a little longer if you take your time and read every little piece of text you find throughout the game. Also Firewatch isn't a game in the classic sense. I think people might fall into trap to think this is some kind of survival game. You can't die, you won't gather resources and you won't build stuff.

This is more like an interactive experience. And by far the most important part of said experience is the conversation between you, the protagonist, and Delilah, your only real contact to the outside world. Through this conversation you will learn about both of their backstories and thanks to the amazing voice acting you'll most likely enjoy the chemistry between both of them.

The rest of the game is more or less a hiking simulator. That isn't a bad thing though. I found it to be deeply satisfying to wander through the beautifuly crafted world, accompanied by the many dialogue options you'll have when talking to Delilah on the radio.

The story that ties everything together mostly kept me on the edge of my seat and therefore I found it very easy to finish the whole game in one sitting. Be warned though, even though the game's setting is certainly atmospheric and creepy, this is not a horror game. If walking through the woods alone, being paranoid about noises, is enough to grind your gears, then this will suffice to you.

Overall this is a very well crafted, albeit short, interactive experience with especially great voice acting. The price at about $20 is a bit steep but justifiable. If you're open to alternative storytelling and aren't appalled by the idea of hiking through the woods, this might be for you.

reviewText:
Pros
-Great writing, the characters felt real
-Art style is extremely cozy and fits well
-World is rather large and feels realistic (This is a pro or con depending on person)
-Beautiful world

Cons
-Kinda short
-Story ends with you wanting more and a bit abruptly leaving many questions unanswered
-Even by the end the guy still can't climb the rope faster than day 1


It's honestly up to you if you want to drop the cash for a game that'll last ~4 hours. The story does leave you a bit upset at the end because of so many things left hanging and feeling like all the conversations didn't make much impact on whether or not you guys ♥♥♥♥ed at the end.  If they released a free DLC wrapping up the story then this would be a must buy.

My opinon; IT CONTAINS SPOILERS:  I just wish we would have been able to have met delilah rather than only being in contact with her via the in game radio  I also feel it's such a short game to pay $20 for, so I would reccommend this game on sale for closer to $10

reviewText: Firewatch is a 4-5 hour adventure through a heavily forested Wyoming park. You never really see other people up close, but you do have a radio buddy that keeps you company. The game styles itself an adult game about adults having adult conversations" and that's a pretty apt description. Sadly
date:
the ending is incredibly simplistic and fails to tie together any of the storylines or themes.

The best part of Firewatch is the writing and voice acting. The main lead is Rich Sommer (you know him as Harry Crane from Mad Men) and he nails this role. Cissy Jones is a video game mainstay and she delivers wonderfully as well. Put them together and you have a legitimately funny yet poignant conversation that basically continues for the entire length of the game. The same story without them would've been a shadow of itself.

The graphics are simple but well executed and consistently styled. The music
hoursPlayed: is amazing. Some of my favorite moments in the game would have been boring walks through the woods without the music. Each track managed to transform idle time into something serene and precious.\n\nThe mechanics are largely like any other "walking simulator." I've had such good experiences with that moniker that even though I know it started as an insult I'm beginning to think developers should take it as a complement. The single biggest problem with Firewatch's particular implementation is that there is a minimum distance to interact with objects. Watching someone struggle with trying to climb a rope they are right next to is painful. "No you need to back up. You need to be farther away from the rope to climb it." That's advice anyone playing this game should take to heart
voteText: but it's stupid that it has to be given in the first place. There's also a bizarre bug where the reticle can be partially on an object
helpfulPercent: but then pressing shift to bring up the radio moves the reticle off the object. Talk about frustrating and unintuitive. Though other than those complaints the game plays like you would expect.\n\nIf you're looking for a game where the focus is on the journey instead of the destination then you should pick up Firewatch. The ending is truly disappointing compared to what it could have been. It's almost like the developers had less of an imagination than the people playing their game. I'm holding out hoping for some alternate
votesHelpful: apocryphal interpretations to gain traction. Until then
votesTotal: the journey alone is well worth the price."

reviewText:
Stunning if cartoony graphics and mind-blowingly beautifully handcrafted dialogue make this a memorable game. The relationships and characters this game supplies are believable and genuine, the emotions and suspense truly grip your heart. The ending may not be as big a twist as you may have been hoping for, but it seems natural, a logical consequence of everything that's happened, not contrived in the least. The music makes an amazing and fitting counterpiece to the happenings of the park.

I have noticed some minor gameplay glitches and some few graphic artifacts, but apart from that my only real complaint would be the short game time. If you explore absolutely everything, you're looking at 6 hours at the most, and that's if you're going at a very sluggish pace (not that that's a bad thing; quite the opposite really), more likely 4-5. Still, the realness" of the heartfelt dialogue more than make up for it in my opinion.

reviewText:
I've been reading a lot of the reviews here on steam and on other websites as well and while there are various reactions I am more interested in the gaming community as a whole.

First allow me to say the facts about this game first so that there isn't any misunderstandings. The game lasts about 4 to 6 hours, depending on how much you explore and how many conversations do you respond or engage.

The main game mechanic would be the conversation aspect of the game. There's no action or much in th way of puzzles.

There are lots of choices and conversation trees but at the same time there are several plot points that will always occur and while how they are approached can vary depending on the conversations you have, they'll play out the same. So there aren't wildly different endings in this game.

In my opinion this probably going to game of the year for me. Let me explain.

Video games, for a while now, have been fighting for the right to be labeled as an art form, like film and literature and theater for example. However what is most interesting to me is that a significant portion of the gaming community is still thinking in an old way. A lot of people have called this a walking Simulator"
date: it's almost as if a lot of people don't know what to do when confronted with a game that focuses on telling a story versus what score do you get
recommended:
or achievement you earn.

Let's call this work what it should be called. It's a Thriller. And if you desperately need to remind people that it's an electronic medium then Interactive Thriller could work.

The community can't function without trying to out this game in the typical "game" boxes which is why you'll still hear
hoursPlayed:
*it's too short" "It's too linear" "There aren't any side quests" "where are the achievements" "no multi-player" etc.

To those who would argue it's too short and too expensive for the money. $20 for 4 to 6 hours of well written and acted content isn't a waste. If you'll pay that much for a movie ticket that you can only view one time then this is definitely justified in price.

I am curious how can people complain about how it's too linear? It's clearly telling a story with a beginning
voteText: middle and end. While the conversation choices add variety
helpfulPercent: it is a story and it doesn't need to have giant multi faceted story possibilities.\n\nThe gaming industry
votesHelpful: in comparison to the other mediums
votesTotal: is still very young. And we still have a long way to go. I can tell you that Firewatch is one of the few games released so far that is trying to make the statement that an interactive medium is just as powerful as a way to tell a story as a passive one. We need more games like this.\n\nThis game is beautiful visually
votesFunny:
a very well chosen  art style.

The voice acting between the two characters is so well done that if it were for an animated movie it would receive such high acclaim.

This game would have made a good book or film in its own right and it knew how to keep me continuing on.

Play this game if you want to support good story telling in video games.
"

reviewText:
This game may not be suited for someone who's looking for action and stuff.
No, this game is about exploring and storytelling. If you don't like things like that, better off not buying this game

In my opinion, this game has a good story and it builds up really nice. The ending may not look like a good one, but I expected it ends that way and it fits. It's trying to tell about human emotions and morale, questioning about what would you do if it's in their position and again it's not about action and stuff.

However, overall story is quite short. You could probably finish it in 2-3 hours if you are not really exploring other areas (or trying to grab books from from caches and places, go back and place them to your tower, yeah I did that).

The gameplay is really straight foward, you'll be immediately introduced with basic items on the 1st day and other things on further days which can be used to aid you to open up some locked path. I like the camera, where they allow us to capture photos and send them back to firewatch website to see any pictures you have taken. It's really a great idea and I love it!

Graphicwise, as I believe one of the main factor in the game. The game is a really piece of art. The flat cartoonish graphic which looks stunning with well built environment designs. I have no grudges to what they've done to it. Cheers to them!

The soundtracks are amazing as well! It really fits with the atmosphere! But some time it plays the music pretty randomly at some area. It may be attended though to enrich the feels, but I don't see why they set the music at certain area.

There are some bugs here and there, like stuck in some trees, which forces you to load the latest save or restart day to unstuck yourself. Some minor grapich bugs, like some models clipping to each other and some missing polygons. But you can barely see it if you are not paying attention.

Overall, great game! The game really does give me chill down to the spline. Especially after you finding out what happens to the story and the credits part is really a nice touch! (you have to play it to know understand what I said)  and breathtaking sceneries as well!

PS : Oh, and woot woot! James Benson is at it again with his animations! I kinda recognise his animation style in this game, but never thought it would be really him until I saw his name in the credits. What a lovely work!

reviewText:
Just played it through in one sitting, what an astonishing piece of work. The vivid colours and ambient detail,the humour both cynical and sarcastic, caustic and somber between Henry and Delilah, the story, the utter and absolute tragedy of the core story and of both Henry and Delilah's back story mixed with the back and forth radio comminique between these two had me almost in tears at times both sad one's and delightful one's.

I have no idea about how re-playable this game can be, maybe I will wait a few months before trying but it was the most delightful gaming experience I have had for a long time, sheer genius!

Gameplay is fairly linear, rather like a walking simulator with some aspects of exploration. It tells a wonderful story, is beautiful to look at. It has humour, sadness, some dialogue choices though I have no idea how each choice changes things after just one playthough but and I won't spoil this I hope, after Henry makes a discovery and reports it to Delilah and she breaks down in tears, I was crying alongside her, she was heartbroken, I was too. Whomever did the voice casting for this should be awarded whatever accolades go to the industry for this type of work, they played it so perfectly, flawless.

So I say goodbye to Henry, to Delilah, to Bucket Jnr and to the Flapjack fire with a great deal of sadness that we are parting like old friends. Maybe I'll come back next summer and we can chat again like old times.

Oh one final adieu, taking pictures in the game didn't seem relevant until the ending credits rolled...and there were all my pictures on display right alongside the words. A truly sweet little gift from the game devs to thank the player for playing. Thank you for that.

reviewText: Firewatch. Firewatch is proabably one of the most visually pleasing games I have ever seen, if you can't tell by all the screenshots I have. The story grabs you right from the begining and shoots you right in the heart. Then once you begin it brings it right back up on just how beautiful it is. Next they introduce you to Delilah in which you grow and bond with over your summer. She always right there with you on the walkie joking with you and helping you through your summer. Also she help point out some of the amazing views and colors in this game. Then they try to add in some weird twist, which I am not personally a fan of, but does had to this story. With that I think the story starts out amazing and jsut grows until it reachs this twist where I think it declines from there. And that bring us to the point of that everyone makes is that the ending sucks but it is a ending I saw a mile away so I really can't complain about. Also the game it's self is fairly short, I completed it in only 4 hours, with that though if felt a lot longer to me, about double the time .Overall I would highly recommend this game just for the visuals, they are a amazing, alone and the mostly good story doesn't hurt it either. So even though the game is short it really does not feel short and well definitely continue to play just to look at and take more screen shots to share it beauty.

reviewText:
As someone who enjoys staring at graphics, this game interested me. I would recommend learning as little as possible about the story. I just took the plunge, and went in with the mindset that this was a fairly linear yet mysterious game/story. I found myself thinking ahead alot, which made me worry, over thinking and adding to the mystery of the story.

I RECOMMEND TURING OFF MAP LOCATION.

Makes the game a bit harder, especially that first hour or so until you have gone down the path a few times. Takes a bit of skill to figure where you are on the map without a little dot, but I enjoy it and am very glad the devs included that option.

This game may be a bit steep on price so hours/price ratio, it took me 4.5 hours for my first playthrough without map location on. I explored most areas first playthrough, but not all, taking my time to enjoy the views though, playing it through the eyes of Henry (Hank) If you are unsure, wait for it to go on a bit of a sale. reviewText:
Firewatch is a beautiful game with some nice natural dialog and an okay story, but that's about it. It has about 4 hours worth of play time and quite little replay value.

The story, while exciting at times, feels a bit lacking in areas and I feel they could have done so much more with the tension and the relationship between Henry and Delilah. As the story unfolded I was coming up with a whole number of exciting theories that could have made for an epic conclusion, but sadly the ending is fairly bland and doesn't provide any real sort of closure. A missed oppertunity.

In hindsight I don't think the 18 bucks I spent on this game were really worth it, let alone the 20 it costs now. 12 to 15 dollars is probably a more realistic price for a short adventure game like this.

None the less, I did enjoy playing and I would recommend it if it comes at a price you are okay with for a 4 hour game.

reviewText:
I'll update when Ive completed but so far that opening and first day has been impressive to say the least.

So it took me about 3-4 hours to complete the game and that is with exploring every area. It truely is a masterpiece in story telling within a game, its been a long time since Ive just sat down and enjoyed the storyline as well as the gameplay.

However it has left an extremely sour taste in my mouth as I dont quite understand what one of the big plot points were, after another plot point is revealed the latter one seems to have been sweeped under the rug with hardly any explanation.

The dialogue and choices are fantastic but Im not sure whether I could bring myself to play through it again for the different dialogue alone as Ive got the feeling the ending wont change very much, if I find out there are varying paths which actually change the storyline I may play through it a second time but as it is the main draw in the game is the need to find out what is happening, other than that I  dont think the gameplay is enough to warrant a second playthrough once you now what is going to happen.

Bravo to the developers for making such an engrossing game, like heavy rain for the ps3 however, once you know the story you can never recapture the feeling of the first playthrough even with different dialogue choices.

reviewText:
Firewatch -  The Flagship Of Awesome Per Second

Firewatch is one of those gems that is rather a hit or miss. Personally, I enjoyed it. It is extremely short, (2.5-3 hrs long)
But the experiences you will have in those hours are the most memorable hours you will have with any story-driven game.

Gameplay
Firewatch is like a Telltale game, but you can move around and interact with the world semi-freely. You can pick up objects and examine them LANoire-style, and piece together story dialouge. If you are the type of the guy who rushes in and likes to blow things up, This probably not for you. If you like taking things slow and steady, observing every little detail, this game will be your soul mate.

Story
The story of firewatch is voiced, written, and delivered excepionally well. You can feel and hear the emotions in any character's dialouge, from the teeth jittering of realizing how ♥♥♥♥ed you are, to Delialah (Did i spell that right) understanding she asked too many questions. It takes a new stride in a type of storytelling, and im too afraid to spoil anything. But spoilers tho:
Dummy, i said i'm not going to spoil anything. Besides, if you already played the game and know the spoilers, why the hell are you reading this?

Asthetics/Atmosphere
Firewatch has a unique artstyle. from the indigo-smothered nights of mystery to the orange-baked rocks of Thunder Canyon, the atmosphere is very immersive. Your immersion may be broken a couple of times due to glitches, but you can glide past them.

Graphical Fedelity
Graphics aren't the new XXX_MLG_COD3_ADVANCEDFISHAI_GWAPHIX_XXX, But they are just enough to support the game. It's soft, warm, and likely won't need a monster computer to run.



Total Score: 8.5/10

reviewText: I want this game to have an overwhelmingly positive" review
hoursPlayed: because it is peculiar in how it contains it's narrative and how it lets you explore it. Many people will hate it
voteText: but it's because this game is not what they thought it would be
helpfulPercent: not because it's a bad game.\n\nIt's hard to explain why you may like or not this game without spoiling the surprises of it has
votesHelpful: because
votesTotal: while many compare it to Gone Home
votesFunny:
I'd say it's more like The Stanley Parable or The Beginner's Guide: It plays with your expectations. Even if it does so in a more subvertive way.

So I'll give it a try and tell you first what Firewatch IS NOT:
It's not a fully open world adventure game
It's not full of action
The ending is more akin to a Stephen King Story to an J.J. Abrahams or John Katzenbach one (take that as you will)
It's not a good thriller (despite what the trailers may led you to believe)
Firewatch doesn't give you a lot room to bend or shape the story. The characters are pretty well stablished and know what they want and who they are. You sort of help them pick reactions to some stuff but you're mostly a passanger in this unfolding story. You've been warned.

What Firewatch is is...
A very human story
A self contained story with an open-ended ending
A game that let's you explore in the same way Mafia II does: You can deviate from the path and see what you may find
commentsCount: but the story pushes you in very specific directionAll in all

reviewText:
There just simply isn't an easy way to describe Firewatch. For me it was an excellent game, which was very well designed and payed extreme detail to aspects such as voice acting and graphical art-style. However, honestly the game lacked some key features which could have made it 100 times better than it already is. I was hyped up for the release of this game but unfortunately it did not quite meet my expectations.

PROS:
-Excellent graphical art-style
-Some of the best voice acting I have ever heard
-Characters brought to life very well by the writers
-Optimised very well (apart from controller speed)

CONS:
-Length of game extremely short! 4.4 hours and I've already completed it
-Story a bit lame, felt kind of brain damaged by some of the choices
-The ending of the game wasn't up to standards.

Overall, I still think that Firewatch will still be one of the best games I have played in 2016 seeing as it was so in-depth and beautiful. Price wise, I think that the £13.49 that I spent to pre-purchase it is definately worth it and you should give it a try.

8.5/10

reviewText: I have never once beaten a game in one, single sitting until today. This game will suck you in and will not let you go until you have used every single ounce of energy in your body through emotion. I have never cried, laughed and been so angry at a story in my life, yes, I did cry, harder than I probably should have but seriously, the story is amazing. The game is fairly short but that is easily justified by the storyline which is completely saturated with the best writing and ideas I have ever experienced in a game. This style may not be for everyone, so be warned, but for those who enjoy very linear, story driven games like I do, you absolutely can not go wrong with this game.\n\nTL;DR: It feels like your emotions got thrown in a blender, 10/10

reviewText:
[No Spoilers]
Good start. Good characters and characterization. Mystery elements build up. Relationships develop and your view of Henry changes. Everything starts rolling momentum up and up and up until it feels like its going to come to some kind of climactic head...

And then nothing. The game ends. Nothing but a completely unsatisfying explanation for the strange events that happen throughout the story is given. Some of the events are even just handwaved away with an offhanded comment and never brought up again.

Not to mention it's three hours, maybe four hours long if you get lost in the woods at best.

I wanted to like this game, I DID like this game. That is, until it ended, and just left me with a bitter taste in my mouth. So much potential and so much GREAT suspense building just wasted. What a shame.

reviewText:
There just simply isn't an easy way to describe Firewatch. For me it was an excellent game, which was very well designed and payed extreme detail to aspects such as voice acting and graphical art-style. However, honestly the game lacked some key features which could have made it 100 times better than it already is. I was hyped up for the release of this game but unfortunately it did not quite meet my expectations.

PROS:
-Excellent graphical art-style
-Some of the best voice acting I have ever heard
-Characters brought to life very well by the writers
-Optimised very well (apart from controller speed)

CONS:
-Length of game extremely short! 4.4 hours and I've already completed it
-Story a bit lame, felt kind of brain damaged by some of the choices
-The ending of the game wasn't up to standards.

Overall, I still think that Firewatch will still be one of the best games I have played in 2016 seeing as it was so in-depth and beautiful. Price wise, I think that the £13.49 that I spent to pre-purchase it is definately worth it and you should give it a try.

8.5/10

reviewText:
So, I played Firewatch when it very first came out but seeing as though it's currently on sale I thought I'd finally write a review.

Firewatch is a beautifully crafted story driven mystery game which revolves around a man named Henry from Boulder, Colorado. Without spoiling the opening text based dialogue(great is fantasticly written by the way) He and his wife run into hard times and Henry decides to get away from it all by taking a job as a Firewatchman in Wyoming. While he works his  job he talks with his boss Delilah over their radios. The interaction between these 2 characters is some of the most well written and well voiced dialogue I can remember and you will not get tired of hearing their voices. I really don't want to ruin any of the main story because it unfolds in such a perfect way that you really have to discover for yourself to get the true impact of what's actually going on but they find out that some pretty 'creepy' stuff is going on.
Onto the gameplay, as I said earlier it is a story driven game so you don't do much other than walk from place to place talking with your boss and uncovering the next part of the mystery of whats happening in the woods around you.
The visuals are simply stunning and the art style is spot on, there isnt really much else I can say.
Other than the sound of Henry and Delilah's voices, there is the wind and the occasional music score when you find something relating to the main story.

All this being said it isnt a perfect game, the constant hiking can get a little bit boring the story will keep you going. My other gripe with this game is the ending, much like a lot of other people I felt like I was left empty handed. It does wrap up the story but not in the way I would have liked.

I'll a little about the performance now, I ran this on a i6500 and a GTX 960 on ultra @1080p and hardly dipped below 60fps other than when sometimes taking out the map when it would dip to 40-45.

All in all/TL; DR, I really enjoyed this game. The story was great, the voice acting is great, the visuals are great. I would whole heartedly recommend this to anyone who doesnt mind not being able to shoot everything in sight and appreciates a well paced story.

9/10.

reviewText:
This game - if you want to call it like that - is special in many ways: It contains very little game in the conventional sense, but nonetheless it has been thrilling me throughout the approxiately 3.5 hours of playtime. Most of this time you will be either walking or jogging through some awe-inspiring landscapes. If that's not the case, then you're reading a note or climbing rocks. That's about it, but that does not have to be negative. The story you're being told is nicely introduced and for the time playing entertaining and affecting, but I don't see it to be outstandingly well written or to be having a major impact on your thoughts. The story in combination with the superb voice-acting and the gorgeous and sheer beautiful artstyle produce a very intense atmosphere, although the story part ceases to support it that well towards the end in my humble opinion. Like I've just mentioned: The graphics are absolutely stunning and beautiful and the voice-acting is amazing and outstanding.

Now that you know, what I experienced while playing the game, let me elaborate, why I do recommend it.
It is by no means a clear recommendation for it really depends on your expectations towards this game. If you want to have a short-lasting but nice story with astounding visuals, superb voice-acting and if you don't mind the price, go get it. If you want value for your money, I would not recommend it for the price of 18$ for ~5$/hour is a bit expensive. I would also not recomend the game to anyone, who wants to take lead in a game and who wants to have game-mechanics to work with other than walking. But why do I recommend it overall? Because it is something special and unusual. In times of the sixtieth Assassin's Creed and the many early-access survival games, I like the idea of a game like this. It is small but good and does not aspire to be something other than what it is. The story is nice but thats about it. The graphics and the voice-acting are perhaps, from an objective point of view, the best parts of the game but I value the whole package. It has its flaws, but kept me entertained for an evening, and in the end I think that's what matters most.

reviewText:
2/10
Good artstyle

Everything else?
Poor (Read spoilers below)

the Story is lackluster. There is a few plotholes and you don't get any real ending.

There is no puzzles or anything that require you to think and a lot of useless backtracking

All in all, this was a very bad 20$ spent.
I usualy expect to play as many hours as I spent dollars on a game OR to get a amazing story.
I got none here.

reviewText:
No spoilers in this review.

When I first saw the trailers for this game, I immediately became interested in it, mostly because the dialogue seemed natural, the game itself looked interesting, and I had a big interest in climbing, hiking, and camping out in the woods.

PROS:
+ Great dialogue, there wasn't a single line that felt out of place
+Great voice acting, believable and not forced at any point.
+The feeling of the great outdoors is captured extremely well
+The feeling of unraveling a mystery as time goes on kept me on the edge of my seat
+What I thought was going to be the ending an hour in ended up not being the truth

Cons:
-The ride only lasted around three hours for me, well under what Campo Santo said it was, of four to six hours. I could understand if I just rushed through the story, but I took my time, explored the map, and got up to do some work for about twenty minutes and still only lasted about three hours
-Just an okay ending to the game. Nothing great, nothing awful.

Overall I'd say the game is worth looking into, but twenty dollars is a little steep for the playtime to dollar ratio. The story itself wasn't anything all that fantastic to justify it either.

When it goes under ten dollars it's a definite pickup. I'd say you could wait a few months to head into the forest.

reviewText:
I'm about an hour in and so far the game is very story driven. If you expected a survival open world game you won't seem to be getting it here, instead we have a hand crafted narrative experience that takes place in the wilderness Wyoming.

The graphics are damn good. The animation, the models, the textures, all of it looks amazing! I have no complaints so far about the presentation.

reviewText:
Review:              Firewatch.
Total playtime: Around 3-4 hours

Story:
Firewatch is a linear story driven experience that tells the tale of Henry.
a middleaged man with a troubled past that takes a job as a firewatch to get away from it all.

Opinion:
This... game, Its... different.
It had me hooked from the start, mainly because I'm a sucker for belivable storytelling.
I quickly fell in love with the characters, I loved hiking through the scenes layed before me.
Firewatch is not for everyone, it is a very classic game in the sense of that it almost playes out like a book.
But even with that, I would very much recommend it to new gamers, and most definitely to gamers that like storytelling.
Firewatch show's the audience how storytelling is done, how games can be that media of art that we all wish was already here.

I tip my head to Campo Santo and I wish new players a lot of fun.

Pros:
* Incredible Immersive storytelling.
* Unbelievable voice acting.
* Will not storyflip for shock value aka: it was aliens".

Cons:
* Can be a bit short for the seasoned gamer.
* Story jumps a lot forward

reviewText:
Firewatch may not be long, but I'm thinking there are some things I could have done that I didn't do.  I got a solid 5 hours out of my first playthrough.. but I'll probably go back and see how things might have happened if I'd done things differently.

Either way, The experience I got was worth the price of admission. For me, anyway.  This isn't for everybody.  It's essentially an adventure game.  It's not full of action or combat or anything like that.  You're exploring a world, uncovering and shaping a story, and getting immersed in your role as Henry as you do so.. learning about the only human you have contact with via a walkie-talkie, and making choices.  If you're not into that, well.. really, you should've already figured out you wouldn't like a game like this from watching the trailers and stuff.

I see a lot of people complaining about the length, or saying that this is just a walking simulator."  Whatever.  It was still one of the most engaging experiences I've had in months.  I will remember this game and the impact it had on me for a long time.

I won't say anything else

recommended: and I couldn't help but complete the whole game in one sitting.  Like a good book you can't put down

reviewText:
In writing a review of this game, I find myself in a real tough spot. There are two competing and equally reasonable viewpoints about this game, and I still don't know which side I find myself on even still.

On the one hand, this game is immensely polished in its graphics, gameplay, voicework and interface. If you read the comments from the team members who worked long nights for years building it, you really get a feel for the passion they put into the game and how much they cared about it all this time. For a freshman effort from an indie studio, this is an immensely impressive game, and I think our saturation with cheap AAA titles has led us to expect the world from these tiny teams.

On the other hand, I agree with many who say that the retail price seemed a little steep to me for a game with about 4 hours of total play time and not very much replayability. The storyline is quite linear, and while you can occasionally wander around off the beaten path, there isn't enough of that side material to justify playing the whole game through again.

So the question has to be, is this worth $15 or $20 or whatever to you?

If you're like me, without a reliable stream of income, it hurts the wallet a little more to think that I only got 4 good hours out of this, and I probably won't pick the game up again. Years of Steam sales and Humble Bundles have spoiled me by giving me dozens upon dozens of hours of replayable entertainment at pennies on the dollar. This game doesn't make that same value proposition, but once you realize that it's coming from an indie studio, it makes more sense why they're asking that amount for it. They've gotta keep the lights on, after all.

Consider it a compliment to the game and Campo Santo that it's so well-polished in so many respects that, at first, I assumed it was just pushed out by another big name publisher who wouldn't care about one refund in the big picture. You might get that feeling after playing it, too, but remember that this isn't a product put out by a giant, monolithic company, but rather a small and hard-working team of people. I wouldn't dare ask for a refund knowing that.

reviewText:
Firewatch is a character driven walking sim/exploration (not really sure what genre this game falls into) game about a middle aged man name Henry who decides to become a lookout in a forest to escape the problems in his life.

Excellent story, character interaction and voice acting. The world you play in is small but beautiful. Basically you go from point A to point B while talking to Delilah, another lookout, and stuff happens. I don't want to get spoilery about it.

I'm going to recommend the game, it's worth playing. But not for $20.  I played it for 4 hours and I'm already finished with it and will probably never play it again. But it was a very enjoyable experience. Buy it when you see it steeply discounted.

reviewText:
Wow! So many feels! All of the feels!

Within the first few minutes  I was a little aggravated about how linear the beginning area was and the fact that I was cleaning up cans. I began to wonder what I had gotten myself into.

Then the real story began. I went from feeling like putting the game down to not wanting to stop! My heart broke for Henry as I learned his story. Not just that, I needed to find out who that weirdo with the flashlight was and why there seemed to be a large fence in the middle of the forest.

I can say without a doubt that I absolutely recommend it! It channels a bit of Ethan Carter while having a life and identity all it's own. The humor is just my style and very endearing. I can easily see myself playing this game more than a few times.

Update: I finally finished the game and although it had a different ending than I expected, I really rather enjoyed it! I hope they make more games like this.

Sadly, it seems there a vocal minority of people who are very salty that most folks enjoyed the game for what it was. Maybe they will do the research next time before blindly making a purchase and blaming everyone else for their own ignorance. They can complain all they want, this game is still a top seller with mostly positive reviews. Owned.

reviewText:
Firewatch is the first game by Campo Santo, a story focused on a man named Henry and a woman called Dellailah. You will be in a gorgeous and natural setting in the entire game, just sit down and relax your summer in Yellowstone.

A very short summer.

The game starts with a moving intro, filled with evocative music, some choices and a backstory for our Henry, a deeply moving and very human backstory for a game. I was tremendously impressed about it, and I was more than ready to start the adventure.

But I guess the adventure took more time to arrive than I expected, because the main problem about Firewatch is the pacing, a very fast start for a …

Very slow rest. I’m a bit mad about how things came out because this game was one of my most expected games for this year, and I completed it in a single setting and still asking myself;

Is it just that?

reviewText:
Maybe I'm a sucker for narrative driven games, but this game is probably the best well spent 20€/$.

The dialogue between the main characters are so fluid, and they fit eachother like foil. The game looks great (a couple of glitches aside), and plays well. While the map isn't huge, and some days are short, exploration is still there.

Admittedly there's not much to explore, but I did feel rewarded for it, even if it meant hiking back to point A, after finding point B and wandering off to get the map points.

While there isn't much to actually do, besides progressing the story, the narrative is just so masterly crafted, I wouldn't mind getting another game like this. Replay value might not be the highest, but like Gone Home (which I enjoyed), it's one of those Play once

This is my first ever review, and im so glad its for this game.

My biggest flaw in the game? i want to relive it again without knowing or feeling what i just did. Great job

Regards

reviewText:
Another great entry into the narratively story driven exploration genre.
The story sucker punches you in its prologue and puts you into the shoes of an everyman struggling with an unavoidable conflict who decides to find serenity and take a break in the position of a fire lookout operator in Wyoming national park circa late 1980's.

What starts as a routine set of tasks and daily occurrences quickly turns into something that appears more sinister and throws the protagonists into a mystery to uncover. With only a radio and a voice on the other end of the line to a fellow tower operator, the feeling of isolation and helplessness reigns true as you delve deeper into the goings on and emotions start to shape and form what they perceive as the truth at the end of the rabbit hole.

Special mention has to go to the dialogue and voice acting as a whole for the two characters (The player character Henry - and Delilah, the voice on the radio) as they do a superb job and have some of the most believable and down-to-earth deliveries that I've seen in a game. The conversations flow quite naturally and make seamless references to other things you've talked about or seen, or in some cases stumbled across beforehand out of sequence. Plenty of genuine laugh out loud moments through this banter in the early portions too and the range of emotions varies as topics such as Henry's home life and reason for being here surface.

Has some beautiful scenery and lighting effects that I've stopped and admired at times, and an eerily somber soundtrack that picks up and backdrops during certain plot points or after particular revelations that added to the experience nicely.

A lot of people are concerning themselves with the length as if this were a replayable RPG or third person shooter to speedrun, I valued and enjoyed this for the story experience and clocked in at 4.2 hours personally. While there are a few optional side areas to explore and more notes/radio conversations to uncover, it does have to be stated that it is more of a linear narrative experience first and foremost.
At the end of the day a movie ticket for me would cost a similar $17.99 and provide about half that in length of storytelling and narrative, the quality of each comparatively obviously being subjective based on a case by case basis. So to me I have no regrets and found it justified, this is certainly going to be a point of contention and a turn-off for others though I gather.

Simply put it's not a game for everyone or for people who aren't into this particular genre and I can't for the life of me understand why non-fans of this established genre would even be so vocal and hate-filled that they appear to be on the message boards. But if you *are* a fan and did enjoy similar styles of art such as Gone Home or Dear Esther etc. as much as I did, then this should definitely be on your wishlist.

reviewText:
Disclosure: Review copy of Firewatch was provided by Campo Santo

Firewatch is essentially a walking simulator, but unlike others that don’t give you much, if anything to do, you are Henry as he finds his way through his new job. You’re in the middle of the Shoshone national forest in Wyoming and your every decision has a consequence, from what you decide to do with the most mundane of items, to how you treat and talk to other people. It’s all about being human, making connections and making decisions.

Firewatch is a short, succinct, game that tells the story it wants to tell. It offers a real look at developing relationships, choice and consequence, all with the beautifully rendered backdrop of the Shoshone national forest. It's a game that will stick with you beyond the finish and one that you'll want to go back to.

You can read my full review over at WCCFTech[wccftech.com].

reviewText:
OverviewSkip to the end for pros, cons and a quick summary.
Firewatch is a fairly short, story-driven adventure game by Campo Santo.
Playing as Henry, you head to Shoshone National Forest in Wyoming, having taken a summer job as a lookout. Your job is to spot fires and report them, but of course, you wind up doing more, thanks to your ever present companion Delilah, your boss. As soon as you begin your day, you’re tasked with finding people setting off some fireworks, and after that, your journey begins.

Let’s get it out of the way: Firewatch is short. If you take your time, explore the wilderness, talk to Delilah about pretty much anything, you’ll finish the game between five and six hours. If you rush to the conclusion, and only talk about what’s necessary to advance the story, you could probably do it in a couple hours. While the game is short, it is priced accordingly. If this were a $60 game, you’d have every right to be mad. But as it’s under $20, and with Firewatch being known to be short, you’ve no reason to argue about value for money, or being misinformed.

Throughout the game, you’ll explore various locations. The wilderness is “open”, but it’s also restricted. You’re blocked in by rocks, outcroppings, thick brush. Some of these will open later when you come across certain items, but not all of them. And don’t let the map size fool you. When you’re viewing your paper map, the wilderness may look big, but hiking from the north end to the south doesn’t take much time at all.

The story starts off really well. It maintains its intrigue throughout most of the game, but starts to falter at the end, and winds up not being as good as you had hoped. The story is pretty decent, and I did not expect it to end the way it did, but the ending seemed like a bit of a copout, unfortunately, and did not have the oomph I was expecting.

That said, the dialogue between Henry and Delilah is astounding. It’s very smooth and flows naturally, thanks to excellent voice acting by both people, as well as a very well written script. While the main story doesn’t change much throughout the game, the little touches are what make it fun. Naming the first hill you come across is reflected on your map, and slightly changes the dialogue. Telling Delilah how you look determines something you see near the end of the game. Even the introductory sequence with how you met and lived with Julia changes dialogue options later on in the game.

The game looks beautiful. The sun shines and reflects off of the environment, the environment is a joy to explore, there are nice details everywhere. Henry looks a bit odd when you see his hands, they look oddly sized, but the rest of the game is astounding. Campo Santo has crafted a fantastic version of Shoshone National Forest.

When it comes to sound, the game is great as well. You can hear rustling in the bushes, water rushing, leaves underfoot crunching, and various environmental sounds. Music is very limited, but works well in what it does. It cuts in at story moments, crecendos when it needs to, and works well within the story of the game. As mentioned earlier, it really is the dialogue between Henry and Delilah that is the selling point of Firewatch.

Unfortunately, Firewatch does not have much replayability once complete. It’s definitely worth a second playthrough to hear the alternate dialogue, but aside from that, nothing else changes. Since it’s short, a second playthrough will take you half the time. Maybe instead of having the beagle, you’ll have bought the other dog with Julia, Mayhem, and you’ll talk about him at a later point.

ProsExcellent graphics
Immersive dialogue made possible with fantastic acting and a great script
Excellent use of sound and music
Great story for most of it
Disposable camera photos can be developed and mailed to you in real lifeConsFairly shot, easily finished in single sitting
Not much replayability
Disappointing endingSummaryFirewatch is an enjoyable experience for its six hours of game (or less, if you rush). With fantastic acting and a good script, the conversations are what you’ll be here for, with the actual story taking a backseat. Do yourself a favor, and do not rush through the game. Explore. Find the little items and report them to Delilah to hear what she has to say.

And something that’s exclusive to the PC version, having your photos developed, is interesting. It’s definitely a novelty service, and doesn’t really add much to the game. When you do find the camera, you’ll notice it’s already been used. When you receive your developed photos, perhaps they’ll explain a bit more of the backstory. I purchased my photos just before writing this review, so I’m interested to see what will arrive in two to four weeks.

reviewText:
About 2 hours in, been waiting for this game for a year.

So far I love it. Everyone seems to jump on it for being short or 'on rails', but its the writing, the emotional weight to the story and the main character that sell this.

*edit*

Ok, just finished the game. What is the issue with the ending? It didnt feel rushed, everything was tied up and I fnished it with a smile on my face (the credit seqeuence is a nice touch). Is the game short? Yes, but it felt the right length for the story. Its very much a graphic novel and playing it like this makes it that much more enjoyable. If you go in thinking its open world, its not, its a story based game and the writing is excellent and the entire game shows the love its creators had for it.


I'd recommend this for more mature gamers or older people who like a slower paced, story driven experience.
