reviewText:
Firewatch is gorgeous, breathetaking, engaging... and slightly overpriced, but I don't regret buying this.
In Firewatch, you play as a man named Henry who is at a difficult stage in his life. He finds an ad in a newspaper for a Fire Lookout at Twoforks Park and takes the job to get away from his problems. Along the way, he's greeted by Delilah, a very chipper woman who runs you though the ropes in being a firewatchman (that's probably not an actual word, but I'm rolling with it regardless). Together you explore the forest, report any misshaps, and discover many secrets... Not all of which are pleasant.
Gameplay-wise, there isn't much to talk about since it's a very story-oriented game. You hike, climb, spelunk occasionally, and inspect/talk about nearly everything you lay your eyes on. This isn't a bad thing, however. Controlling Henry while walking through the forest is an awe-inspiring experience. From the amazing view from the watchtower to the lush, green fields and woods to the burned-down sections of the forest, you get to take in some of the most amazing visuals I've had the pleasure of witnessing. There was only one moment when I saw the end of one of the utility wires suspended in the air, but it didn't distact me for long.
There's a lot to say about the story but not without spoiling anything. The story was a joy to sit through the entire way and you come to care about these two characters who just want to have their own lives out in the wilderness but can't shake the feeling that someone is watching them...
In conclusion, this game was well worth the $16.50 (I got it on sale). If you're curious about the story but don't want to spend the money, there are plenty of YouTubers (I know Cry and Markiplier are nearing the end since writing this review) who will play it for you so you can see the story for itself. However, if you're anything like me and wants to experience a story rather than simply watch it, I highly reccommend picking it up.

reviewText: A compelling story with heavy thrilling elements based of a relationship between Henry (the main character) and Delilah (your supervisor) being torn apart by a mysterious being in the woods. The story is definitely very short, but incredibly suspenseful. Props to this indie studio for coming up with a very above-average story and expressing it nicely in their game. For the record, I would not recommend to buy this game at it's full price, unless story matters the most to you, rather than gameplay. Still nonetheless, a great story and would recommend it in general.

reviewText:
Definitely recommended, but if you're short on cash you might want to wait for a sale.
In my opinion this is one of the best looking games ever created. Similar to Life Is Strange, this game has a certain aesthetic to it that almost made it a must buy for me from the graphics alone.

A game is ofcourse more than graphics alone. In my opinion, this game is a must buy if you enjoy story driven games that lean towards the 'walking simulator' catergory, because that's what it does, and it does so wonderfully. Sure, the game isn't the longest, it took me a little more 3 hours to complete, but I feel like that is the perfect amount of time to tell the story in and make the player experience what the gameworld has to offer. To explain this a little more, some games feel a little 'forced' in the sense that they make you do certain things that don't add anything to the game experience itself (see Fallout 4: Another settlement needs our help!"). This game absolutely does not do that and that what makes it the perfect length for me. They also absolutely nailed the atmosphere in the game: it did make me feel certain things at certain times which made the game great for me. (I can't really elaborate without spoiling things)

However
date: there are 2 things I'd critisize the game for
recommended: and it seems like I'm not the only one in feeling that.\n\nFirst of
hoursPlayed: it doesn't really have any replayability
voteText: UNLESS you replay it for the visuals/dialog alone
helpfulPercent: to try and see if you've missed something your first time around. Other than that the story is pretty much what the game is based around and I don't think it will have the same inpact the second time playing it.\n\nThe second thing is the price point. I don't necessarily feel like the game is too expensive for what it delivered to me
votesHelpful:
but I can definitely see why you would feel otherwise. The ~€20 price point might be a little high for some people for the game it gives you and in that case I'd recommend you to wait for a sale.


Overall though
votesTotal: I loved this game and I would definitely recommend it simply for the game it is."

reviewText: It’s a gripping, compelling story set in a truly beautiful world that’s worth exploring. Just go in with your expectations clear. This is a relatively short game that’s almost entirely about the story, which consists almost entirely of two people talking over radios to one another. You play a chubby guy in his forties talking to, presumably, a woman of a similar age who you never see. There’s really nothing else like it I can think of, which makes it all the more rewarding...I loved Firewatch, mostly, letdown with the ending notwithstanding

reviewText:
Quite a unique game with its own flavour. Non-spoiler alert: this game is not for everyone. It has a slow pace, mainly relying on psychology, feelings, and of course the beauty of the graphics.

It sports a halo of mistery around it.

It is told like a novel, with atmospheric layouts and music. Yet it is a beautifully crafted openworld game with a pretty interesting story that packs no action whatsoever.

Preteens and teens: avoid this game. The rest of us are welcome to this piece of art.

reviewText:
This game is not for everyone.

This is a fact but that does not make Firewatch a bad game. In fact, the game itself is artfully executed with a lot of love and care from the developers with wonderful environments, well-crafted characters, and a lovely build-up.  With hints of the art style of The Long Dark and the tension and wonderful dialogue (and slightly misleading) from Gone Home, Firewatch has a lot of factors which make the money for the experience- but once again, this game is NOT for everyone and many people would not feel that the game is worth your time.

MY RECOMMENDATION: If you do not mind an emotional story about two people’s internal struggles with some great atmosphere, induced paranoia, beautiful graphics, and well developed characters that don’t involve as much external struggle, like fighting or shooting, then I recommend this game to you!

Pros:
+ A beautiful environment bursting with color.
+ An atmosphere fitting any scenario the game thrusts you into.
+ Branching dialogue and impressive voice acting.
+ Emotion inducing in some parts.
+ Henry is a badass middle-aged guy and is a likable main character and is very human.

Cons:
-	NOT A HORROR GAME (could be misconstrued as one, not the fault of the game).
-	Easily disliked by those who do not like dialogue driven stories with more emotion driven themes than an actual threat.
-	Easily lost, even when following the map and a lot of back tracking.
-	Getting from one point to another takes a long time, more so annoying when retracing steps BACK to a place you’ve already been. But the visuals and dialogue were interesting enough to keep me entertained.

** SPOILERS **
The most complaints that I have seen regards the ending, which I felt turned many people off to it- expecting a government or secret organizational conspiracy but ending up with a normalized story about a man who becomes a hermit due and is an individual watching both Henry and Delilah and tapping into their walkie talkies. While I did not mind this ending, I felt that there were some unanswered questions in the end and a lot of facts used to make the player believe in the potential, large conspiracy that were not answered or solved.
The story is NOT about the conspiracy, it is about the individual people involved in solving his conspiracy- Henry and Delilah are our main characters with flaws and are attempting to decide what to do with situations in their lives and the story inevitably is meant to help the player guide these characters into a decision about their lives. It is an internal struggle, being driven and changed by an external struggle, for both of these characters.

** Also to the reviewer who complained what Henry looked like and called him ugly- please pay more attention because his face was in a photograph and drawing since the beginning of the game **
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Game Score: 9/10
*A short game but an addicting storyline that keeps you wanting more.

The game has a rather short storyline that can be completed in 4 hours or less, however it is the storyline coupled with the graphics make this game easily one of the best small games ever. You started off as an ordinary guy who hikes in the wood then discover mysterious happening and then you are task to find out what is going on there. The game is very atmospheric, there will be some hilarious conversation that will have you laughing real hard while there will be some that gives you creep feeling like you are being followed by some mysterious guy in the woods. The games run really well even on ultra settings and it is worth mentioning that the musics is nice to listen to.

All in all, the game is worth purchasing on a sale and i just wish there will be extra content between Delilah and Henry.

reviewText:
This will be my first review of any game I have played on steam and I must say I just had to.  This game is simply wonderful with its gorgeous style of art/graphics. The gameplay is quite nice, despite it being mainly a walking simulater, made me feel i was there as Henry and felt I was a lookout ranger. For me, at times I felt i was playing a sims 3 type of game where i was able to look and interact with the items there. It was really cool when I was able to interact with the turtle ( when you pick him up for the first time,can't help but go aww its cute.)

Now many people say they don't like the fact that it is short, around 4 hours, however to me, it didn't feel short and felt like the length of the game was right. The story was interesting and every day left me wondering what is to come next, how is this new day going to be like, what is in hold for me. Some people say the ending was kinda okay or meh, and i would sorta of agree but at the same time felt like it was a good ending to the adventure and craziness that you and delilhia encountered and discovered together throughout the 3 or so months in game. For me, talking with delilhia was fun and enjoyable to talk with and throughout the game I just simply got more and more attached to her. There is a point in the game somewhere near the end where you just don't want her to leave as for me I felt alone without her. This game is simply amazing and if looking for a great game that allows for you to choose what  to say and enjoy a great story and great feeling of building and forming a relationship, it will not disappoint.


There are some fps drops which were annoying but even then I still kept playing the game and did not stop me from my immersed experience with the game. This game got me hooked and just wanted to play and see what was going to happen next and what new areas  we were going to see next day.

I do wish it was a  longer game but for how long the game was, I think it was still worth what i payed for it. :)

Would I pay the $17 again after having just played this game (at time of this review)(pre-order) Yes I definitely would.

Hoped this review was helpful.

P.S prefer for some feels.

reviewText:
A bitter-sweet story of a guy who's life derailed, and took a job in a forest part tower in Wyoming to... run away? sort out? his problems. It's a summer slice of someone's life, with a little bit of delusion and imagination-run-wild thrown in.

It's a really great, heartfelt, and emotional piece of story-telling.
And it's art-direction is top notch.

Come to it for that. Not for video-gamey-video-game stuff.

-Edit-

There's a plethora of bad reviews, thumbs down, and whining on the forums about 'this is pointless', 'the ending sucked', 'I want a refund', 'longer than 2 hours - cash grab, can't get refund, f-you devs'.  My response? You just don't get it.

The general vibe this game gives off is that it's -adult-. Not as in sexy, but adult as in mature. Henry is 39, has been through some bad stuff. He's confused, and running away from his situation. The middle act thriller piece? It doesn't happen in normal people's lives. And this is what this game is about - normal people. Stop expecting heroes journeys or power-fantasy wish-fuifillment from every video game.

This is something -different-.

reviewText:
From once you play the game you are thrown into the perspective of Henry, you quickly feel his pain and you choose how you deel with situations right off the bat. You are alone and all you have is someone on the other line of the walkie talkie.

This game is beatiful, though the world isn't very lively, but  it fits so well with the narrative. I feel alone in this world which is perfect, deeper into the story every day I walk around Two Forks I feel like I am being watched. This game is gripping and after playing for two straight hours I had to take a break to calm down from the thrill I just experienced. Other than the world. On the other line of your walkie talkie you have Delilah, as i progressed through the story I felt like I needed her more and more as the plot thickened, I felt deeply connected with her and felt like I knew her more than Julia in the story which was done great, Delilah was done great and she interacts with Henry perfectly, as both of you talk more you get connected to the story and you feel so much more immersed into the story that much more. Finally I love how Henry was created, sometimes I may not have a say into what he says I still feel like I chose what he said because this game kept me so deeply connected to this character. Finally I feel like the walking mechanics are great too, Henry's movement is a little lacking but it just adds to the fear I recieve when walking around in this game knowing I can't climb over every rock I see.

All in all this game is done great, with amazing narrative and a stunning and unique world. This is a game that may need you to pay attention a little more and channel your inner feelings to decide what to say to Delilah. Overall the story is gripping but I feel like the ending was a little lacking and a sour taste in my mouth. This game is wonderfull and I recommend it to anyone willing to dive into a new world and experience mystery, fear, and emotion.

reviewText: Amazing story with many relationships to build. You get a real feel for everyone in the game, best part is you design your own path. If you pick to be the clown and a goofy guy you will be that guy. So have fun with it when it asks you those types of questions, they really do matter. You never really fully understand what the hell is going on until pretty much the very end. You need to collect and read every note you see, it helps a lot. Also when you get the camera take some cool pictures  you view them later, and when I saw mine I really got the feels. Great gaming to play, even though many people watching it on streams are saying it's boring it is a game you must play yourself, hence all the options to make the guy yourself. I would give it a 8.5/10 due to the shortness of the game and the ending I wanted to see more then it would let me.

reviewText:
Good Game that is worth experiencing when on a Sale.
Not a bad game. The ending was a bit meh" but I didn't hate it. Overall I recommend it when the price gets lower or on a sale. I got it for $17.99 and beat the game while taking my  time and exploring in about 4 1/2 to 5 hours. I probably won't play this game again since there really isn't much in way of branching or alternative ending other than a few dialogue changes which I might just watch on youtube.

Voice acting and dialogue was top notch
date: both actors nailed it. Dialogue was really funny at times and at other time held great emotion that is conveyed through their tone. They did a good job portraying life as normal in the first couple chapters only to see things get very strange and the mystery to come to life half through. The game portrayed tension very well and had me at the edge of my seat until the climax and while I didn't hate how it ended I agree with a lot of reviewers that say it was a bit unsatisfying and lost a lot of the games momentum leading up to it.\n\nIf I had to put a numerical score to it I would give it a 7.5/10"

reviewText:
I have been casually checking on this game over the last year. Its a great game BUT i knew going into it what to expect. This is one of those almost" a movie / interactive story style games.

7.5/10

(-0.5) for small performance issues hardly noticed
date:
not crashes or anything major.
(-1.0) for not allowing me to carry Turt Reynolds to the escape chopper.
(-1.0) for lack of replay. (I was hoping for 2 playthroughs good / bad to see the difference.)

Its not a survival game (even though it looks like it). Choices exist only to amuse you provide a bit of flavor to your tastes. Minor alterations which allow you to slightly shape the circumstances /dialog of the narrative. Is that narative worth paying for? I think so yes but go into it expecting 3-6 hours at most. I stretched it to 10 hours exploring everything I could with my pet turtle. I think he was an easter egg of some sort. Sadly I could not escape to the chopper with Turt Reynolds because mechanic reasons and limitations. Apparently one cannot push the escape lift button to cross the canyon while carrying an adorable turtle. The loss of Turt proved too emotionally damaging for me to give this game a perfect score. As he gets himself to safety your thinking NO YOU ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ PICK UP YOUR TURTLE - AHH !

Seriously design an ending for saving your pet not leaving it to burn lol. (Granted I think i wasn't suposed to take him along during the final scene but what right minded person leaves their pet in a lookout tower which is said to catch fire and burn into ruin soon...

Anyway that being said...

Great game
recommended: amazing visuals. Fantastic voice acting dialogue
hoursPlayed: very thought provoking story. It handles darker concepts in life some younger gamers probably don't want to face. Having lost people in my life already at a young age I can identify with the themes its trying to convey. How to find peace with yourself . ect . Good game. I don't regret paying full price.  Although some may want to wait for a sale."

reviewText:
There seems to be some talk of the story's ending being of no significance or value, and being disappointing. However, those same people say that they were engaged and riveted to the end, this tells me that perhaps they are missing the point.

The game was a brilliantly crafted journey, with excellent voice acting and an incredibly engaging story. There were lulls of saftey and enjoyment, and peaks of uncertainty and concern. Nothing gave away the storyline along the way, leaving the mystery hanging in the air, allowing your imagination to go wild, and letting you contemplate what might be going on.

The game didn't resort to any tropes or deus ex machina like circumstances in order to make it feel like a blockbuster movie, it simply made sure to tell the story it intended to tell and stayed authentic and true to that goal. It was an incredibly refreshing journey, and just because the ending didn't have you diving off a cliff into a helicopter or being chased by an axe wielding murder, does not discredit the journey you took.

There were definitely lessons to learn along the way, but if your focus is on the ending then you may just miss them.

reviewText: Rather than a traditional game
date:
Firewatch is more of an interactive story.
It's...fun. In the sense that I really enjoyed learning about the characters (who are incredibly well written, I might add) and just progressing through the story.

Is it worth $20? Maaaaaybe not for everyone. I love story-driven games, so I think it was worth it, but you might not.

However,
That's not to say the game wasn't good, it was amazing. After about 15 minutes of playing I was fully immersed in the story and quickly lost track of time. The story here is amazing. The environments are done in an extremely beautiful art style that suck you into the world and make you want to stay. But the gameplay is very limited. You click to interact with things, but that's about all you can do.

The story is more or less what you make of it. If you like speedrunning through games just to get the required bits, you'll miss so much. I highly suggest you explore everything you can to get as much detail as possible about the world. That's where I found a good chunk of the fun in this game.

Pros:
-Great story
-Awesome visuals
-Believeable characters
-Great soundtrack
-Large amount of detail


Cons:
-Limited Gameplay
-Some minor graphical bugs, and rare but noticable frame drops (I have an i7-4790K and a GTX 980, for reference)
-Relatively low replayability

Do I recommend this game?
At its current price, it's a maybe. If you really really like story-driven games like me, then I'd say $20 is a very fair price. I feel like I got my money's worth.

If you don't, and you just want something to kill time, I'd wait for a sale.

reviewText:
If you haven't considered this game yet, please do.
This type of game is rare, especially for a debut studio. Yes, the game is short but its the perfect length to where it isn't drug on to be something it's not and seeing as to how each choice you make changes the outcome of the game, you can replay it over again and get something different. The environment is astounding both visually and audibly, the voice acting is unlike any other game I have played. The animations are by far the most fluid I've seen, better than any AAA studio has ever produced. This game evokes utter immersion with a hard hitting story coupled with such a rich environment and voice acting, all are essential for any single player game today. All these elements make you feel like you're alive within the world.


All in all, this is an amazing game and I for one am impressed at how easy it is to get lost within this story, I am going to replay it again tomorrow, with different choices from my first time and see how much of a different story I am able to produce. I would strongly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Absolutely fantastic game in my eyes, but may contain red flags for potential buyers.
POSTIVES:
Simple, yet interesting prelude to the main story, providing needed information.
Story progresses quickly. Keeps you interested. Keeps you on the edge of your seat at points.
Great, natural dialogue that is performed very well and doesn't seem out of place no matter what choices you make.
Fantastic visuals and design. Very simple, but stunning.
Lots of walking, allowing time for the story to progress and the visuals to be seen.
NEGATIVES:
Rather anticlimactic ending.
Completed in roughly 3 hours and 40 minutes.
Lots of walking.
OVERVIEW
I highly recommend this game. The gameplay is very simple, but you are kept interested through the progression of the story and interactive conversations. The design of the game is sexy as ♥♥♥♥ and I am in love with how gorgeous it is. There is a lot of walking in the game which allows the story to advance, but it may seem monotonous to some. It's also rather short and has an anticlimactic ending. If you let those last few factors turn you off, I don't blame you, but I highly recommend that you try it first. If the first 2 hours doesn't impress you, get a refund. I do not regret paying $18 for this game.

reviewText:
About 2 hours in, been waiting for this game for a year.

So far I love it. Everyone seems to jump on it for being short or 'on rails', but its the writing, the emotional weight to the story and the main character that sell this.

*edit*

Ok, just finished the game. What is the issue with the ending? It didnt feel rushed, everything was tied up and I fnished it with a smile on my face (the credit seqeuence is a nice touch). Is the game short? Yes, but it felt the right length for the story. Its very much a graphic novel and playing it like this makes it that much more enjoyable. If you go in thinking its open world, its not, its a story based game and the writing is excellent and the entire game shows the love its creators had for it.


I'd recommend this for more mature gamers or older people who like a slower paced, story driven experience.

reviewText:
Well, I only got 3 hours of playtime from one completion, but if I'm satisfied with the experience, that's what matters, right?

Firewatch was a well-crafted experience, and is an interactive story that adjusts to the player's input without sacrificing the plot's consistency.

The voice acting and writing came together to create characters that are colorful and inviting, despite spending the game invisible to the viewer.

The sound, music, and visuals come together to create a simple yet convincing and coherent world that draws you in.

To me, this is easily the most impressive interactive narrative to date.

reviewText:
Ostensibly Firewatch is a game about a guy who goes into the woods to escape his problems and finds mystery and excitement therein. But the first part of that: the escaping into the woods part is what Firewatch really focuses on.

The game gets a lot right when it comes to presenting a narrative and environment to explore. Its world is fleshed out and there is no doubt of who you are or where you’re going.

Where the game falls short and where a lot of review negativity surrounding this game comes from the game also having a console release.  I believe the marketing for this game was sort of presented it as an action/mystery game. Trailers showed things like falling down a shale cliff or a stranger shining a flashlight in your face with a panicked voice-over. If that action/mystery is what you’re here for, you may be disappointed.

This game does have elements of mystery, it does have elements of action but it is neither an action nor a mystery game. Its core experience is the relationship between people who want to be left alone but can’t ever escape their need for others.

Most players won’t find this experience worth the $20.00 price-tag. It’s well written and beautiful and considering the size of the studio and the stunning graphic and voice work I felt the price was fair but for those who are merely curious I suggest getting it when it’s on sale at -50%.

reviewText:
This is one of the first game reviews I have written on Steam.  Why?  Because Firewatch deserved it.  The game was AMAZING.  As some other reviewers have stated, it is shortish.  I beat it in only a mater of hours but I still loved it.  Why? Because I viewed it as an interative movie, not just a game.  It was a story that I got to experience.

Was the game worth 19.99?  YES!!!!  For the experience I had, I probably would have paid more.  I loved the game.  I may have played a large portion of the game drunk, but it was amazing.  This is a game I could reasonably see myself replaying.  I even recommended it to my friends and told my fiance to play it.

If you like a game that has a true story and beautiful scenery try this game!

reviewText:
Review Date - 2/10/2016 @ 2:10 AM - Work Day - Shows you how much I want to say, great job.
Initial Review - 8.5 - Pretty Darn Tootin Good & Funny

I came into this game watching the 20 Minute Gameplay Video from a few months ago, thinking looks like a very serene and interesting adventure game, this being the first adventure game I've played in a very long time (aka Myst, Riven, 7th Guest, and Shivers - You get the idea, its been a really, really long time). Though I was kinda expecting puzzels as most adventure games use to add filler and content into the game, I was really lead into sort of a Radio Simulation / Forest Lookout kind of scenes, now I am gonna be honest I came into this game thinking it was gonna be a good laugh with maybe some interesting story elements, yea well, started and played the game and laughed my ♥♥♥ off through the first few days. Good work on the Play acting, this I give a whopping 95 / 100, which AAA Titles I rarely give more than 90, so Woot Campo, Shame Big Titles.)

Gameplay / Performance - Game runs smooth, beautiful hardly any kind of slow downs or inital bugs on release, very nice, Fallout 4 nice. I am proud of indie developers when their games come out and show such dedication towards their code, and game structure that other big titles think they'll fix in a couple patches down the road, I am talking to you Firaxis (XCOM 2), though Cid Meiers: Beyond Earth was pretty okay on release and was glad for something similar to Alpha Centuari for a change. Anyway off topic, Gameplay is engaging and well designed, especially how it develops as conversations change between playthoughs, its not huge, but nice, replayability comes in handy.
A few moments of fright come into this game, especially with the wildlife and finding certain things, there were a few points I won't spoil the scenes, but lets say it made me feel like I was playing Doom 3 again with the lights off and a Imp leaps out at you from a dark corner and basically turns you butt over head from the back of your chair. Bravo Campo, that was exciting.

Overall Review - 9.0 - Great job, always room for improvement, add some additional game DLC between the days that are set already, give us some additional playtime by doing so, and maybe a few additional funny scenes and we'll call it Super Indie Extravaganza, as you made me smile from playing your game. That and if you decide to get intuitive, and create a Mirror Episode for this game that puts you in the option to be Julia coming out there, and Henry is the one that gets well whatever he gets (No Spoilers here), that would be spectacular.

Great Job - Faith for Indie Games High, Faith for AAA Titles of 2016 - Moderately Low...
Reasons - SPAZ 2 Looks Beautiful - Delayed but still nice
Firewatch - Adding some much needed flare in the game industry, we see way too much zombie $hit lately.
Tom Clancy's: The Division - Not Looking as good as when they announced it a couple years ago.
XCOM 2: Came out really ♥♥♥♥ poor in performance with bugs, great game but gonna wait for a patch before attempting normal difficulty.

reviewText:
This looked so promising. I watched a preview gameplay on youtube and I thought to myself that I had to play this for myself. Oh was I fooled. This review might be pretty long and contain serious spoilers. TL;DR: The game has good and bad elements. It depends on how you look at it. Overall, the game isn't worth 20 EUR, not even in an alternate universe. Replayablity is a massive problem.

There are a couple of good points about the game but the rest of the stuff is BAD.

Let's start with the good points:
Excellent voice acting
Great dialogue
Very intriguing beginning

Now, for the rest:

The beginning is really very strong. First minutes are quite emotional, then when the game actually starts there is a really good buildup. Then it gets spooky and mysterious; however, after a while it kinda just flatlines and starts going downhill from there. Only at the very end it felt a little exciting again but that was just me thinking there's more to it than there actually is.

The game is split into days. Many days are skipped but I guess that makes sense. Some days are just tiny flashes, which I didn't really like. Other days you get to walk a lot, which is ok but gets repetitive. The world is actually extremely simple - a bunch of corridors, and you're very limited in terms of movement. There is a little bit of exploration, even though it's most likely completely unnecessary. My playthrough took a little over 5 hours, and I didn't even see everything that was in the trailers but that's not the point. I'll get back to the gameplay time later.

The ending was extremely disappointing. There is this mystery, which made me kinda paranoid. I was expecting someone to try to murder me at several points. I guess that was the point, to make the player feel paranoid. The solution of the mystery was very meh. There is no substance behind the mystery, nothing that would justify its existence. It made no sense after it was revealed. It's there just for the sake of there being a msytery, and that's bad.

The relationship buildup is interesting, and it really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off that there was a disappointing ending to this. You can also look at this as a good thing - emotional reaction from the player. What I dislike here is that the game was fooling me  all the time. From the dialogue between Henry and Delilah, I got the feeling they might want to meet. And then she just ran away. This makes me want to try to play again, just to see if there is a different ending, if there's a chance she waits there at the end. But here's the problem. I am not willing to spend another 5-6 hours of my life hodling down the W key and occasionally pressing spacebar to find out. Alright, alright, you get to press Shift pretty often...but that doesn't help. One more bad thing here is that we don't get to find out anything about what H and D actually do after the game ends.

Another major problem with the game...there is no wildlife, like none whatsoever. There is one raccoon. I also saw a butterfly. I assume there were birds I didn't notice. That's it.

There's also a pretty big hole in the story. There's this research place in the forest. It's not on the map, and Delilah doesn't know about it. This makes no sense whatsoever, since it's a university research site and Delilah has had the job for years. It should be on the map and she should know about it. It's just mystified for the sake of the mystery.

Not worth the full price. If you want this game, get it during a sale when it's at a massive discount.

reviewText:
all in all, if you're desperate for a walking simulator,cuz you are a hermit who can never have conversations in the real world, or actually go outside. this is a close second to the real thing. Kinda similar to a movie in a sense, idek right now. I know it's not about how much time i spent in it, but really, 3 hours? felt like i was taking it slow too.

The thing is, I was hoping this game would really get to me, on the feels, you know? But, I guess i'm a heartless prick, cuz I'm pretty sure I felt the feels harder in Everlasting summer, which is a free game.  And is also roughly 6-7 hours long, and has multiple endings.

I'm sorry this review has little to no structure to it, but, I'm just writing down what I'm feeling about this game. I would love to give it a positive review, really. Yet, I must've put my hopes a little too high. Did it suck me in? sure, but only for 3 hours, and was really just a bunch of small talk, other than near the end, which was a fizzle. Really, was it worth $20, maybe. But it isn't really that diamond in the rough ( ALLADIN!) that i'm sure a lot of people were hoping for.

Now, would I recommend it? that's a tricky one, there are tons of games that come to mind when I think recommend, games that were life changers. Games that could take so much of my time, and i would still love them. I mean, not even looking at the amount of time, the game kinda felt dull, idk, dull comes to mind, maybe ther is a better word. What I'm trying to say is that this game didn't blow me away, and I probably won't tell my friends to bother with it either, just so they don't yell at me.

Now, you can read this review in a blitering fury, and write down a entire essay about how i'm wrong and you're right, and you don't need to tell me that. This is MY opinion, and yours is yours. I'm sure you loved it, I really am. but because I can't read minds, i dont really know what other people were expecting, so i wrote this review as if i was talking to a past me. Not you, I dont know you, I don't even know that many people, and out of the few people i know, there are some that would love it. Yet, I can't write a review for them, I'm writing one for me. So please, let me live my life in peace, and you do the same.

reviewText:
I would fully recommend this game, it is definitely one of my contenders for top game of the year!

With the looks of a 'AAA' Game, even on the lower settings it still manages to pull off its interesting but beautiful art style.

The game has a very compelling narrative with interesting and believable characters that even from the start you begin to feel for and you root for them. Whilst it may fell to start off slow and somewhat empty as you reverse the lovely open world forest, you soon forget about the cross-map hikes as you are too interested in the quickly growing story line.

The controls took me a while to grasp but made sense quickly afterwards. I decided to play this on a game pad as it feels to have a more casual play style to it.

I don't want to say too much about the story as it is one of the games you need to play yourself. So don't watch any of the game play on YouTube if you are even considering this game.

Whilst I haven’t finished the story and have only played 85 minutes at the time of this review. That was a solid 85 minutes spent playing the game. 85 I thoroughly enjoyed and only stopped As school work just about took priority for me.

I think that's all I have to say. This is a game that is well worth the £14.99 price tag on steam, maybe even under priced for the amount of amply and enjoyment I have gotten from. If any of the development team see this. Well done. This is an amazing game and you have a real talent for story telling and game development. I will definitely be following this studio for more games in the future as this game somewhat got me back into PC gaming.

This review may seem a bit bit but this game deserves all the praise it can get. I hope this was usefu to anyone considering the game. Buy it now!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
The phrase 'interactive book' normally is a negative but in this case it is a massive compliment.

I can't think of many games where I felt emotionally involved from the start. The closest emotional involvement I can compare to was in The Last of Us, but in Firewatch it's a much more grown up experience.

I am of a similar age to the characters in the game so perhaps this is why it resonated with me , but I think all gamers will appreciate the solid story telling in this game.

On top of that the game is very pretty. It has a stylised  art direction but it works so well, and as the game progresses the colours change along with the darkening story line.

All in all this is a great gaming experimented and the only downside is that it is a little short, completed in 4 hours, but it feels ok for it to be that short.

There is also a great thing involving photographs which I will let you discover on your own!

I can't recommend   this enough!

9 out of 10

Well this game is actually something. In short its a great game. Loved it all the way through and always had my attention. It even actually had me say my god" out loud and to be honest only 1 other game made me do that ever.
On the down side its is only about 4 hours long and I really do wish it was longer. I took my time and even listned to the conversations the two characters had between one another. The ending either good or bad depending on your personal preference.

reviewText:
Definitely recommended, but if you're short on cash you might want to wait for a sale.
In my opinion this is one of the best looking games ever created. Similar to Life Is Strange, this game has a certain aesthetic to it that almost made it a must buy for me from the graphics alone.

A game is ofcourse more than graphics alone. In my opinion, this game is a must buy if you enjoy story driven games that lean towards the 'walking simulator' catergory, because that's what it does, and it does so wonderfully. Sure, the game isn't the longest, it took me a little more 3 hours to complete, but I feel like that is the perfect amount of time to tell the story in and make the player experience what the gameworld has to offer. To explain this a little more, some games feel a little 'forced' in the sense that they make you do certain things that don't add anything to the game experience itself (see Fallout 4: Another settlement needs our help!"). This game absolutely does not do that and that what makes it the perfect length for me. They also absolutely nailed the atmosphere in the game: it did make me feel certain things at certain times which made the game great for me. (I can't really elaborate without spoiling things)

However

reviewText:
Firewatch was a decent, slightly different kind of game. The characters and dialogue were above average. The story was a bit rushed. The ending is somewhat unsatisfying but I think that the unsatisfying ending worked for the story.
It's more like an interactive story than a game, but worth playing and pretty to look at. Firewatch was sort of like one of those long, boring not-quite-that-good indie flicks where not much happens (except characters either grow or don't grow, and that's the point of the story!) in compressed form.

It was worth playing and a refreshing change from most games of its ilk.

reviewText:
This game, well, is short. I want to make that clear. 4.5 hours of my logged time is me accidentally leaving it on because I was going to be late to work if I didn't leave. But this game is simple, and it doesn't try to be more than simple. It plays with our expectations, our way of looking at the world and games and the idea of conspiracies.

But most of all it teaches you about yourself. Not many people will look at Henry and understand exactly what is happening to him, that I know. But it show's the player how they would handle the situation. It's hard not to give spoilers, but I'll be damned if I do, so just know that you'll get a better sense of yourself by the end. Are you willing to please other's at your own expense, or do you need your way even if it makes them uncomfortable?

This game is beautiful. This game is funny. This game is... depressing. It's very real in certain senses, and I think some are taking their unease at the games ending a bit too far and too personal. The reality of escapism manifested as a game, is what I might call it.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I came into this game knowing next to nothing about it. I only learned about it the day before its release. I went in blind with no expectations.

Firewatch is a game for people who like heavy narrative and dialogue - i.e. a story, and a very sad one at that. If you don't like stories, and especially if you don't like sad stories, don't play Firewatch. I happen to love sad stories, which is why I loved this game.

You're not going to find any sort of intensive (or even remotely challenging) gameplay here. This game is strictly a guided narrative; the gameplay is secondary, something to keep you active while you engage with the story. However, I remained deeply emotionally invested throughout the entire experience. The game is visually stunning, and though the aesthetic is slightly cartoonish, I never once felt as though my sense of realism or immersion was broken. But the real engagement is 100% as a result of the absolutely fantastic voice acting. I felt so invested in the characters, I think more than I have been in any other game I've played.

Some cons are the runtime and the pricetag. Just shy of $20 is too much for a game that takes less than 4 hours to beat. Granted, I found those 4 hours to be riveting, but I think my experience would have been more (soul-crushingly) fulfilling if I had paid $10 for this game. Also, there is no incentive for replayability - play through the storyline once, and you've seen everything the game has to offer.

A lot of people are complaining about the ending (don't worry, no spoilers). I was upset with it at first, too, but then I sat a while and thought about it, and realized that the ending is what makes this game so brilliant. I urge those who are upset with the ending to really spend some time being introspective.

This game is wonderfully written; a short story personified. A model for narrative realism in video games.

Score: 8.5/10

reviewText:
*SPOILERS INCLUDED* View with caution!

To sum this game up it is a heavily story driven walking simulator with Gorgeous Lighting,Particals,Dialogue, and Animations.

The game is set in 1998 Yellow Stone National Park where you play as Henry a man who is trying to escape his issues back home by working a summer job as a FireWatch that he found in an advertisment. Right off the bat you are introduced to Delilah your ''Boss'' she is the Character that you are alongside throughout the entire game(Via Radio Conversations). As the days progress the relationship between them builds. Then roughly half way through the game after a fire starts to build in the forest you find out that your conversations with Delilah have been recorded. Paranoia develope in both characters until you eventually find out who was behind the recordings. At the end of the game you take a Rail Car over to Delilahs watch tower where you await to be picked up by helicopter. Delilah gets picked up before you and when you arive inside the watch tower you call her the last conversation of the game happens Delilah decides to go back to her home and you decide to go back home and see your ill wife. You hop in the helicopter and then the credits roll.

Overall the story was very well written and i felt the connection between both characters as the story developed. I havent seen a game like this in a long time and i hope other creators see this as inspiration for their game!

Pros:
-Outstanding Animations, Dialogue, Effects
-Runs well in 99.99% of the map
-Beautifully written story
-Perfect timing of the music when events occur
-Amazing Character development
-Great voice acting

Cons:
-Only 3-4 HOURS of gameplay for a 20 dollar Title! (This is the main reason why this game gets its hate)
-The ending fell short of its leading up Which left a lot of people dissapointed
-Barely any replay ability :/

Overall: For the experience I would definitely buy this game. It does has its flaws ,but the Pros Insanely out way the Cons
Rating : 8.9/10
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
You know what I loved about this game (which Im playing through a shared account, but plan on picking up when Im not so poor)? The subtle nature of it all, there are peaks and valleys, but through all of it the story is really about the relationship being formed between the two characters.

Im not going to spoil anything here, but the high points in terms of excitement are def around the 3/4s way through, which leads to a resolution that is human, and believable. It reminds me of a movie in that regard, a good movie that doesnt have to end with an explosion, just open ended with enough information to leave you wondering and contemplate the characters.

Lots of people have talked about the choices you make not having a bearing on the outcome, but those outcomes happen mostly in real time. Its about how you choose to communicate, and it changes the ebb and flow of the game.

Ya know sometimes I love action, sometimes I want silly fun, but sometimes I want to sink my head into something that makes me think, or, just plants me in the environment and atmosphere of a tale; it doesnt necessarily need a beginning middle and end, I dont need the Heros Journey all over again, I just want to immerse myself. Thats what this game was to me.

I got vibes of the movie Fargo for some reason, mainly in the back and forth dialogue I think, and the whole escalating mystery. The resolution too, with how it came back down to earth, reminded me of that sort of writing. One that doesnt simply pander to an audience that needs stimulation every thirty seconds.

I sat down at midnight last night, and started playing this game after my friend told me how great it was, we have similar taste. I had expected to go to sleep around an hour later, and was still awake at five in the morning unable to leave the story unresolved.
My overall playtime was five hours, none of that felt drawn out, and I didnt particularly stop to smell the roses as I was so drawn into the story. I see most people quoting 2-3hrs, and personally dont know how they did it.

Overall, sure this game isnt going to be for everyone, just like there are plenty of games that arent to my tastes. To the people this does appeal to though, its something to cherish because we really dont get enough of this sort of story in games.

Thank you devs, for your time, your story, for taking that risk.

reviewText:

What this game isn't:
- An open world game
- The Long Dark
- A survival game
- A puzzle game

So if you go in expecting that, then you should have a pleasant time.

The ending isn't for everyone, but I was quite happy with it. I think there was room for expansion, but it wasn't necessary. It keeps it short and sweet.

reviewText: Rather than a traditional game
date:
Firewatch is more of an interactive story.
It's...fun. In the sense that I really enjoyed learning about the characters (who are incredibly well written, I might add) and just progressing through the story.

Is it worth $20? Maaaaaybe not for everyone. I love story-driven games, so I think it was worth it, but you might not.

However,
That's not to say the game wasn't good, it was amazing. After about 15 minutes of playing I was fully immersed in the story and quickly lost track of time. The story here is amazing. The environments are done in an extremely beautiful art style that suck you into the world and make you want to stay. But the gameplay is very limited. You click to interact with things, but that's about all you can do.

The story is more or less what you make of it. If you like speedrunning through games just to get the required bits, you'll miss so much. I highly suggest you explore everything you can to get as much detail as possible about the world. That's where I found a good chunk of the fun in this game.

Pros:
-Great story
-Awesome visuals
-Believeable characters
-Great soundtrack
-Large amount of detail


Cons:
-Limited Gameplay
-Some minor graphical bugs, and rare but noticable frame drops (I have an i7-4790K and a GTX 980, for reference)
-Relatively low replayability

Do I recommend this game?
At its current price, it's a maybe. If you really really like story-driven games like me, then I'd say $20 is a very fair price. I feel like I got my money's worth.

If you don't, and you just want something to kill time, I'd wait for a sale.

reviewText:
Campo Santo's debut adventure offers up a taut mystery built around two tremendously engaging characters.

[ PROS ]

A Beautiful video game with some outstanding voice acting proformances.
Graphics are extremely done well
Extremely optimized ( Currently running 760 GTX )
Decent humor


[ Cons ]

A extremely short ride that leaves you feeling a little empty at the end ( it's like a slow hike up the trail, only to instantly get pushed down a cliff. )
Decently short (3/4 hours) ( explored for about 3+ hours to see if there was more - NOPE )
Bait and switch style ending, really waiting for a twist that never comes.
The ending feels like they ran out of budget & just wanted to end it.
Invisible walls everywhere.


Overall my rating :

9/10 Graphics ; Atmosphere ; Immersion
7.5/10 Story & Banter
6/10 Length


Overal 7.5 Tops.

Price per length Buy Deluxe Edition $14.99 or less

Final notes : if there was more to do in the game I would be incline to give this game a better rating.

Examples of more stuff they could have done.

Added more events, campers, potentional fires, fishing, more expoloring ( extend map ).


Do I thing this game has more potentional, YES. Does it in it current state well that is something to talk about at Pork Pond...

reviewText:
I remember seeing this game somewhere ... E3, maybe? Yes. E3. I didn't think much of it, I didn't get hype, I barely remember thinking that the visual style was nice and the story seemed appealing and mysterious. Now, I got reminded of the game's existence today by funkE who was streaming it earlier today. I watched the stream a bit and immidiately closed it. I don't want to see the game, I want to  play the ♥♥♥♥ out of it. Now.  And it's what I did! Saw the price, sure it's low and obviously it's not going to be a 10+ hour game, which is considered a con towards the game by some people, but let's not get there yet. I buy it, install it and start playing. One sitting later, I finish the game.

Was it great? Yes. The prime asset of any adventure-type game is that the journey is the most important aspect. Not the end. Despite the end coming faster than expected, Firewatch delivered what I consider an amazing and inspiring journey. Oh, gotta keep this spoiler free ... Almost slipped there! Anyhow, I don't want to  write a book  about this game, so let's just say that for it's faily low price (from my standards), the emotions and the beauty of it all really makes it worth it. All in all, alas, I thoroughly recommend Firewatch.

Oh! Almost forgot. The only thing I really want about this game is continuity, like DLC. Maybe that's just me and the game is bound to be shrouded in mystery (what I mean by that is what happens after the game ends.) You really get attached (with a tight  rope , really) to the characters, heck, even Delilah, who, mild spoiler, is never seen throughout the adventure.

TL;DR

Good game. Worth buying. Definitely looking out for more about this game in the future.

Thank you for the experience!
